name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the European Parliament's position on the Conference on the Future of Europe (2019/2990(RSP)).

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to discuss the project of a Conference on the Future of Europe, which has emerged over the last months and, in particular, to listen to a debate on the Parliament’s position. As Prime Minister Plenković told you yesterday, as far as the Council is concerned, we are starting work to define our position regarding the establishment of the Conference. As you know, the December European Council gave us guidance to this effect. We believe that priority should be given to the implementation of the strategic agenda for 2019-2024, agreed in June last year, and to delivering concrete results for the benefit of our citizens. The priorities outlined in the strategic agenda closely echo those raised by our citizens, for instance in the citizen consultations and dialogues. The Conference should build on the success of these dialogues over the last two years. Yesterday, my Prime Minister underlined how the Conference could be an opportunity to listen to citizens so that we are better able to meet their expectations.  We think the Conference should contribute to the development of our policies in the medium and long term so that we can better tackle current and future challenges. We also believe the upcoming Conference should be an inclusive process, involving our three institutions in full respect of the interinstitutional balance of our respective roles. Likewise, Member States should equally be involved, including their parliaments. Shared ownership is important.  The European Council asked the Croatian Presidency to work towards defining a Council position on the content, scope, composition and functioning of a Conference on the Future of Europe and to engage on this basis with the European Parliament and the Commission. We are indeed starting this work and I can announce to you that, today in Brussels, ambassadors will have a first informal exchange of views to that end, and that the General Affairs Council on 28 January will discuss the issue. We will listen to your debate on the Parliament’s position and read your resolution attentively. We also look forward to the Commission’s input, which we understand will come back next week. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, it is an honour to be here today in the heart of European democracy to discuss the conference on the future of Europe video. As a previous Member of this House, I consider the European Parliament as a close friend. Today I stand before you, honourable Members, still as your friend and now also as your partner in my new role as Vice-President for Democracy and Demography. Like you, I know how important citizens are to European policy-making: after all we are making these decisions to their benefit. However, we have not always got that right – this must be acknowledged. Now we have an opportunity to reflect with citizens, to listen to them, to connect and engage, to answer and explain, to build trust and confidence in each other between the European Union and citizens. This is an important part of what the Conference on the Future of Europe is about. We are at a key moment in European political history and are facing a unique opportunity, as well as a challenge. Getting this right will have repercussions, not just for the present but for the future. It is up to us all to make this a success. Honourable Members, let me be very clear: we are no longer politics as business as usual. The old way of doing politics no longer works. Citizens want us to hear them, and we must listen to them and give them the feedback they need. Cooperation and courage are the new keywords in this process. We must be brave and find new creative and innovative solutions to make our democracy work even better for citizens. We must do this together as partners: the Parliament, the Council and the Commission. To this end, a joint declaration from all three institutions can pave the way for this unique partnership. But partnership does not stop with these three institutions. Member States and their national parliaments must also be involved. Their cooperation will be an asset to this process. To ensure we reach every citizen, especially those who do not always engage directly with us, we rely heavily on cooperation with the Committee of the Regions and the European Economic and Social Committee. I am committed to visiting regions in my role as Vice-President, and I want to hear from citizens from all corners of the European Union. Shall we stop here, dear colleagues? Certainly not: this is an open process. As the Conference progresses, hopefully, others will join us. There are two strands to this process. One on policy, with debates clustered around the themes, including the Commission’s political priorities and the European Council strategic agenda. The second strand addresses institutional topics such as the election of the President of the Commission and transnational lists. Here, the role of the Commission is that of honest broker. My colleague, Vice-President Věra Jourová, is responsible for following this institutional strand. The European Commission will adopt its contribution to the shaping of the conference in its Communication on 22 January next week. This Communication is the Commission’s contribution to the discussion that needs to be held in the coming weeks between the three institutions aimed at agreeing together on the scope, formal structure and objectives of the Conference. This would be the content of the joint declaration I referred to earlier. Once the General Affairs Council has discussed the Conference on the future of Europe on 28 January, we will be able to move to the next phase, including to determine the date for the start of the conference, ideally in the first half of 2020. And what better date for this than 9 May – Europe day – which is a date of such importance for all of us? I can already see the potential for a fruitful partnership with the European Parliament, given the priorities we share. In his role as Vice-President for Interinstitutional Relations, my colleague Maroš Šefčovič, will join us in this work. Honourable Members, as directly-elected representatives of the citizens, you are crucial to this process, and I welcome the resolution of this House, as well as your commitment not to pre-determine the outcome of the Conference. I believe that pre-determining the outcome would cause more damage to democracy than if it did nothing at all. So no pre-determining from our side. Honourable Members, by confirming me in my post as Vice-President for Democracy and Demography, you have shown that you have placed your trust in me. Just as it is important to build trust with the citizens, I want to build trust with you, and I look forward to hearing your views. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, having listened to the Council and the Commission and before giving the floor to the group chairmen, I would like to make a few comments, because we have been working on this draft conference on the future of Europe for several months and I am, of course, very pleased that this debate is taking place today and that parliament's plenary is voting today on the resolution that will kick-start this process. As you know, the conference was the result of a request from the European Parliament that The President of the Commission, Mrs von der Leyen, met last July, after the European elections, when it became clear to everyone that certain mechanisms of democratic governance need to be reviewed and rearranged, and of course we want – and this is the opinion of the whole Parliament – that this should be done with the national institutions but above all on a path of listening to the citizens. I believe that the resolution that the plenary will vote on today will be the start of a season of reform, not predetermined, but certainly of great impetus, because we need democracy to work and, above all, for democracy to be useful to the citizens. I believe that this is in the interests of the European institutions but, as a whole, of the Union. That is why we want this process to focus on the citizens. I believe that today, for this Parliament, is an important and shared day from this point of view with all the political groups, on a path of listening, discussion and dialogue, naturally with all the European institutions. We will succeed if the European institutions can walk together. I thank you and give the floor immediately to Manfred Weber, Chairman of the People's Party.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Madam Vice-President and Council Representative, the starting point for our debate on the conference for the future of Europe is the outcome of the elections last year.  201 million people participated in the European elections. The second largest democracy on the globe. That is the starting point for our debate, so people believe in Europe; people trust in Europe; people want to contribute to the future of Europe. The key question is now: does my vote count? Does it really have an impact? And there we know an improvement is possible, and that’s why the next decade must be a decade of strengthening European democracy.  What are the principles for the working structure for us as the PPE Group? The first and most important point already mentioned is people’s involvement. So, to find a way to get in touch with the ideas of our citizens to involve them in the process. The second thing is that Parliament is in the lead. That we are the representatives of the citizens. We are representing the political landscape of the European Union of today – geographically, politically, from the content point of view. We are representing a Parliament where we really respect the free mandate in a very, very positive sense. For me as a group leader, it’s always difficult to manage the unity of the group. We have a real free mandate and that’s good, and we have, together with the Commission and Council, a good working relationship.  First of all I want to underline that with Dobrevka as Vice-President responsible for the issue, we really can work very strongly together. And another element for these principles is to involve the national parliaments. All of these issues are agreed, but again, the ‘re-parliamentarisation’ of the European Union is for our group, a key element. That is the working structure and then about the direction.  Democracy is based on two principles – on candidates and on a programme. You have this for a mayor, you have this for a chancellor candidate and for us it’s also important to implement this on a European level for becoming the Commission President, for example. So the old debates on the Spitzenkandidat concept, last year we failed with this idea, it is still our interest as the PPE and we want to make this Spitzenkandidat process a binding process for the upcoming elections on the European level. We need a healthy competition between the European parties. That means we have to reflect again on the rules for the European political parties, and we have to consider how to strengthen the rights of this institution – the European Parliament – for example on the key issue, the question of right of initiative for the European Parliament, like all other parliaments have.  So that is what must be the direction for the future. More democratic – people decide. That is the best medicine against the anti-Europeans.  And finally, are we really prepared for the challenges of tomorrow? What can we do under the current Treaty, but also, is there a need for a Treaty change? That is another element which we want to discuss during the conference on the future of Europe. So let’s start today, let’s work and let’s have a new dream for Europe.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, seventy years of the Schuman Declaration, which proposed the creation of the first European Communities, will be celebrated on 9 May. That day began a political adventure, in the world and in history. Six countries freely chose to unite their destinies to ensure peace and improve people's lives. But I was already saying that declaration that Europe would not be done at once, but throughout a constant evolution that should be based on solidarity. Now it is up to us to give it a new push to ensure that the European Union is able to guarantee peace in Europe and the world, and also to improve people's lives. Today our Union faces new challenges such as climate emergency, inequalities, digitisation. But also, unfortunately, attacks on the rule of law, the deterioration of the rule of law, and the populs. The Conference on the Future of Europe is therefore a unique opportunity, which we cannot miss, to update our Union by improving its capacity to meet the challenges. And it is also an opportunity to involve citizens, to listen to what the people of Europe expect and to know their proposals, so that they can also come from all sectors of society. This was the first major conference on the future of Europe, held in The Hague in 1948. Of course, today we have many more means and mechanisms to facilitate the participation of civil society. And we have to take advantage of them. The Socialists and Democrats want this to be a real dialogue with the public and to translate into concrete results. We will work to ensure that there is broad participation of the whole society, with a balance of gender, age and geographical origin. And, moreover, with all levels of representation: from the local to the European. Because everyone has something to contribute. Because Europe does not exist if there is not each of its towns and cities, which is where the policies we decided here in the European Parliament are finally implemented. Jean Monnet said that we are not here to coalition states, but to bring people together. Some seem unclear and are still bent on speaking in the national key. They don't realize that Europe adds up. That together we are stronger, and that in an increasingly difficult geopolitical context we need to strengthen our project. And we're not here to build a market either. We want to build a community, which is much more. That is why it is time to defend European democracy and remember that we must improve people's lives. For too long the Union has neglected the social pillar, and economic policies have not been accompanied by social measures. We have let poverty grow, and inequality to increase, and that can only increase populsy. We have taken great steps to advance the Europe of citizenship, and we must be proud. The Lisbon Treaty strengthened the European Parliament and has also introduced new instruments for citizen participation, but it is not enough. I hope that the conference on the future of Europe will open up new spaces to enrich the debate and to find innovative ideas that will improve our Union. We must refine the electoral system for the next election in 2024. In these seventy years we have come a long way and, above all, the European family has expanded. Only six countries started and we've become twenty-eight. With great sadness we say goodbye to a member, although I hope it is only temporarily. Let us see it as an opportunity to rethred the European project. Looking back to see the path traveled is a necessary exercise. So is remembering everything that brings us in. But even more important is to be aware that the future is in our hands, that we cannot fall into nostalgia, that every day we are building Europe. This is a community of destiny that belongs to all of us, and between all of us we must set the course. The Socialists and Democrats will do our part to realize this dream of Europe.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we often say in this forum that diversity is an asset of Europe. Now, once again, we will have the opportunity to demonstrate that. The European elections have shown that European citizens believe in Europe, but they want a better, different Europe, a renewed Europe. The first change must be in how citizens are involved in these European processes because Europe was not created for Brussels or for an elite or for a bubble but to serve all citizens. The conference can become a great opportunity to renew Europe if we have the courage to get out of our procedural way of thinking and to really give citizens a voice in their diversity. Yet over the years we have often developed the feeling that Europe does not listen, that Europe means rules and constraints. The Europe that builds is often hidden behind restrictions. The conference is an opportunity to open the doors of Europe to the citizens and it is not for nothing that we defended the date of 9 May for its launch. We need to find solutions to involve citizens on a regular basis and not just once every five years for elections. Of course, I hear some Member States who are worried because they are afraid of losing their responsibilities, but I am convinced that participatory democracy and representative democracy, through the parliamentary process, are complementary and not opposed. Colleagues, we are giving ourselves two and a half years to present ideas that should not only make the functioning of our institutions more efficient and readable, but also ensure that our priorities echo the expectations of those who want Europe to be a real common home. Many people already experience it in this way and I think we have a lot to learn from how they combine their links with a specific territory and culture but also from this European sharing because Europe is both. This is the last session of our British friends in Strasbourg this week, and we have also just celebrated the ten-year anniversary of the Lisbon Treaty. I do not make a link between the two events, but it is clear that the time has come to refresh Europe and adapt it to today's challenges because without the European bubble syndrome, Europe can rebuild its diversity and the European Parliament must be the promoter of this new vision.

name: Daniel FREUND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I think this debate that we’re having today here is the absolute best going away present for Nigel Farage. For his last plenary, what better idea than to dedicate the prime slot of the week to this conference, what I think is a bit his worst nightmare. So it’s a shame that he hasn’t joined us here today. He would call this the federalist plot, but it’s happening right here in the open. It’s a public debate. It’s a democratic process, and not for some old ideology but because solidarity is stronger than hatred and because cooperation is stronger than nationalism.  While Nigel and the band of lying Brexiteers are driving the UK over the cliff edge, we start a much needed debate on the next steps of European integration, a debate that will lead to a stronger and a more democratic Union and because we think what is needed in a time of climate crisis, of large corporations not paying their taxes, of being squished between a less reliable United States and an ever-stronger China, is not small mindedness, is not national selfishness. We have to unite. We have to cooperate because otherwise we perish, small and alone.  The big challenges of our time we can only face as Europeans, so the proposals that the European Parliament is putting forward today are strong, based on the good examples that we have seen in Ireland, the citizens’ assemblies. Our ambition is to have a grand debate with citizens from all across the European Union, with national parliaments, with the EU institutions. I have to say to my colleagues from the Social Democrats and the Conservatives that it’s not enough to also bring the social partners, Business Europe, to bring European trade unions to the table, but we also have to include European NGOs in in this debate as well.  I know there are risks in this project – having this debate in 24 languages, possibly not breaking out of the Brussels bubble, maybe not delivering the kind of reforms that citizens expect from us, but I think the worst thing we could do is to not even try. So we have seen in the euro and in the migration crisis that we always get stuck when integration is done only half way. So I think the answer that we have to deliver, is that we give the European Union the tools and the competence to actually address the major challenges of our time. Let’s stop letting populists and eurosceptics dominate the debate on European integration. Let’s start building a stronger and truly united Europe today, and let’s take another step towards a European Federal Republic.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that both Parliament, since the beginning of this parliamentary term, and the new Commission have put a great deal of effort into organising this conference, making it clear that this will be a pillar of the programme for the next five years, a pillar of a reform of the European Union of which, with obviously different compositions and outcomes, all parties and groups see the need. However, I do not believe that this exercise is useful in giving answers to what the citizens have told us in recent years and, above all, with the elections in May. The citizens have not asked us to organise conferences, to organise debates, to organise agora, but for years they have been asking us for concrete answers, asking us for action. So the problem is not listening to the citizens, we know what they want, the problem is political. The problem is that these institutions have not been able, in recent years, to give concrete answers, to play politics, to respond to the three major problems that the citizens of Europe are facing today, namely that of the economic crisis, that of internal security and that of immigration, which is an issue that I believe is also lacking in Parliament's resolution and which cannot be ignored. I believe that this type of exercise may make sense if, before making proposals, this House and these institutions are able to make a profound self-criticism of what they have done wrong in recent years, because mistakes have been made and serious mistakes have been made, which have led the continent to sink, to count for nothing more on the international political stage. If we do not understand that the reforms and policy pursued over the last twenty years have only weakened states, weakened our continent, made our citizens poorer, any proposal we are going to discuss will only be a marketing exercise that will make no sense. I believe that the aim is to understand where it has been wrong - and unfortunately the institutions have not yet made a profound self-criticism - to understand that, contrary to what my colleague from the Greens said, the issue is not to create a federal state – what the citizens do not want, what the citizens, when they have been called upon to express their opinion, have always said against – but that we must start from our identities. , that we must start from the knowledge that without states, without our nations, without our peoples, Europe does not exist.

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I will be talking about the resolution that will be coming from this Chamber and my main point is that everything in this resolution is wrong. It is wrong because Article 48(4) of the Treaty on the European Union states clearly that it is the Council, not Parliament or the Commission, that can convene such a conference. I know that the attitude of this Chamber and of the Commission towards the Treaties has been consistently rather cavalier, but let us at least remember that we are deviating from what the Treaties have stipulated. So the attitude is that the aim justifies the means, the aim being ever closer union justifies the means, even distraining and ignoring the letter and the spirit of the Treaties.  It is wrong because the whole procedure to produce this document was a disgrace. The Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) excluded two Groups from serious involvement in drafting its opinion and fixed the voting list in advance. Five Groups prepared the document in secret and excluded two Groups from having any input in the draft text. In case you don’t know, ladies and gentlemen, this is foul play. This is the tyranny of the majority. This is foul play. It is wrong because it gives the European Parliament the leading role in the process to the detriment of national parliaments, and the democratic legitimacy of national parliaments is far, far greater than that of the European Parliament.  It is wrong because it gives the real power of the conference into the hands of an inner cabal, called the board, which will no doubt include only the representatives of the five political groups. So you have the tyranny of the majority again. It is wrong because it has a predetermined outcome as we have heard this morning. The conference is simply regarded as a springboard for the next great leap forward in European integration, including a transnationalist spitzenkandidat process and greater competences for the Union at the expense of the Member States, so do not talk about consultation. This will be fake consultations because the aim is already specified. It does not really require much intelligence to predict that all this will exacerbate the divisions in Europe, which are already quite deep and disconcerting. But we should not be surprised. The advocates of  ever closer union have always been very good at antagonising people. It is said that human beings learn from mistakes. Maybe they do, but apparently most Members of the European Parliament don’t.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, for more than a month, the French have been protesting against the breakdown of their retirement. Yesterday, 1,200 doctors tendered their resignations to denounce the general state of disrepair of our French hospitals. Across Europe, citizens are mobilising against the consequences of austerity, which is at the heart of the European Union's treaties. Everywhere, they reject this individualistic future where solidarity systems are broken one by one. The conference on the future of Europe should have responded to this tremendous desire for change. Unfortunately, it is a stunted procedure that is proposed to us at this stage, both on the objectives and on the method. On the objectives, the Union cannot be satisfied with a cosmetic façade upgrade. It is the whole building that is currently in danger of collapsing, and it is therefore all its architecture that needs to be rethought, that is to say, that we must dare to name things: to change the treaties of the European Union in depth. Why not rename this conference on the future of Europe in a conference on the change of European treaties? The project is huge and we will not be able to miss out if we want to implement a genuine European, social and ecological green pact. Moving away from the logic of free trade, favouring a pact of solidarity and sustainability rather than growth and competitiveness, and social harmonisation from the top rather than widespread dumping. On the method, nothing would be more disastrous than a new falsely democratic gas plant. Parliament must be the only leader, not the Commission, which has no popular legitimacy to do so. Who can think that citizens' agoras, composed of a maximum of two to three people per Member State and without real power of impulse, are sufficient to guarantee the effective participation of citizens? Who can think that the confidence of European citizens and peoples can be regained in the institutions without endorsing the results of consultations by referendum or equivalent procedure? Don't we learn from our failures? Why repeat the mistake of the Convention on the Future of Europe in 2002, which led to the unfortunate adoption of the Lisbon Treaty against the wishes of the European peoples expressed in a referendum? For years, the fear of the people and the contempt for the will of the citizens have shaken the European edifice. We must respond to the growing distrust of the European institutions by assuming to challenge the rules of the game. Behind its bombastic title, the conference on the future of Europe is in danger of giving birth to a mouse at this stage. This is not what we want, on behalf of our group of the European Unitarian Left. European citizens deserve better: a profound and radical reform at the service of the peoples and the planet, based on a genuine participatory process. Let us not once again waste the opportunity to give meaning to the original ideal of the European project.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, this year we will finally have the opportunity to restart that serious debate on that change which, as a political force, we have called for so much in recent years. Bearing in mind the bitter, I would even say traumatic, warning of Brexit, we must take this precious opportunity not only to discuss the new European agenda but above all to unblock the most ambitious reforms: the social pillar, the fiscal union, a truly supportive management of immigration. By relaunching, if necessary, the instrument of enhanced cooperation, which is still little explored, while avoiding the cumbersomeness of a Europe at too fast. We cannot allow the possibility of this conference also bringing about a reform of the Treaties and the institutions, starting with the introduction of the right of initiative for our Parliament, to be ruled out in advance. The citizens must be the real protagonists of this process and we, as a Parliament, must be at the forefront of defending their participation, their voice, their dreams and their hopes. Ladies and gentlemen, allow me to give you a clear warning. This conference cannot and must not be a mere exercise in style, a media fig leaf: too much time has already passed in vain, the rise of anti-Europeanism is precisely the consequence of this unjustifiable inertia. Today's world is pervaded by three feelings: anger, fear and hope. Which of the three will prevail will depend solely and exclusively on us.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that, 10 years after the Lisbon Treaty, it is really time to prepare our Union for the next decade. We need a very, very deep and broad debate and discussion to prepare our institutions and to prepare our Union for the challenge of the future. This is the scope and the reason for organising this conference. What is really different is that this time, we want to use in the preparation all the skills and all the tools that we have available to engage citizens in this debate. This is our goal. But this is what we call participative democracy, this is true. But, be careful: we don’t want to mix participative democracy with representative democracy. One thing is to listen and to consult citizens, to engage them, to bring them committed to our debate. Another thing is institutional representation, with all the liberal heavy touch from our rule—of—law states and we should keep these two spheres very clearly separated, even if we have to engage in this project in a manner that we can use all the impulse that citizens will give us. So, my hope is that we can, for the first time, have a process of reform of the European Union where citizens are really heard and where their opinion matters.

name: Gabriele BISCHOFF
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The last few years here have been marked by crisis debates, Brexit, growing voices from Eurosceptics and right-wing populists – not just in this House. The higher turnout in the European elections in May last year was a first step out of this negative spiral. The citizens have made it clear through their high voter turnout that they have an interest in Europe, that they do not care about Europe. But they have also expressed their expectations of a Europe capable of action. This turnout was not automatic, but broad alliances, an active civil society, helped to make this time different from the other European elections. Citizens want a union capable of action, an EU that protects them and strengthens them. That is why it is important that, with this conference, we finally look ahead, that we dare to set off. But this will only be possible if we get it right, if we tackle it properly and courageously. Therefore, this conference must not be a routine affair, it must not be business as usual. We must have the courage to get out of our comfort zone. We have to go where the people are, where they are, who feel abandoned. This also means: out of the capitals, into the rural regions, towards the workers, the unemployed, the young people, those who are critical of Europe, to whom Europe is not necessarily an important project. That is why it is important for citizens to be able to exert direct influence – from the outset and not at the end of the day, when everything has already been bagged. That is why we have made it clear that we see this conference on the future of Europe as a great opportunity. We have an institutional plenary, where representatives of civil society are also represented with the European Economic and Social Committee as the House of Civil Society, but where the Committee of the Regions is also present. Because we need the mayors, we need the councils if we really want to bring these debates to the people. That is why I am happy and hope and plead for us to have the courage to leave the beaten path and dare to do something new – together – in order to make Europe more democratic, social and capable of action.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Madam President, let’s give a common conclusion here. That is that, for the first time – nearly 20 years, I think, after the start of the Convention, the three institutions agree again on the necessity for an in-depth reform of the European Union. This is already an important fact because it is 20 years after the start of the previous Convention and, for the first time, these three institutions say, ‘OK, an in—depth reform of the Union is absolutely needed’. I will not contradict or have a debate with Mr Legutko because, in the meanwhile, he is no longer here in the plenary. The reason why we want this Conference is because there are problems that we recognise in the European Union. When we have Brexit, a big country that is leaving the European Union, it’s difficult to say, ‘Oh, fantastic, we work well’. No, it’s a problem. We have a problem when a big country is leaving the Union and when, five years after the start of the migration crisis, we still don’t have a reform of the Dublin Regulation. We have a problem in the European Union when, ten years after the outbreak of the financial crisis, we still do not have a banking union in the European Union. We have a problem. And when Russians and Americans are deciding everything in our neighbourhood – in Syria and in Libya and in Ukraine – well, we have a problem. In fact, the reality is that, on the international stage, we are mocked by Putin, we are blackmailed by Erdoğan, we are bullied by Trump, and mostly we are ignored by the Chinese Government. That’s the reason why we want to reform Europe; not because we say ‘we are Europeans and everything is going well’, and it’s over. No, tomorrow it will be a different world tomorrow, dominated by what I call empires, like China, like India, like Russia, like America. That doesn’t mean that we have to become an empire – on the contrary – but we want to defend a Europe in which our children and grandchildren can survive in this new world, which is not the case today.  We have to do it with a new method, not like in the Convention. In the Convention it went from the top down and at the top, with Valéry Giscard d'Estaing, the top was something very impressive and present. We have to do exactly the opposite, not in contradiction, but from the bottom up – going up from the citizens so that we can create. After the generation of Monnet and Schuman and after the generation of Kohl and Mitterrand, we need a third movement, a third movement with, I would say, the vision of the first and with the courage of the second generation.  (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take two blue-card questions under Rule 171(8))

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: blue-card question. – I do feel lucky with you, Madam President. Mr Verhofstadt, we’re talking about the future of Europe, but one of the key concerns of mine for Europe, and for your future, is your dependence on your geopolitical foe. You mentioned Russia and Putin, but recently the Nord Stream 2 channel pipeline, which will bring gas from Russia into Europe, was completed with the Denmark signing of a further EUR 150 million to complete that. Do you agree with me that Europe has no chance to be energy-independent while it is still reliant on Russia?

name: Niklas NIENASS
text: blue-card question. – Mr Verhofstadt, you said that you want to enable a bottom—up approach. So, there are some rumours going on that certain parties already agreed on who should be leading the conference and your name was mentioned on that as well, so I wanted to know from you, presented right now here, that those rumours are not true and that the conference itself should decide on who leads the conference.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: blue-card answer. – It seems to be a good idea to have a democratic process during this. Let’s consult all the citizens in Europe like we did during the elections. That seems to me the best thing to do. Maybe we can ask Mr Sassoli to organise that procedure and maybe I’m a candidate to do that.  To our British friends, I want to say on Nord Stream – that is a good point that has been made, but Nord Stream is proof of what? It is proof of a lack of European Union, it is proof of the fact that a European energy community does not exist in Europe. So if really those people, like those in the Brexit Party, are anxious about Nord Stream, well, they should create the energy community we desperately need and as fast as possible, colleagues.

name: Christian ALLARD
text: – Madam President, I would like to talk about not only the problems, what are the opportunities and what are the solutions we could find for the future of Europe. This conference on the future of Europe is a timely democratic exercise. As you heard already if Brexit was about the EU, it was to mute the progressive agenda of the European project.  When the people of Scotland voted to remain in Europe we meant it. Trust us to continue and to promote outward looking, internationalist European values. Those values are firmly at the heart of our vision for Scotland. This conference is needed because we are under attack. We are under a populist attack. Politics doesn’t stand still. We either go forward or we go backwards. This conference is the way forward for all Member States, including future Member States. Scotland is a future Member State. No doubt about it.  Let’s start by Scotland then other parts of the United Kingdom will follow. Voltaire said a long time ago, we look to Scotland for all our ideas of civilisation. One innovative idea we have developed in Scotland, is to enshrine into law the democratic participation of all people living in Scotland, wherever they come from, whatever their nationality. Wouldn’t it be fantastic to also include the contribution of all the people living in Europe to this conference, not only EU citizens.  In Scotland our devolved institutions are based on European laws. The foundation of modern Scotland comes from the EU. Scotland is looking forward to contribute to the debate as a future Member State of the European Union.  (Applause)

name: Gunnar BECK
text: – Madam President, in 2000, the EU launched its Lisbon agenda to make the EU ‘the most competitive and dynamic knowledge-based economy in the world by 2010’. As 2010 was approaching references to the agenda were expunged from EU websites and the plan was renamed the Europe 2020 strategy. 2020 has arrived and the most competitive and dynamic knowledge economy, maybe as a moral champion of the world, but it also enjoys the highest consumer income and corporate taxes in the developed world, high unemployment and the lowest growth apart from Japan. For the most integrated countries of the eurozone, economic data are even worse than for the more sensible non-euro EU Members.  The Commission president now proposes a conference on the future of Europe to make the EU more democratic. She mentions an economy for the people. Yet also proposes more taxes and an EU Green Deal for EUR one trillion plus, when EU influence on world climate is minimal. In the name of Europe’s way of life, she’s advocating more non-European immigration to make Europe less European by the day. EU democracy is democracy, neither for nor by the European peoples. Sigmund Freud spoke of ‘Flucht in die Krankheit’ or ‘escape into illness’ to describe a neurotic avoidance of an unsatisfactory reality. Rather than face the struggle to regain health, the neurotic patient is secretly desiring to remain ill. Is there a better diagnosis of the EU today? Faced with a menacing economic truth, the EU Commission is reaching for a narcotic overdose of EU integration to take an extended holiday from reality.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The future of Europe is not the same as the future of the European Union. Europe existed before the Union was created – we should remember this – and it is likely to continue to exist even if the Union ceases to exist or becomes some other form of political cooperation between European peoples. However, there is no doubt that, bearing this difference in mind, one must reflect on the future and of the Union and Europe. Such a discussion is needed because, on the one hand, the voices of prominent thinkers, both conservative and left-wing, are multiplying, that European civilisation is in a critical, even end-of-life state. On the other hand, we feel that the European Union is also in need of reform. We are in favour of an open, honest, non-exclusionary discussion of people with different views, such as opponents of further integration, which does not prejudge the direction of the proposed changes. We cannot divide (like some colleagues who talk about the European republic) European citizens into bad and good Europeans.  We also agree that citizens should be involved in the debate on the future of Europe, but we know that there is no single European public sphere, which is why this should be done at national level. We also believe that citizens' discussions cannot replace parliaments' debates and should only be public consultations. We would also like to remind you that the amendment of the Treaties can only take place in accordance with Article 48 of the Treaty on European Union.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Commission has given the European Parliament a leading role in this two-year debate space. That is a good thing! And with today's resolution, Parliament is presenting a concrete proposal to the EU Council, the Commission and the European public on how, together with all citizens, a redefinition of European policies can be made to address so many challenges for the future as well as everyday problems. After years of painful crisis experience and attempts to deal with it, we need to work together to determine what kind of EU we want and need, what needs to be changed or reworked. I believe that Parliament's core approach is extremely important and right, from the outset, to place the Sovereign, the citizens, at the centre of the conference and, in a very innovative way, to link representative democracy and the participation of citizens in defining the future framework for EU policy in a permanent dialogue process. Yes, a conference on the future of the EU means, first and foremost, making citizens' voices with their wishes, expectations and demands on the EU. They themselves should decide which issues need to be addressed in order to eliminate democratic deficits, develop new policies and test the suitability of policies at EU and national level. Dear representatives of ID and ECR, why are you afraid of citizens who want to create solidarity on the European continent? To achieve this, we need transparency and the benefits of today's modern means of communication. That is another reason why the Conference will have to go beyond the Convention.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, really, where and how do you talk about the future of Europe by identifying it with the future of the European Union, a Union of monopolies, which some have once described as eternal, as lawfulness? Today, Brexit is recorded, centrifugal tendencies and contrasts, while in your own texts you are concerned about the anemic capitalist recovery. You are launching a gold-paid campaign of brainwashing, provocative embellishment of the European Union, manipulation and anti-communism, trying to stem the growing controversy and lack of trust of peoples and youth in it.  Conferences, supposedly popular participation, are being set up with business groups, NGOs, lobbies and workers. Contrary to what the GUE Group, which co-signes the resolution as its genuine apologist, claims, the European Union neither changes nor, as the far-right claims, makes mistakes. It serves the exploitative system irrevocably, it is an opponent of labour interests, a constant undermining of the defence of borders and sovereign rights. The people can carve out their own future by freeing themselves from the European Union, with the people in power, for the Europe of socialism.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, the European Union, ladies and gentlemen, is not the result of chance, but a peace project in the face of the horrors of war. We are the first generation that has not suffered the war and we are a generation that has forgotten the war. The European Union is now a peace process that has stopped and is beginning to reverse. Europe was a dream, but today it is an unsatisfactory reality.  We should rebuild the dream, but we live in times when politicians have no legitimacy to dream. And politicians these days have left empty words and slogans. For example, we distinguish between ourselves and the citizens to give the impression that we are close to the people, when the citizens are the ones who have elected us, when in election campaign we have been talking to the citizens, when we ourselves are citizens and, if not, what do we do in this Parliament? The assemblies of citizens parallel to parliaments all they do is delegitimate parliaments.  Europe does not need politicians to dream. Europe needs politicians to believe. Politicians who believe in a European Union without nationalisms, without borders, without discrimination; who believe that Europe is not just the European Council; who believe that together we are better; create in a federal Europe. Today we decide how we're going to work, but it remains to decide where we're going and that's what really matters. What Europe we believe in, not what Europe we dream of.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Patrick BREYER
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, you said that you don’t want the EU Parliament to be delegitimised by Parliament representation. Do you know the concept of a fundamental treaty of society as laid out by Mr Rousseau The idea that citizens will agree on the kind of government that they want. And do you think that this idea is a threat to representative institutions or would you rather agree that we are elected to represent citizens when they want us to?

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: "blue card" response. – I believe in the representative mandate. I believe in the representative mandate. I understand that the Council and the Commission consult the citizens because they are not Parliaments, but it seems to me that there is some contradiction in the need for people to consult the people only six months ago.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to say to our colleagues from the Far right that come to this Chamber every day to tell us what the citizens think, believe, and to tell the rest of us that we are mistaken. But the truth is that you only represent 20 or 25% of the European people. It is the pro-European groups, the ones that support this resolution, that represent more than 70-75% of the vote in the last European election, so let’s set the record straight on this matter.  (Applause) Second of all. It’s 10 years after the Lisbon Treaty entered into force. And if you look at the world now, some others have already said it, it is totally different from the world of 2009. At that time we didn’t have Brexit; we didn’t have the Arab Spring; we didn’t have Trump as President of the United States; we didn’t have the immigration flows. So unlike some other colleagues that mention Freud and narcotization, we do live in reality. The issue is that you don’t recognise reality, the external pressures that as Europeans we are facing and that we have to react with this conference on the future of Europe, that I think has to lead us, because the world is there and we cannot ignore it, towards a political union of a federal sort.  But we are going to do this with the citizens – in a conversation with the citizens and with organised civil society. It’s very important that we ensure the participation as well of the organised civil society. I think that we can achieve the maximum implication of ordinary citizens and NGOs in this process, national parliamentarians, and then come up with a set of answers to the policy challenges that we are facing and we cannot ignore. And when we have identified these policy challenges, then we can also provide the right institutional answers.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – The Maastricht Treaty of 1992 provided for a Citizens' Union. Why has this noble goal not been achieved for so many years? Maybe you will give at least one reason.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: blue-card answer. – I didn’t understand the question. The ‘Civic Union’ – what does it mean? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Perhaps you could get together afterwards and resolve that issue? And because the lady at No 29 has asked very nicely for a second question, will you accept – you may understand this one?

name: Lara WOLTERS
text: blue-card question. – I’m just enjoying the way this debate is going at the moment, really. I’m enjoying the blue cards because for the first time, I feel like we’re having an actual debate here (applause) and I think that’s very, very necessary when we’re talking about the future of Europe. I just thought I would take the opportunity to give some of my time back to my colleague from the S&D who, very importantly, talked about the involvement of citizens and of NGOs in the future of Europe, and the conference on that. That’s a really important topic, so I thought that by doing this, I can give him a little bit more time to talk about that.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: blue-card answer. – I believe in representative democracy, as my colleague González Pons said before, but I don’t see any contradiction with having a permanent consultation with citizens. As elected representatives, we have to be in touch with ordinary citizens and NGOs every single day, and we also have to do this in the context of the Conference on the Future of Europe.  (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: At this point, because we have over 16 catch-the-eye requests, I will now close catch-the-eye. I will try and continue with the blue cards, as has been referenced.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Madam President, I think you have heard Parliament's position: it is almost unanimous on the need to succeed in this Europe conference. This is a new element that is part of a debate that is often too institutional and we have an extremely strong opportunity here. I would like to rebound from a word that you used that echoes the French that I am, you spoke of the word 'audacity' and you know that this is a phrase that the revolutionary Danton had quoted at the time when France was in danger saying: 'Boldness, still audacity, always audacity'. Yes, now is the time. Europe is in danger, as has been said and explained, we are probably at a crossroads. Yesterday we were talking about Brexit and other dangers are before us. Sir Winston Churchill said 70 years ago, at Kléber Square, at the end of the war, that the dangers before Europe were great, but that great was its strength and that it must be aware of it. So it is to you, Mrs 'Ukoica,' and I turn to the Council. And I will simply base myself on a phrase by Jean Monnet, who said when Europe was created: Europe is not there to coalesce states, it is there to connect human beings with each other and this is the moment we find ourselves today. I therefore look with both concern and hope at the Council. I look at you, Mrs Ica, and I look at the Commission. And I ask you, on behalf of this institution, which represents European citizens, on behalf of NGOs, who are knocking on the door of these institutions, on behalf of civil society, not to waste this opportunity to finally make us work together with all those who represent European citizenship. We must succeed together or we will fail without each other. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8, of the internal regulation)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: 'blue card' question. "Dear colleagues, dear Pascal, we have worked together a lot on many issues in the past years. I very much appreciated your speech and I ask you a question. It was read that this conference might not be able to lead to treaty reform. Do you think, as I do, that we should take this opportunity to discuss a possible reform of the treaty? To push within this conference in this direction? To put an end also to a certain imbalance in the institutions that really need to be corrected?

name: Pascal DURAND
text: answer 'blue card'. Thank you very much Fabio, I will respond simply by listening to what the Council, the Commission and Mrs 'Ukoa have said. We must not pre-empt anything, we must not forbid anything, we must simply try to establish the necessary dialogue for solutions. We know that there are deadlocks in Europe, we know that we can overcome them: so let us do it, let us not be afraid, - I take up the word - let us be bold, let us not be afraid of European citizens, let us not be afraid of dialogue and try to reform, indeed, what needs to be reformed.

name: Gwendoline DELBOS-CORFIELD
text: Madam President, we are studying this text on the conference on the future of Europe. In this month of January 2020, it has been said, this is the last month of our British colleagues in this European Assembly. So we are living in this Parliament the first effects of Brexit and the departure of the first of the 28 Member States. We hope that this will be the only start, but what do we know? Did we really think ten years ago that this first risk of dislocation was possible? During this parliamentary session, we will also study and vote on a resolution which recalls the triggering of Article 7 by the Commission and Parliament against two governments of the Member States: Poland and Hungary, following serious violations of the rule of law. We seem to have been frozen for two years, with no real capacity to react to these threats to our European project. The European Union is therefore at a critical juncture. This idea of a conference on the future of Europe is a necessary and remarkable initiative: the President of the Commission and the Commissioners can be congratulated for supporting it. But above all, the fact that the European Parliament has seized on it with such determination and a relative share of audacity is also promising. However, let us be clear: if this conference is a failure, we will all bear the responsibility: Council, Commission and Parliament. And this could be one more step towards the end of a coherent And ever more inclusive European Union. Conservatives and Social Democrats, many of them want to curb citizen participation. We consider that to be a major mistake. We, the European parliamentarians, work here in very privileged conditions. If we do not allow the citizens involved to have similar conditions, we make fun of them. Good examples of civic assemblies in Ireland, France and parts of Germany should inspire us. My colleague Daniel Freund has already mentioned that. The consequent working time, regular meetings, information so that they can debate knowingly, a technical organization to accompany them, this will have a cost. To really interest the citizens and give a collective meaning to this conference cannot be done without and at the end of the process, the citizens... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Mr President, let us not be around the pot here today. This great conference on the future of the European Union is either intended to give a chance to the opposition to the transfer of national sovereignty to the European Union, a debate that is open and genuine and which is in touch with what has emerged from all elections throughout Europe in recent years, namely less European Union and more prudence and freedom of European cooperation. Either it is a forum, a theatre performance à la macron's great debate where that resistance is set aside and made invisible.  Our fear is the latter, and the majority who are calling for a resolution here today have explicitly included in the text in three places and, despite our amendments, that the EU, even more than today, must become an ever closer Union in principle. As a result, instead of a debate with the people, your conference becomes a theatrical performance, expensive and useless, dedicated solely to your federalist state religion of ever more powers. You should be ashamed of yourself.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Mr President, the functioning of the European Union is based on representative democracy. This means that there are two legitimate representatives of the citizens. These are the national parliaments and that is this Parliament. And it is good to listen to the citizens, to the NGOs, to all kinds of organisations, but they are never representative. What the citizens want is politicians who make choices, politicians who dare to decide and who are accountable.  Secondly, the EU is based on the principles of proportionality. This works both ways, and we do things together when that's an added value. If not, we will keep it at member state level. So more internal market, more global actor, more border guards, but no unemployment benefits, no minimum wages: that is a national competence.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, those who send the European Union to continue to do what they have always done need, at least, to pretend to listen to what the peopleof Europe say – this could be the motto of this farce. The same ones who approved treaties on the citizens' backs, the same ones who banned referendums when the results became inconvenient, the same ones who disrespected the referendum result, now appear very interested in hearing the opinion of citizens in a process formatted with conclusions drawn from the outset. We are here to discuss the future of Europe, yes, and that is why we refuse this farce. We are here to discuss the future of Europe, but without scenarios that seek to hide conclusions drawn from the outset. We are here, above all, to fight for another Europe, not the neoliberal Europe of multinationals and economic groups, but the Europe of workers and peoples. Not a militarised Europe, but a Europe of peace. Not a Europe of the impositions of the most powerful to the less powerful, but a Europe of equal sovereign states on rights. We are here to discuss Europe, and above all we are here to transform this Europe.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Madam President, when we ask ourselves about the future of Europe, the first thing to solve is what role we should give to citizens. If we don’t solve this, in a few years, with other MEPs, the same debate will have to take place and it will be a defeat. Do we want citizens to be uninterested, passive and distant or, on the contrary, do we want their voice to really count and for them to be able to participate directly in European democracy?  I don’t refer only to the elections of Members and senior positions, but to habilitate a mechanism in order to participate in debates and decision—taking. We must update the governance of our democracy. The dissatisfaction that runs through Europe only benefits Europhobic populism. There is a real basis that justifies this dissatisfaction. The alternative cannot be the temptation of Euroscepticism. The future of Europe is not for conformists or sceptics, but exigencies. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: "blue card" question. – Europe is a political project based on the rule of law and the rule of law. It is a community of values, of which Spain is a part. Europe is the antidote to its destructive nationalism.  You are a fugitive from justice, who attacked the rule of law and stole public money. This week, what you fear most has started for you. He's going to get the law. Immunity is not impunity and no one in this House is above the law. When are you going to have the courage? When are you going to lose the fear of dealing... (the chairperson withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: "blue card" response. – Mrs Montserrat, I believe that you should respect the rules that this Parliament has adopted. And you must know that there is a directive preventing public office, especially if you are Members of that Parliament, from attacking the presumption of innocence. Exactly what sentences do you mean? What do you mean? What crimes do you mean that I have committed to make such a statement in this House? That said, I think states should comply with the laws, yes. And the Spanish state is the first state of the European Union, the first to receive sanctions for not complying with European laws.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the first thing that needs to be done to protect Europe's interests is a return to politics. The real great reform is to have a Europe that is able to meet the great internal and external challenges. We need a different geopolitical balance, we need a Europe with a single foreign policy, with a single defence policy. We have seen Europe's weakness in the Middle East crisis, in the Libyan crisis, europe absent in the great crisis in Venezuela and South America. There is a Chinese offensive to which Europe has a duty to respond. We therefore need strong and cohesive action. Strong and cohesive action does not mean renouncing national identities, renouncing nation states, nor must Europe be the pretext for destroying national units. Small homelands do not exist, homelands exist and as such must be defended and valued in the context of a politically stronger Europe. I do not believe that the problem is solved by illegitimate referendums, I do not believe that the problem of European unity will be solved by a kind of unrepresentative democracy that goes against the will of the people, that is, the people who chose their elected representatives. That is why I believe that the role of the European Parliament, which must finally be given the power of legislative initiative, should be strengthened, as is the case in all the parliaments of the world. At this conference too, we must of course give space to the voice of the citizens, but we must also give space to the voices of the elected representatives, including the mayors and presidents of the regions on the European Committee of the Regions.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, the Conference on the Future of Europe is a good opportunity for citizens to meet with the European project, but three conditions must be respected. First, it needs to be a truly open and participated debate, where all citizens and organisations representing civil society can make their voice heard. Secondly, it needs to be a debate focused on the real expectations of citizens and aimed at building viable political commitments. We gain nothing from institutional affairs, with a confrontation of sterile utopias or with an anarchic debate where everything is discussed and nothing is decided. Thirdly, we need a conclusive debate that allows the democratically legitimate European institutions to take decisions and take concrete steps in the right direction towards a fairer Europe, a more democratic Europe and a Europe that offers more prosperity to its citizens.

name: Svenja HAHN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Young people are the future of Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, I am sure you will have said this, as I have said more than once during the election campaign. And now we can show how serious we really are. The Conference on the Future of Europe is also a conference on the future of the next generation. This next generation must also be able to have a say in this. Above all, I also expect respect, as much respect for the youth forums as i do for the citizens' assemblies. This is above all a greeting to the Colleagues of the ECR, who would prefer to abolish youth participation with their amendments. However, I also expect respect from this House and from the national parliaments. Above all, send young Members, because only if we involve young people at all levels of the conference will we show that we take their point of view seriously, that we have respect for their opinions and that they can actively shape their own future in Europe.

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: – Madam President, after listening to this debate, I am even happier that we have a strong resolution in this House, which is basically supporting the future of Europe. I just want to mention a few points that have been mentioned already to showcase that. We do recognise the problems – and because we recognise the problems, we’re trying to find solutions, and the problems as Mr Verhofstadt has said and also Ms O’Brien and others, lie in all the challenges we face with migration, with our social standards, and so on. We cannot address them fully because we are currently blocked in our solutions. That is why we need this conference to go into the future. The second question about the national interest. Yes, currently, we can’t defend our national interests because national interests are European interests and that is I think important to understand.  The majority of this House is for the future, and the future can only be obtained if we find a common future for Europe together and that means to have a common vision together that is shared with the citizens, and I hope that with this conference we can go down this path.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Katalin CSEH
text: blue-card question. – Mr Boeselager, you mentioned that we need a strongly worded resolution on this topic, I completely agree, but just let me remind this House of a later debate we are having about a very strongly worded resolution on Hungary and Poland. This House voted on this and nothing is happening so far. How can we guarantee that this resolution we are voting on will not lead to a similar talking shop, that we can finally achieve results and that this Parliament actually stands up for what has been voted on?

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: blue-card answer. – Ms Cseh, there are two elements that we can use to make sure that this doesn’t end up as a talking shop. The first one is that we actually follow up on the outcomes of this debate, so that we have Treaty changes, so that we have procedural changes, so that we go into the regular processes here in this House, and in the other institutions and follow up. The second one is that we don’t only go bottom up as Mr Verhofstad said, but that we also play back our results to the citizens and say, ‘do you agree? Do you think these are good results?’ And only via this accountability, I think will we be able to hold all of us and all politicians accountable.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for They want to take control of the future of Europe here, but they are already failing to deal successfully with the present and the current problems. Two examples: Migration – since 2015, you have not been able to exercise the appropriate external border protection. The second example is economics and currency. In the monetary field, we have a zero interest rate policy in the face of a negative interest rate policy. The economy is weak and we are not able to stimulate the economy accordingly. But where success is suggested here by pushing aside the key areas, that is the climate crisis. But they are using this to take even more money out of people's pockets with a CARBON levy. What the European Union is failing to do, however, is to set a location, and every month 120 service vehicles are ordered from Brussels to Strasbourg, each with only one driver, and have to return. Recognise that the future of Europe does not lie in centralisation, the nation states are good enough and smart enough to solve their problems as much as possible themselves, and this is a successful future for Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the "blue card" procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Claudia GAMON
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Vilimsky, I would like to thank Mr Vilimsky for his You have not spoken at all about the matter now. I would therefore like to ask you what would be the objection to getting the citizens of the Union into this conference and to exchange ideas with them about what their ideas are about the future of Europe, because you are constantly reluctant to hear their voices, because they would think much further and think much more European than you trust them to do.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Gamon, I would like to thank Mrs Gamon for her part in the With all the appreciation of your person – you are also new to the House – I have been here for the past period and have also witnessed the fact that we have discussed the future of Europe on a number of occasions with the participation of citizens, interest groups, whoever wants to participate in it. There is no consensus here, the House is reluctant to give an answer. We have had five scenarios since 2016 about a possible future for Europe, and to this day the House has shied away from making such a determination. That is my reproach, which I postulate to this body ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – President, ten years, President, ten years since the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and what we have had is a financial crisis, an immigration crisis, the Brexit crisis. We haven't been able to solve any of these problems. It is right that we are therefore debating the future of the Union, but be careful, because it seems that the solution is to continue to walk towards what has provoked it, which is the federalisation of Europe. You're still walking off the cliff.  In my view, the solution must indeed be that of a free conference in which the views of more than 20% of this Parliament, which has been excluded directly from the same wording of the text of the proposal which is taken to plenary, are not excluded. Is that the future of Europe that you want? The future of a Europe which begins by sanctioning two Member States and continues to exclude more than 20% of the European population from the debate, I repeat. There are other Europeans who want a Europe of free nations, of sovereign nations, who cooperate freely defending their traditions. And I would also like to remind you of something that you seem to forget: the future passes through our traditions and respect for our history, our Christian culture. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Sven SIMON
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to prevent the creation of legends, which two speakers from your group have now wrongly put into the room here: you claim that you have been excluded from the wording of this resolution. That's not true. It was your desire to retire. Everyone else regretted it. We would have liked to have drafted a cross-party resolution, across all the political groups. They have withdrawn. We have not ruled anyone out. Are you aware of this?

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: "blue card" response. – I am sorry to disagree, but I am also part of this Committee on Constitutional Affairs and in the first debate we were already brought a proposal, signed by the four large groups, which spoke of a future of a closer, closer Europe... of the federalization of Europe. And, from here, make amendments. What amendments are we going to make if you have already closed the document? I think debating is starting to work from the beginning and really thinking about respect for our citizens.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Madam President, in order to make a united Europe more attractive and stronger, it needs to be made more democratic, more social, more ecological and fairer. Only in this way can we avoid the risk of regression and a return to a black past, which is now openly pursued by the forces of the anti-European populist far right. In order to achieve this, this dialogue, in which the European Parliament must have a strong role, must take place not only among the elites but, above all, with the participation of civil society. That is why my left-wing group is co-signing this resolution, although we would like it to be more radical. We are impressed not only by the absolute refusal of the extreme right to support this resolution but also by its refusal to accept the participation of citizens in this dialogue. Why are you afraid of civic participation?

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairmen, European peoples and states are doomed to each other. We've been here before Europe, now that it's Europe, we'll be no matter what happens to the European Union.  Today, by the way, is the International Day of Recognition of the Republic of Croatia, and on this day, listening to the debate here, I got a little personal recognition listening to the great proponents of Europe who I have followed for years admit that they made a mistake, that they implemented policies that ran into the wall. good job! Recognition is the first step in solving anything.  Europe lacks solidarity. In Croatia, when there are fires in Dalmatia, we all jump to help Dalmatia. When there are floods in Slavonia, the whole of Croatia jumps to help Slavonia. In Europe, however, solidarity is minimal. Instead of solidarity, you offered oppression. You have reduced solidarity through your erroneous common oppressive policies.  For example, monetary policy. Now Croatia is pushing itself into the eurozone. This will deprive us of all the tools of getting out of the crisis, the interest rate exchange rate policy. What happens to us then? The elements of help are none. Are we going to lose like Greece 25% of the economy? Will our economy die like a dog on the road?

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Madam President, this two-year conference can be something entirely different from just a podium for popular or populist politicians. We have a chance to initiate an openm fully inclusive debate on Europe and its future. It can be a debate of equals that would lead to a permanent mechanism of dialogue on Europe. Independently of its final outcome, this conference is a political process, it can have its own value added: renewing European liberal democracy, keeping European unity, advancing European citizenship, enhancing the feelings of ownership of Europe among our citizens. Such an unprecedented open dialogue can make Europe grow as a democracy caring, with reciprocity, about its citizens.  I see this conference also as a follow—up to what was new in the last European elections. As never before, the 2019 elections generated a common European narrative instead of the traditional separate 28 national stories. These elections proved that our citizens expect more from Europe than in the past. We know that citizens cannot just be offered the option to listen to what we politicians and institutions have to say about globalisation, climate neutrality, green policies, migration, digitalisation, social justice, competitiveness, and so on. They want to participate in responding to challenges, to address them jointly and to tailor these responses to their taste, needs and dreams. We should use this opportunity to learn how to be in listening mode. (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we must recognise that the proposal to have a conference came from the crisis in which the European Union is in, and we all need to make an analysis. Have politicians done everything they need to talk to citizens? Perhaps if we did more, the politicians, that yes, and I believe in representative democracy, we represent the citizens, but have we met as much as we should have with the citizens to consult them when we vote, when we make decisions on their behalf?  And in management, when a measure fails, you have to find another measure, and in fact, that's what you want through this conference. Obviously we have to be careful how we integrate this conference, this new body, this platform that wants to bring the citizen closer to us with national constitutions, with national parliaments. The structure is laid down in the conference proposal; implementation is important, it is important not to make a new bureaucracy, a new cost and to follow the effects. Yes, I will support this resolution and I believe that we all need to support it because, in fact, it is a mechanism to improve communication with citizens.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Madam President, just because the task will be difficult does not mean that this conference should not be launched. No, it is because the engine of European integration is failing that it is important to do a collective introspection. Let's be clear, the way we operate is going to lead us straight into the second league.
