This conference will be an opportunity to agree on a collective diagnosis, to question the reasons for our paralysis, to coalesce the efforts of citizens who want to help shape their future, to give a voice to the disappointed and also to give a voice to young people. In fact, I would advise those who lack the arguments and motivation for this conference to draw inspiration from the messages from young Britons disappointed by Brexit.

name: Patrick BREYER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her How do we make the EU policy for the majority of citizens and not for corporations? How do we curb lobbying? How can Europeans take the helm themselves, if necessary, through EU-wide referendums and direct democracy? In order to regain citizens' confidence in the EU and to protect Europe from a break-up or gradual takeover by nationalists, as we have heard today, we need fundamental reform, a relaunch of the EU. I hope that this conference on the future of Europe will be able to bring about some minor improvements. But to expect representatives of the EU institutions to reform themselves is like asking frogs how to dry up a swamp. Let us therefore have the courage and confidence in our citizens to entrust a directly elected Citizens' Convention with the drafting of a new EU Constitution and to let Europeans decide for themselves the EU that you want in a Europe-wide referendum.

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Madam President, tomorrow the social Europe, tomorrow the Europe that protects a more democratic Europe tomorrow, it is now more than 30 years since politicians sang the same song to us and made the peoples of Europe promise promises that had never been kept. The best intentions of the world will do nothing: no legitimate and sustainable European project will see the light of day until it is based on free cooperation between nations and therefore on respect for the sovereignty of each. The European Union is not only criticised in its structure, it is also and above all in its policy. Protecting peoples from the face of wild globalisation, defending their identity, artificial intelligence, technological revolution or environment and ecology, your European model has made us miss everything. We had to compete with America, China, Russia or India, we are actually reduced to impotence. I dare to express a wish: that this conference on the future of Europe should finally be the moment of a radical change of course, but I am under no illusions. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8, of the internal regulation)

name: Ben HABIB
text: blue-card question. – Mr Bardella, would you agree with me that the name of this conference is a misnomer? It really ought to be ‘the future of the European Union’, not ‘the future of Europe’. And would you also agree with me that the conference could actually be dispensed with, because the future of the European Union is actually quite dire and will dissolve quite soon?

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: answer 'blue card'. I do not confuse Europe with the European Union. I believe that Europe is a continent, which invented the nations, which contains within it, perhaps the most beautiful and oldest nations in the world, but that in any case the European Union, which has been built for a little over 30 years now, is destroying nations. I am delighted to have seen the British people regain their freedom, but in any case we cannot imagine European cooperation without British power and I believe that partnerships between a new form of European integration and the British nation will still have to be considered.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: – President, i'm not If citizens see that, despite the European green course, laws are being adopted that, in the name of protectionism, will drive empty trucks across the whole of Europe every other month, they hardly believe in European values. As union adherents are increasingly struggling around the European Union's budget, which is in fact one per cent of the NGNI, or twenty times smaller than the US Federal, and at the same time reducing cohesion resources, the already difficult demographic situation will mean the outflow of young people from the periphery of Europe to richer countries, making the differences between European countries even greater. Nor will the citizens believe it. When the demand for increased European sovereignty at global level was bordered on the fact that some major countries will be able to represent Europe on their own at global level, this is also not a delight for the rest of the country's citizens. And finally, if a citizen has candidates on the European lists in the European Parliament elections, for whom they have not heard anything in more than ninety per cent of them, that will not please them.  We can corrupt what is good for us in Europe at the moment, not to achieve anything else. Thank you.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: Madam President! The EU is the project of the elite. The EU benefits multinationals and the richest. This is at the expense of the climate, of the environment and of workers. Instead, we need equal democratic cooperation that puts citizens, nature and the climate at the centre. That is why we need a fundamental debate on how to cooperate in Europe. We do not need a predetermined debate in which the conclusion is always more centralisation, more unregulated market. We need an open and real involvement of citizens, civil society and national parliaments. That is why we are voting in favour of this resolution. We are never afraid to ask the citizens. We would also like to send a clear signal to the European Commission that unless there is a real involvement of citizens here - unless there is real popular involvement - then citizens will never forgive it.

name: Richard TICE
text: – Madam President, the future for the United Kingdom is bright, full of opportunity, as we have the political certainty of leaving the EU in just two weeks’ time. The opportunity to run our country as we want, not as the EU tells us. The opportunity to be a high—growth, low—tax, smartly regulated economy that competes on the world stage without unnecessary bureaucracy and protectionism. The opportunity to run a sensible, fair immigration policy that works for our economy, for our people. The opportunity to use state aid for our strategic industries and businesses. Our employment levels are at record highs, our unemployment at record lows, especially for our young people. I suggest to you, Madam President, the opportunity for the remaining EU27 countries can too be bright, if you reform, follow our lead and take back control. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I hope that we will agree with the majority that our future needs a strong, efficient, more credible European Union. And the European Union is all of us: citizens, municipalities, regions, nations and the European community. Let us therefore make the future our friend! Let us make the citizens our allies! Let us put the future of Europe and the role of the European Union in the world out of controversy in terms of party politics! The future needs a strengthening of European democracy, no decision without the European Parliament, the elimination of unanimity in the decision-making process, a European right to vote with European lists, the right of initiative, budgetary sovereignty, self-financing, European referendums. The future needs a European government that will then be the continent's spokesperson in the world and must have a common foreign, security and defence policy. Our future needs European responses to global challenges, our future needs a single market without barriers, our future needs a budget that is equal to the size of the tasks, the number of people in Europe and invests in the future. That is why I say to you: the future needs dialogue, European awareness, joint action. We as parliaments must be ready for this. We with our one million visitors, with an increased turnout and with our liaison offices and stakeholders. Let us tackle the matter together!

name: Giuliano PISAPIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, almost eighty years have passed since Altiero Spinelli and Ernesto Rossi, confined to an island by the fascist regime, wrote ventotene's manifesto. Today, more than ever, we feel the need for renewal and concreteness. The conference on the future of Europe offers us a unique opportunity, and perhaps the last, to respond to the demands for change and participation not only in the major urban centres but also in the countryside and in the suburbs, also listening to those who are against, those who are critical, those who do not agree with the current system of the European Union. That is why a structure capable of transforming ideas into concrete results is essential, the commitment of the European institutions to implement, even with the amendment of the Treaties, the main proposals that will emerge from the conference, otherwise we risk wasting one of the last chances of change, and there will be a great risk of a real boomerang, a step backwards for Parliament and the European Union. The way forward is neither easy nor safe, but it must be traveled and it will be, we will do it with conviction and passion.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, the conference on the future of Europe should deal with nothing less than our common future. And where to go next should be said by the most entased – citizens, Europeans. I am therefore glad that we have taken this step. I have heard calls for change in recent years as well. I have not heard any colleague say: everything works perfectly, there is no need for change. And that's why it's a good thing that now we politicians are actually going to market with our skins. Let's hear what we should be doing differently, better. That is to say, what is often true here in the Brussels bubble may not and often is not well perceived by the citizens of our countries. Europe is changing, the world is changing, we have new challenges technological, security, environmental. We have to look for answers to that, though. The worst thing we should do is do nothing, keep going. For many, this would probably be the most comfortable solution, but the solution would be short-term and the solution wrong. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the Blue Card (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: blue-card question. – Ms Charanzová, I am very happy that you mentioned meaningful citizen participation again, and so my question – because this has been discussed a lot here – is how would you see meaningful citizen participation with the maximum amount of people? How would you organise that?

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. If it were up to me, I'd only want citizens there, I'd want young people there. I hear them when I travel around the regions, in the Czech Republic. They want to get involved, we just haven't shown them the way. So let us sit down with them, we politicians, the institutions, the European Commission, representatives of national parliaments and let us listen to them. But for me, the driving force must be our citizens.

name: Scott AINSLIE
text: – Madam President, Brexit should serve as a dire warning to all of us as to what happens when ordinary people see the EU as distant, unaccountable and out of touch. It becomes terrifyingly easy for well—financed, far—right demagogues, aided and abetted by the populist gutter press, to turn people against it and whip up Eurosceptic fear. In the UK, it’s too late. The damage has been done. But it would be an absolute tragedy if the EU didn’t learn lessons from the calamity that is Brexit. So, if the conclusions of this conference are to be worth the paper they’re written on, the voices of citizens and civil society must be heard loud and clear. This process cannot be reduced to a tokenistic rubber—stamping exercise.  It’s worrying that powerful lobbyists and big businesses find it easy to influence the politics of any government anywhere, while NGOs and ordinary citizens are too often muted and kept in the cold. At this vital Conference on the Future of Europe, it is absolutely critical that we seize this chance to amplify citizens’ voices of all Europeans, which I and my country – as proud Europeans – look forward to continuing to contribute to doing.  (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Just briefly, Ms Huhtasaari, you are the next speaker but you also indicated to ask a question, which I’m not going to allow. I’m afraid that I’m subject to the rule of time, and my advisers tell me that I need to discontinue the blue-card system. I apologise for that, but we do have a formal sitting at 12 and we need to prepare the Chamber, so you have to accept my ruling on this for now, and perhaps you could discuss this procedure at a future time. Thank you for your cooperation and participation.

name: Niklas NIENASS
text: – Madam President, sorry, but I have to challenge your decision on the blue cards, because we have one hour in between the end of this debate and the next debate. I see your point that you have to discuss in the Chamber, but you have enough presidents to do that without one, and I think that you can continue this debate. We have seen so far that this debate really lived through the usage of blue cards. Therefore, I want to challenge your decision on discarding the debate by taking a decision in this plenary to continue with the usage of the blue-card system.  (Applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I love the blue-card system and I think it works. However, I cannot allow this debate to roll into the noon formal sitting. Maybe you and your Groups would take on board how good this debate has been and how interactive, and talk afterwards about how we might continue the process. But for now, I do not have one hour’s flexibility – I wish I did, but I don’t. So please, accept my ruling, and we will proceed with the debate and take on board my comments about, perhaps, reform for the future. Now, Ms Huhtasaari – and without interruption – you have one minute.

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Mr President, in totalitarianism, cooperation is only with those who agree. In the position building of the EU's future project, our ID Group has been ignored. Nationalism and Brexit have been identified as threats to be tackled in the EU's future project. Who are they a threat to? Certainly not for the people or for the sovereignty of nation states. Instead, they pose a threat to the EU's socialist superpower project and to the EU leadership, which believes that socialism should be tried once more.  Brexit has caused a panic reaction, which has deprived meppies of their own flags. There is a debate here about the need to involve citizens in the debate, but that obviously does not mean everyone. You keep saying that populists are not included in the debate, but citizens are being taken.  Just you wait – the future belongs to... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr President, Europe is indeed at a crossroads. The majority resolution is clear: you want a sovereign EU state with its own government, its own taxes, its own army. This makes member states into provinces. European conservatives have another Europe in mind, namely a community of sovereign states, cooperation between states – that is very important – more power back to the Member States and ultimately the abolition of the heavy bureaucracy we have. So we are going to launch a parallel process with a competitive and competitive project and we are going to debate with the people in the Member States. We also believe that the people should be able to express their own opinions in referendums.  So, ask the citizens, not all kinds of NGOs and the like, people everywhere in shadowy positions, but directly to the citizens. Let them speak out about the future of Europe rather than subsidised organisations.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, this is the best debate I’ve listened to in this Chamber. Well-chaired, Madam McGuinness. There’s been some honest reflections, and even Guy Verhofstadt has shown humility: to quote him, he said ‘we have a problem’. You do. With all this talk about citizens’ assemblies and consultations, there’s a danger that it is superficially bringing citizens into the decision-making process, but is really stage—managed tokenism. Actually, European citizens do speak out; they do debate freely all the time, without the help of bureaucrats. European citizens often shout their opinions loud and clear, in national elections, and in referenda, but they’re often dismissed by people here. When EU citizens dare criticize the EU institutions or eurozone austerity policies, many MEPs here in unpopular institutions and political parties put their hands over their ears or spit out insults. ‘You’re populist’, they say, ‘you’re far right’. I’m actually on the left! ‘You’re manipulated,’ they say to voters, ‘by misinformation or demagogues’. In other words, you can’t be serious about consulting citizens if you demonise those citizens unless they sycophantically act as cheerleaders for the EU.  (Applause) You seem to want to create ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Madam President, I very much welcome this discussion, and I also welcome the resolution for which I hope we can gather the widest possible support in this House. It is important: we need a strong start for this conference, and we don’t need it just in this House – we need it especially beyond the confines of this House. Indeed, the conference should bring results for improving our institutions, and also our decision making.  But, more importantly, I hope that the conference carries something more, and that is the emotion: the emotion which we saw in the run up to the last European elections, when voters’ participation increased in unprecedented numbers across the EU Member States. And we need to carry this emotion; we need to carry the increased trust of our citizens in Europe’s future, and we need to do it through their participation in this conference. This is essential, and I just want to respond very quickly to the remarks from the far—right corner of this house. This is going to be a conference on Europe’s future. Article 19 is very clear. I believe we should engage all of those in the EU candidate countries who are ready to work with us, who are ready to join us. This is the opportunity to make this a conference on Europe’s future; to make this a conference on a stronger Europe in the world.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with the last European elections, the citizens have shown us that they still want to believe in the European project, provided that Europe changes. Today alone, closed in our states, we are not going anywhere. The international crises on our borders are just the latest wake-up call to the need for a one-voice Europe, but it is the last call to change Europe. We have a duty to open, with this conference, a new constituent phase, an opportunity to relaunch in order to focus on a more democratic Europe, with a central role for the European Parliament, but also a moment of openness and listening in order to re-engage the citizens and talk about their needs and expectations. We therefore need a dynamic and pragmatic conference which will give the European institutions a real change of pace in terms of effectiveness and credibility. But be ware, colleagues! We must avoid a debate for its own sake, where the intentions are not followed by action, because otherwise, as an opportunity, the conference becomes a fuel for the engine of anti-Europeanism, and we cannot afford it.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Just briefly, when people are speaking really fast, I get a flashing light from the interpreters, so say less rather than more, and then you’ll be within your time. A small piece of advice.

name: Claudia GAMON
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her With the Conference on the Future of Europe, we are making a promise – a promise that Europe must function better in the future. I am very pleased that over the next two years we will be putting the citizens of Europe before the curtain to ask them what their expectations of a common, strong Europe of the future could be. The central question will be: what is our vision of a common Europe? And also to the citizens: what is your vision of what the future of Europe can look like? Important reforms often fail because of fear – fear that citizens do not want something supposedly. But my experience from many conversations is that the citizens of the Union think much further, think much more courageously than their Heads of Government might already trust them to do. That is why let us take this courage with us and let us also take decisions that will be essential and decisive for Europe to function better. We have so many challenges that we face here every day, such as the climate catastrophe. How can we counter them, if not in an improved, common and stronger Europe? I hope that we will also use this conference as an opportunity to carry on this spirit of common altogether into the coming years, and for me that means moving on to the United States of Europe!

name: Niklas NIENASS
text: – Madam President, I think we have seen so far in this debate that we do face a crisis in Europe, and I think we have seen not just after the election, but already before, that there are two possibilities. Do we want less Europe or more? The Far Right have so far expressed their vision of this, but we, with a big majority of people who said we want more Europe, have won this election. So therefore, we now need to decide: how much more Europe do we want? And I think this question should be answered by the public, by everyone, by sitting together and answering this question. And yes, the answer to this question can be that we want less, that the people want less Europe. But I say let us take the risk, because so far, I know that we have the better arguments. We know that Europe has brought unity of East and West, that it has brought freedom, that it has brought peace and prosperity. And so I see all the good arguments on our side, and I know that we will win this debate. Talking of debate, let us continue to have a good debate in this plenary and make this the first European public sphere.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this Europe must be changed and turned from top to bottom. We do not need more Europe but a completely different and new Europe. No more Europe as a slave to banks and multinationals. Enough of the Europe of bureaucrats, lobbies and finance. Von der Leyen's will be the usual heated soup, the usual Europe dominated by France and Germany, Merkel and Macron. The Europe we want is a Europe of peoples, of freedom and of true democracy. The Europe we want to build must stop illegal immigration, defeat Islamic terrorism, protect made in Italy, defend our businesses and our workers. This is the great democratic revolution that we will carry on with our backs straight and with the strength of those who truly represent the will of the Italian people.

name: June Alison MUMMERY
text: – Madam President, the hallmarks of British society are politeness, respect and modesty. But as those who sought to hijack the Brexit agenda have found, we continue to be no simple ‘nation of shopkeepers’. When our values, democracy and sovereignty are threatened, the ‘bulldog spirit’ rises in our blood and the fightback starts.  This is what happened in the recent election, which was convincingly won by Boris Johnson. The British public saw three years of delay, bullying, plotting and platitudes for what it was: a betrayal of British democracy.  So as this stage of the Brexit saga draws to a close, I trust that lessons have been learned to help a future UK-EU relationship. I trust that the EU hierarchy now realises the British people will not be taken for fools or pushed around moving forward. I sincerely hope we can find a route to effective cooperation and friendship.  Above all, I hope the EU can finally accept the choice of the British people to leave the EU. I think Lech Wałęsa summed up the situation well when he... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Madam President, four days ago, twelve dead migrants were added to the tragic list of victims between Turkey and the Greek islands. Twenty people were rescued by superhuman efforts of the Greek Navy, while unfortunately so many others are missing. Migrant flows continue unabaised, despite bad weather, and Turkey continues, in its usual practice, to disregard international law. The new asylum plan, announced months ago, has not yet been launched.  What future of Europe are we talking about today? There is no future without the participation of all countries in tackling the top common European problems. The emphasis on guarding the external borders, which is also a concern of each Member State, is important, but it is not enough. A fair and equal distribution of refugees is required in all, without exception, the countries of the European Union according to the criteria we have set. Today we didn't hear anything about it. How do we dream of a united Europe when each Member State pursues a different policy of its own interests? When countries have closed borders and refuse to take responsibility? Let us be realistic and honest, colleagues. We cannot talk about the future of a Europe without solidarity in practice. Migration threatens the cohesion and foundations of the European Union, and its management undermines citizens' confidence in our values. We have a duty and an obligation to react immediately and in practice but above all seriously and responsibly.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The European Union is still the guarantor of peace, freedom and prosperity on this continent. The achievements for the citizens are innumerable. But the EU is not perfect. She's work in progress, she's constantly changing, and she has to. It must become more democratic, more social, more ecological, and, above all, it must overcome the distance that many people feel about it. This two-year conference on the future of Europe is an opportunity. It will be crucial that citizens are not only heard, but that they can also take decisions that carry weight. We are aware of what this means, and we are committed to this: a clear mandate from the Conference to initiate legislative initiatives, including amendments to the Treaties. That is why it is important, firstly, that the conference delivers clear results and, secondly, that the citizens are fully involved. Confidence can only be strengthened through comprehensive communication during and after and complete transparency, and that is Parliament's job.

name: Caroline VOADEN
text: – Madam President, millions of people in my country don’t really understand how the European Union works. They associate the EU with mythical rules on bent bananas and banning bagpipes, because of a right-wing media that has spread lies and disinformation for decades. But beware: we are not the only ones. Brexit is a cautionary tale, and it could have happened to many of you.  This conference on the future of Europe is an ambitious project, and it needs to be if it is going to secure the future of this unique union of nations. I believe that people want to feel involved, enfranchised, represented and consulted. We are the democratically elected representatives of the European people and for them to have a proper say, this House must have legislative initiative. The Council must become more transparent. People must understand the reason that progress is not being made. Migration is a classic example, because national governments are blocking Council.  Colleagues, cooperation between peoples, nations and cultures is the future. Going it alone is not the answer, and the citizen’s voice is the most important one of all.  (Loud applause)

name: Anna DEPARNAY-GRUNENBERG
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For us Greens, too, the conference on the future of Europe raises the question: how do we want to live in the future? How we want to balance environmental, social and economic concerns can only be found out if we enter into a great exchange with the citizens of Europe. Participation is at the heart of a sustainable and regenerative culture that we urgently need in order to limit climate change and stop the loss of biodiversity. For example, what exactly is the mobility revolution on the ground, how do we manage to change an economy so that it serves the common good? Such transformation processes are profound, and they can only work if they are placed on a broad democratic basis. That is why I am very pleased that Parliament is today expressing this invitation. Join us! We want to shape Europe together, and we must make Europe fit for the challenges that are present and for the challenges ahead. What kind of Europe do we actually need to do this? How do we want to live in the future?

name: Ann WIDDECOMBE
text: – Madam President, it was Madame García Pérez who reminded us at the beginning of this debate that the European Union started with six countries. The vision then was that it would be a loose alliance of sovereign nations in a trading agreement with some sort of political cooperation, with a totally noble ideal that that would somehow promote peace. And if that had remained the vision, and was still the vision, I venture to say that I don’t believe that Britain would now be leaving.  But that did not happen. Co-operation morphed into domination. Sovereignty morphed into a superstate. And that is why Britain is going, and I believe that when we have made a big success of being a competitor on your doorstep, others will follow us. And therefore if you want a future – not for Europe, but for the European Union, which is a different thing – learn the lessons of what has happened in the UK.  (Sustained applause)

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, Madam Representative of the Council, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The Conference on the Future of Europe is an important conference, because we do indeed need considerable reform in the European Union. For me, one issue is important, which is to strengthen our parliamentary democracy. And when I talk about parliamentary democracy, I mean the leading candidate process. We have talked a lot today about proximity to the citizens and how we involve the citizens. I note that a great deal of trust has been lost among the citizens since the last European elections. We have over 200 million people who took part in the European elections, and our people had a clear expectation that those who are running as leading candidates in this European election will ultimately assume responsibility in the Commission. We all know that things have turned out differently, and I believe that if we want to restore confidence to our citizens, then we really must work on reforming this leading candidate process. For me, the heart chamber of democracy here is the European Parliament. This is where the decisions are taken, and we need to exchange and discuss. I think it is good that we are involving citizens' opinions in the process broadly, but at the end of the day we in the European Parliament must decide. That is our task, and that is what we have been elected for. I would be very pleased if, in the course of the debate on the future of Europe, parliamentary democracy, with the right of initiative and the like, would be strengthened accordingly.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: – Madam President, let us be brave. Let us talk bravely. Let us start building the United States of Europe. (Applause) Europe has achieved a lot in the past decades, but it’s not enough. The world is changing, so Europe must change too. The threats, the challenges, became global, so the European Union has to become a global player. I do understand that changing – especially changing ourselves – is always frightening, but I would say that fear is a bad advisor. So that’s why I say: let us start to build a stronger, more federal and more democratic Europe. I call for an alliance of the brave. Let us build a United States of Europe, and I promise that the next generation are going to be proud of us in exactly the same way as we are proud of the founding fathers of the Union.  (Applause)

name: Cristian GHINEA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we want to involve citizens in this Conference, but it must not be a formal involvement. There is a way to involve citizens in a consistent way – it is called a citizens' jury – and I recommend, Commissioner, that you use this method.  At the same time, I want to respond to the challenge of my colleague from the Group of The Greens, Niklas Nienass. ... (responding to Niklas Nienass's assertions)... Dear Niklas, I would like Guy Verhofstadt to lead this Conference, I would like us to have a leader, and strong, at this Conference, and let us do it together.  You saw Guy's speech today, it was the most listened to – perhaps the most interesting moment of this debate. Even colleagues at the Brexit party, who we will miss very soon, have listened intently. We, all of us, listened carefully. Let us promote Guy Verhofstadt to the leadership of this Conference, so that we can have a real debate at European level.

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner! The problems facing Europe are not solved by moving away from cooperation by leaving European cooperation. But it is also not a question of creating the United States of Europe. Instead, it is a question of focusing on the social problems that require more answers.  We need to fight terrorism and cross-border crime better together in Europe. We need more of a common immigration policy. We need to ensure that we have a modern and effective climate policy, speak more in common with a voice of foreign policy and strengthen our defence work.  On this, the conference on the future of Europe should be about. Not about how we view electoral systems or how we are going to change the powers of our cooperation, but about political leadership that solves the societal problems facing Europe. That is what will, in the long run, be able to ensure that we have greater support for European cooperation. Do not let the fringes of politics here in Europe be the ones that set the agenda, but let the voice of reason be the one that governs this. I am quite sure that we will then have strong support for what Europe needs.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, European construction has been and continues to be a constituent, open and transparent process at the service of the common destiny shared by all Europeans. Ten years after the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the holding of the conference gives us a great opportunity to build directly with citizens the future of Europe through participatory and representative dialogue at European, national, regional and local levels. There are many ideas that we will discuss, but I believe that the Full respect on the part of the Council for the Spitzenkandidat process, the right of legislative initiative of this Parliament, of the European Parliament, and the elimination of the right of veto of States in the Council, with the transition to a qualified majority, must be at the heart of the discussions.  I hope that the European institutions will work together, and with the citizens, to achieve it with political courage.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are more than just Member States. We're more than isolated people. It is clear that we are living in a time of convulsive, that we need better rules and that the big problems, the big challenges, are not national. They're transnationals. And our chance is here in the European Union. That's why we have to look at the worst and the best since we walked together. But we're not going to be able to do it if we let ourselves be blinded by the poison of nationalpulism. Of course we have something to learn from Brexit: populism. Of course we have to learn from ultranationalism. Yesterday we were told here that we want a European mechanism of self-determination. To balkanize, to blind us. So that we can destroy Europe. We need to be strong, indeed. We need to put citizens at the center of the system and we need artificial intelligence to be human. We need, perhaps, to be so strong that we can reach a new convention. We need European citizenship, not destroying Europe. No more borders.

name: Sven SIMON
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. This fine debate has shown that, ten years after the Treaty of Lisbon, we need a reform of the Treaties. The primary objective of this conference on the future of Europe must be to strengthen the capacity of Europeans to act. And then we saw quite nicely in the debate that we have not yet found the right way in this supranational structure of how we organise the democratic process. I thought the debate we have had today was very nice. It was about direct democratic elements, it was about parliamentary democracy. There is one thing we should not do: we should not create a split between the citizens here and Parliament here. Parliament can get smarter through this conference and we should involve the people. But in the end, after 300 years in Europe, we learned that parliamentary representative democracy is the best way to organise democracy. Whatever the outcome of the conference, I think it is important that we create a European public, and this Parliament must be the platform for that public. That is why a cross-party group has today written a letter – including to you, Madam President – that we are reforming this plenary debate. We should be at the forefront of this as speakers, look at each other, sit down here, that we have a lively debate that is also transferable in the media.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the conference on the future of Europe opens an ambitious process of dialogue between the institutions and the citizens, which must be well structured. The aim is to bring out a proposal for reform of the Union on the basis of concrete demands and needs. We must emphasise the content and give Europe the opportunity to deal with it, starting with issues that have a tangible impact on people's lives, such as taxation, the fight against climate change, social policies but also foreign policy, which is the subject of the spotlight these days. Our resolution puts in black and white the Commitment of the European Parliament to ensure that the conclusions of the Conference are respected, that they are effectively followed up by specific legislative measures, by amending the Treaties, because we need the European Federation today. Parliament must lead the way, which I believe is the best guarantee against the risk that the conference will instead become a political and electoral showcase for some leaders, or be used to see intergovernmental agreements on the downside. We must prevent this and we will prevent it, in order to really defend the future of Europe.

name: Gilles BOYER
text: Madam President, when, like me and others, many of us on these benches discover this Parliament, the first challenge is to understand how it works and if we sometimes have difficulties, that is to say how far the distance is for European citizens to take ownership of the functioning of our institutions. In our common interest, one of the first objectives of this conference should, in my opinion, be to bring clarity to our functioning and it starts with clarity at the most emblematic moment, that is, at the time of the European elections, which is when citizens are most aware of our issues. Last May, the mechanism of the Spitzenkandidaten (top candidates) was presented as a democratic progress, but events alone - and events have shown this - is not enough. On the other hand, it will find its relevance if, at the same time, European citizens can vote on transnational lists and thus clearly give a mandate to a European personality to try to gather a majority around his name. European lists for European elections are, I think, a fine goal.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – Madam President, the European Union today is significantly different from what it was only a decade ago when the Lisbon Treaty entered into force. We are witnessing truly unprecedented technological and economic, but also demographic, changes. This clearly affects the way we live, the way we work and the way we communicate, but it also has an impact on the demand for a more active role for our citizens in our democracy.  This is why we have the responsibility to offer new and innovative ways for Europeans to be included more in the decisions that matter to them. Since young Europeans are often the ones who really lead the transformative trends in our societies, they can certainly offer a unique point of view. I’m also glad that Vice—President Šuica will lead the Commission’s work on the conference. This is because, for its success, it is really crucial to understand all the European diversities and to include the special perspectives of our citizens coming from all corners of Europe. Because of that, it is really important to include all those perspectives. This conference should certainly not be a box—ticking exercise. We have to be constructive, we have to be inclusive, and we have to adapt Europe for the new world and for the new generations.  (Applause)

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner! Democratic values, fundamental rights, climate change, social justice, equality and equality. These are precisely the important issues that the future debate on Europe should be about. A conference on the future of Europe, which must also be aimed at the young generation.  I was delighted today when I was able to listen to a lively debate in which several of our young, including newly elected, parliamentarians have taken part in the debate on the future. That's good. The debate on the future must be about the important thing that strengthens Europe. We must show commitment and determination. We must hold together a Europe in which we bring out hope, where we give the young generation hope for the future of Europe.

name: László TRÓCSÁNYI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. The conference on the future of the European Union gives the European Union a chance to take steps to regain a shaken trust, thus giving a boost and a new impetus to European construction. Participatory democracy is important, but make sure that we do not force ideological views on each other. Therefore, beware of ideological missionaries settling into the conference. For us, tradition and renewal must be important at the same time. We must not forget the preservation of the spirit of the founding fathers and christian democracy, but we must also seek answers to new questions such as the content definition of the European way of life. A European identity can only be built on the recognition and respect of national identities. The conference can only be successful if we accept that the European Union is a community of values and interests whose pillars span from the bottom up and whose motto is Unity in Diversity. That is why the idea of a United States of Europe cannot be accepted.

name: Włodzimierz CIMOSZEWICZ
text: – Madam President, the Conference on the Future of Europe comes at the best possible moment. In the last quarter of a century, the world has changed significantly. The economy, technology, communications and the share of power in global relations – all that is new.  Dangerous climate change and the demographic explosion in many regions create an urgent need to act. Europe must adapt itself to the new reality, and Europeans have to understand this situation. The Conference can and should diagnose the problems and prescribe the remedies. The basic condition of success is unprecedentedly broad participation of the citizens of the EU.  Conferences, agoras, consultations – all that is necessary, but it is not sufficient. We should make full use of communication online. I believe that the best way is to have pan-European consultative referenda with the participation of millions of people. It would strengthen democracy, make the people active citizens and give them satisfaction from having had a say.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Madam President, the idea of reconnecting with our citizens is an essential tool, and not a recreational toy, and no one should be playing with it. We should ask our citizens what Europe they envisage, and we should do it sincerely, honestly, and truthfully. If we say that we need to hear from them, then we must be ready to listen and also to implement. It has been the biggest direct democracy exercise of Europe for the last decade, and we cannot initiate it with a prepared vision for the end and final results. We all know that, in some capitals, treaty changes are being drafted. Projects like a Europe of various speeds or blockages like the one of North Macedonia may not be what the people want. They may not be happy to simply play the role of a rubber stamp. The preparation of those conferences should be focused not on assigning posts and inventing mechanisms to steer the public debates, but on how to hear what our citizens have to say and implement that. Perhaps those old habits are exactly the reason why we have to reconnect with our citizens today. (Applause)

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Madam President, for too long in the European institutions has dominated this idea that We can make Europe without the peoples, not against the peoples - let us leave this rhetoric to the nationalists - for the peoples, certainly, but without them. This logic has reached its limits and we are now on the brink. So yes, 100 times yes, this conference to re-found the European Union is more than necessary, but citizens must be directly involved in this work, the debate must come out of the institutions to irrigate all our societies. How can we strengthen our European democracy, how can we build a common army, how can we establish a common tax system? These and so many other issues must be debated and decided by involving as many citizens as possible. It's not just about consulting, it's about co-building. So, ladies and gentlemen, this conference must mark a new beginning, not just by its conclusions, but also by its method. In its very method, it must open the era of active and no longer passive European citizenship, the era of genuine transnational public debate. Either we democratize or we die, then democratize.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, the future of Europe is, without question, a concern of us, of each of us. I therefore appreciate that the solution to the Conference on the Future of Europe is welcome. European citizens must be able to debate what tomorrow will look like in Europe, but also be able to express their own vision on this subject.  Civil society and all stakeholders at European, national, regional and local level must contribute to strengthening the European future, while respecting a set of inalienable and indestructible values, while also shaping the European Union as we want it. Whether we are talking about the environment and climate, the economic and social sector, the rights and freedoms of the European citizen must be guaranteed.  Young people are, at the same time, the most affected by decisions that are made in one way or another. That is why they must be given the necessary space where they can express their views, as well as present their solutions for their future and for Europe.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Madam President, I hope that the Parliament – the great majority here – is ready to prepare the future of Europe openly and not behind closed doors. We even invite citizens to participate and to be listened to, firstly in a citizens’ agora and in an additional agora for young people, who will be the most affected by the future of Europe. There are very good signals of people’s will to participate. In last summer’s elections, participation, especially among young people, increased by over 12%. So what kind of future? For example, in the Nordic countries we value security and foreign policy and see good opportunities to be a more serious global player. We have a strong commitment to climate action, we value social fairness and we hate ongoing tax frauds. We know that citizens also want to raise practical issues that make their lives easier and better, but that the lack of common regulation hinders this. Dialogue gives people more of a voice to raise topics and issues between elections. This conference needs to look at the democratic aspect of the future of the EU, and the Spitzenkandidat system must be clear well before the next elections.

name: Geoffroy DIDIER
text: Madam President, will the conference on the future of Europe be another 'thing' that Emmanuel Macron has the secret to preparing for his future presidential campaign or a concrete step forward in the service of the people? The future will tell. If you want concrete progress, here is one: we were elected on 26 May, our mandate lasts five years, and yet the truly structuring work does not begin until this week, eight months after our election. What time wasted with successive installations of institutions. In order to improve the future of Europe, I propose concretely that from the next mandate, the Commission and the Council of the Union should be installed within four weeks of the election of MEPs and thus, from 1 July and not the following 1 January, all the institutions should be fully operational and thus be able to start their work in the service of the peoples. Ladies and gentlemen, we have not been elected to get bogged down in the pipes, we have been elected to repair the image that peoples can have of this beautiful project that is Europe.

name: Radan KANEV
text: Madam President, I have decided today to speak in French because I would like to express my indignation against the idea of a multi-speed Europe, of which President Macron is the main promoter. European countries can indeed follow development trajectories at different speeds and this can even suit bureaucrats and administrations. However, our debate is not about the well-being of governments. It must be centred on European citizens, it concerns the peoples of Europe and even the peoples of associated countries such as Northern Macedonia or Albania. People do not move at different speeds in their efforts to achieve freedom, prosperity and the rule of law. Promoting a stratified Europe is a mistake, and such a policy will have perverse effects.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, when the Lisbon Treaty finally entered into force in 2009, the then President of the Council, Mr Van Rompuy, announced in this House that it would be the Treaty with which we would live for the rest of our lives. And yet ten years later, when the von der Leyen Commission kicks off, it launches a Conference on the Future of Europe, from which a reform of the Treaties can come, what is the reason? For, in agreement with the Lisbon Treaty, the European Union is plunged into the worst crisis in its history. Great recession, exasperation of inequalities, application of Article 7 to two Member States, a Member State which leaves the Union – Brexit – and, above all, in this Parliament, increasing the number of seats representing exclusionary nationalism and supremacist and reactionary populism.  This Parliament has no deficit of democratic legitimacy. It is the only directly elective institution. It has no skills shortfall, even if they can be strengthened. It is a legislative parliament, but it must seize the opportunity of the Conference to reconnect with the ... (The president withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Valter FLEGO
text: – Dear Chairman, I think this Conference on the Future of Europe is a fantastic opportunity to hear what kind of Europe citizens really want. What is important from their needs, from their desires, we will come up with an idea that we need to make, which is how to change, how to reform this Europe. The question arises as to how we will be able to measure the success of the Conference. I think in two ways. The first is definitely the conclusions that will need to be implemented, and the second is the number of citizens who will join the conference. That is why it is important to maximise the motivation of citizens, so it is important to reimburse them for the cost of travel, but also to involve NGOs, to involve maximum all interested parties and not to ask citizens once every five years what kind of Europe they want, but now in the next two years to give them a maximum vote, and then to act.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab At the outset, I would like to mention that, from the beginning of this debate, from nine o'clock in the morning, I have been here and listening to all the voices, all the voices I accept with respect, some with amusement. What made me laugh the most? Well, your statement – I am turning to the left of the Chamber here – how important the voices of the citizens of the European Union are to you. And what are the facts? The person who most of us gathered here won votes in direct elections, the former Prime Minister of the Polish Government Mrs Beata Szydło your decision, the decision of your political families, did not make her chair of the committee. Another of my colleagues, Professor Krasnodębski, did not become Vice-President of the European Parliament as a representative of the ECR Group. It made me laugh. I was also amused to say that the future of Europe depends on what decisions will be taken on the leading candidates for President of the Commission or whether Mr Verhofstadt will be president of this conference. The names of the founding fathers were here. It is worth recalling the words of one of them: "The future of Europe – yes...". (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Mr President, I think there are people here... (doesn't finish sentence)... I hear from the right that there is confidence in the European Union. I hear the same from a few Socialists and some Greens. I would like to reiterate that one in two citizens did not vote in the last European elections. There is a democratic crisis within the European Union, and you are underestimating it. Where did this crisis come from? When the French voted against the European Constitution, you ignored them. The Dutch did the same: they were ignored. When the Irish voted against the Lisbon Treaty, they had to vote again. Then we got the Greeks who voted against the savings policy: bulldozed. And then you are surprised that the British do not see a social alternative in this European Union. You are not going to solve this crisis with a conference of some establishment politicians, perhaps even led by Guy Verhofstadt. It's not going to work that way.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first of all, let me thank you for this very vivid and fruitful debate. I have listened carefully to today’s points and taken note of your views. It is my role to listen to you. The start date of the Conference is yet to be confirmed, but the listening process itself has already started. We are already reflecting and engaging with as many actors as possible. We will need the cooperation of the Commission representation offices and the European Parliament liaison offices in the Member States, who already do tremendous work to bring the European Union closer to its citizens.  We need them, now more than ever, to lead our efforts. Let us remember how this feeds into other areas of my work as Vice-President for Democracy and Demography. We want to hear from all people of all ages and, of course, from the young. I thank the younger Members of Parliament for today’s debate.  I also have to thank Pascal Durand, Daniel Freund and Ruiz Devesa Domènec for mentioning NGOs. Of course, we haven’t forgotten NGOs. They will be included, and that was our idea from the beginning. We also have to take care of the older generation, whom we wish to encourage in their active contribution to our society and economy.  Of course, this concerns not only NGOs or older people, but also minorities, entrepreneurs, students, regional and local authorities, mayors and everyone who can say something on the structure, scope and the content of the Conference. These views will feed into my work on demography. We want to provide real and workable solutions for our citizens. Our democracy is in need of creative and innovative solutions. The results of this process – whatever they are – must be tangible, must be implemented and must be based on the feedback we receive from our citizens. As I already said, this is no longer business as usual. We must be brave and embrace the innovative nature of this process. Not everything needs to be known in advance, but we are providing the solid structure necessary for full citizen participation, both online and in person. I want to ensure that every voice is heard and listened to, and that we follow up on it accordingly. It is vital that this process remains open and transparent. I do not want to pre—empt what the citizens have to say, on the contrary, I want to be surprised by them.  I’m sure that, together, we can also surprise the citizens. But we, the European Parliament, the European Commission and the European Council, we can do this only by working closely together as real partners. I want to thank you once again for this fruitful debate.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, to conclude, I wish to thank you for the very useful debate we had today. I have listened carefully to your views on this important subject and taken note of Parliament’s position on the Conference on the Future of Europe. This process, which requires long-term vision, should focus on the topics and policies that will continue to be at the forefront of our citizens’ preoccupations in the years to come, especially of the youth. Let me assure you that our part of the Presidency will continue working towards a definition of the Council position on the Conference on the basis of which to engage with this House and the Commission. As stated by President Sassoli and Vice—President Šuica, cooperation among other institutions will be key to making the most of this idea. I am confident that I can count on your cooperation to find together the right formula so that this initiative can be launched on a shared basis to deliver results for our citizens. Thank you very much once again for your attention.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have received three motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Emmanouil FRAGKOS
text: Writing. – The Conference on the Future of Europe must take into account the urgent need to strengthen democratic legitimacy and restore public confidence in the administration. We reiterate that the Europe of the future must ensure that a Christian Europe remains. We must stop blinding ly to the critical issues. Mass illegal immigration, which distorts European homogeneity and the European way of life, must be tackled immediately and effectively if this is the Europe we want: a Europe with a strong geopolitical position and an active role on the international chessboard; a Europe that leads in world trade and economic development and stability; a Europe of citizens, able to protect its sovereign rights from illegal actions by third states; a Europe with more democracy and greater stability; a Europe with more democracy and greater stability; a Europe of citizens, able to protect its sovereign rights from the illegal actions of third states; a Europe with more democracy and greater stability; a Europe of citizens, able to protect its sovereign rights from illegal actions by third states; a Europe with more democracy and greater democracy; a Europe with more democracy and greater stability. autonomy of its members, rather than a centralised and oligarchic Union. We want this Europe and we will fight for it.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – (IT is very important) that the European Parliament is speaking today, in a determined and timely manner, and through a comprehensively agreed resolution, on the objectives and methodologies to be adopted at the Conference on the Future of Europe. This Conference, although promoted by the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council, and involves the Committee of the Regions and the Economic and Social Committee, must mobilise national and regional governments and parliaments, civil society organisations throughout the European Union and, in particular, citizens, strengthening their sense of belonging to the European project and giving them a voice , not only to assess the decisions of representative democratic bodies but also to propose and demand concrete priorities, measures and solutions. After multiple debates and reflections that have not generated the necessary reform momentum in the European Union, the Conference which proposes to launch on 9 May and to be held by 2022 must be accompanied by the implementation of strong convergence and cohesion policies, translated into the European Ecological Pact, the Multiannual Financing Programme and a euro area architecture that strengthens the Union's own resources and its position in an increasingly competitive world.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, we have the honour of having King Abdullah II of Jordan with us today in this House, and he is returning to the European Parliament after having already been a guest a few years ago. It's a great honor for us.

name: Abdullah II
text: King of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. – Bismillah ar—Rahman ar—Rahim. Mr President, honourable Members, Your Excellencies, my friends, thank you all. It is an honour to speak before the European Parliament once again. As I look around this historic Chamber, I see it holds many hundreds of people. But in truth, there are with us today millions more, from different countries, histories, and perspectives. So we who are gathered here have two things in common. First is our responsibility to these millions – the people who have entrusted us with their hopes and fears. And second, we are all very fortunate, for a life spent in the service of others is a life fully lived – but only if we live up to the expectations of the millions of people with us in this hall today. If we falter, the most vulnerable pay the highest price – the young men and women who look to their future and see nothing; bewildered refugee mothers, clutching their children, with no place to call home; or anxious fathers who cannot find jobs to provide for their loved ones. And the many who feel side-lined, their identity under threat. The defining feature of the past decade has been people finding their voices. millions across the world have poured onto the streets, marched, occupied, sat down, sat in, tweeted, podcast, hashtagged what they want, loud and clear. And they all want the same thing: a fair chance, a fighting chance. Dear friends, people around the world have voiced their desired destination but are looking to us to guide them along the path; looking to us to foresee and prepare for the obstacles ahead. This calls for several ‘what if?’ questions. And these questions are not merely a whimsical or a theoretical exercise – especially in my region, where worst-case scenarios don’t lie comfortably within the realm of the hypothetical but often wander too closely to the borders of our reality. Furthermore, what happens in the Middle East has a way of making itself felt everywhere around the world. So let me start with our region’s deepest wound. What if the world gives up on the two-state solution of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict? Seventy-plus years of conflict have played havoc with hopes for justice. Today, one-staters are actively seeking to impose an unthinkable solution on the region and the world: one state, propped up by structural inequalities, with Palestinians as second-class subjects; one state turning its back on its neighbourhood, perpetuating divisions among peoples and faiths worldwide. Five years ago, I stood in this Chamber and spoke of the dangers of failing to move forward with peace, and today, I must say frankly that the dangers have grown: violence continues; settlement-building continues; disregard for international law continues. I’ve said it countless times and in countless ways, but I will say it again and again: a more peaceful world is not possible without a stable Middle East. And a stable Middle East is not possible without peace between Palestinians and the Israelis. (Applause) What if Jerusalem, a city that is close to my heart personally and of great historical significance to my family, remains disputed? Can we afford to rob Christians and Muslims alike of the spirituality, peace and coexistence that this city symbolises, and instead allow it to descend into political conflict? Now fast forward to the most recent standoff between the United States and Iran. What if, next time, neither side steps away from the brink, dragging us all towards untold chaos? An all-out war jeopardises the stability of the entire region. What’s more, it risks massive disruptions of the entire global economy, including energy markets, but threatens a resurgence of terrorism across the world. And I ask you another ‘what if?’: what if Iraq fails to realise the potential and aspirations of its people and slips back into an erratic, 17-year cycle of recovery and relapse – or worse yet, conflict? Iraq is home to 12 per cent of the world’s proven oil reserves. But more importantly, it is home to over 40 million people, who have suffered through four decades of war, crippling sanctions, occupation, sectarian conflict, and the terror of ISIS. Today their future rests on a fragile peace. And I, for one, will not abandon our brothers and sisters there. Now what if Syria remains hostage to global rivalries and spirals back into civil conflict? What if we see a re-emergence of ISIS and Syria becomes a staging-ground for attacks against the rest of the world? Syria may be out of the headlines, with its suffering out of sight and out of mind, but the crisis is far from over. Over the past nine months, more than half a million people have been displaced, many of them already refugees. Do any of us in this hall want to see another Syrian refugee crisis unfold, with all its horror and heartbreak? Or another innocent child washed up upon your shores? I know I speak for everyone here when I say: absolutely not. And let me ask you: what if Libya collapses into an all-out war, and ultimately, a failed state? What if Libya is the new Syria, just much closer to the continent you all call home? And let me say again: what if Arab governments fail to create the more than 60 million jobs our youth will need in the coming decade? And if we fail, wouldn’t we in fact be creating a perfect setting for extremist groups? We make their job of recruitment easier if we leave behind a trail of vulnerability and hopelessness. Can we afford to let the region’s young people live without hope? My friends, let this reflection upon ‘what if?’ scenarios be a productive exercise, one that can pre-empt countless tragedies and safeguard our people along their journey. My faith in God reinforces my optimism and my belief in the strength and resilience of humanity. There is always a better and much more united version of us around every corner. The Holy Qur’an teaches us that ‘Those who endure in patience and put their trust in their Lord’ will enjoy the greatest rewards. Patience is hard in a world that never seems to slow down, where people make split-second decisions and expect instantaneous results. Leadership, however, demands the very opposite: reflection, wisdom and the long view. More than ever, we need patient politics. Because we all have a responsibility to safeguard our people’s long-term interests and welfare; to react to rapidly unfolding events with measured responses, not knee-jerk reactions. Because politics is not a game where the fastest win. Sometimes, the faster we go, the farther away we end up from the finish line. My father, the late King Hussein, taught me that peace-making is always the harder – but the higher – path. And a tough road is best walked with our friends: friends like you and the people of Europe, so that together we can reach the future that both our peoples aspire to and that they and our whole world deserve. (The House accorded the speaker a standing ovation)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We thank the King of Jordan, the European Union's privileged interlocutor and a great friend of the European Parliament. We have listened to His words, his passion for achieving peace through confrontation and dialogue. We have a lot of work to do together and I believe that the beginning of this year shows even more the need for the work that we will have to do together.  (The sitting was suspended at 12.20 p.m.)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: – Mr President, my point is a bit moot, but I just wanted to ask if you could wait a bit before everybody gets seated and you get their attention, because there was a lot of noise here and what you said couldn’t be heard.

name: Daniel FREUND
text: Mr President, I would like to table an oral amendment to replace Strasbourg with Brussels. This is the seat of the majority of the EU institutions, and I believe it is important to send a strong signal to the citizens that they are being taken seriously and that a meeting will take place in Brussels at the end of the citizens' forums and not in Strasbourg.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Freund, I would have interrupted you now. Reasons are not admissible. (Parliament decided not to put the oral amendment to the vote) That concludes the vote.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – A Uachtaráin, leis an gComhaontú Glas don Eoraip, beidh gach Ballstát ábalta aistriú chuig sochaí íseal-charbóin. Ach níl ann ach túsphointe. Vótáil mé i bhfabhar an Chomhaontaithe. Leis an bplean docht seo, beimid ábalta stádas ísealcharbóin a bhaint amach. Chun é sin a dhéanamh, caithfimid trí rud a dhéanamh: Uimhir a haon: Tacú le pobail aistriú cóir a dhéanamh chuig sochaí ísealcharbóin. Uimhir a dó: Cinntiú go bhfuil na rialtais sásta na cinntí deacra a dhéanamh anois. Uimhir a trí: Cinntiú go n-oibríonn gnó príobháideach leis na rialtais.  Níl a lán ama fágtha chun an pláinéad a shábháil. Ba cheart eagla an domhain a bheith ar gach duine sa seomra seo mar gheall ar na tinte uafásacha san Astráil. I mo thír féin, tá stoirmeacha móra ann faoi láthair. Mar fhocal scoir, caithfimid misneach a thabhairt do dhaoine - misneach gur féidir linn teacht slán as seo. Gan dóchas, géilleann daoine. Molaim go gach duine anseo, óráid a thug Jacinda Ardern, Príomh-Aire na Nua-Shéalainne, roimh an Nollaig. Thug an óráid seo misneach dom gur féidir linn ár bplainéad, agus ár dtodhchaí, a shábháil.

name: Antony HOOK
text: – Madam President, today we have voted on perhaps the most important action the European Union will ever take. The European Green Deal marks a necessary effort to stop climate change and protect biodiversity for good. The framework for action must be agreed at a European and international level. Pollution never has, and never will, stop at national borders. It takes every individual, every local community, to act. In my home town of Faversham, air pollution is three times in breach of legal limits, and the government in which our own MP is a minister permits it to continue. Local councillors and the community are pushing our own environmental projects: we have become a plastic—free town. If you give communities power, they will fix their problems. Europe’s new Green Deal promises prevention of environmental damage that harms us now and endangers our children’s future. We cannot go on destroying nature. We can use new technology to make a greener, cleaner future.

name: Jackie JONES
text: – Madam President, the climate and environmental emergency is one of the most important challenges facing humanity, and all states and players worldwide must do their utmost to fight it. Europe urgently needs a new sustainable economic model that has to fit for the 2020s, meaning that it must combine social and environmental progress, reduce inequalities and improve the well-being of all, leaving no person and no place behind.  The European Green Deal spans across the EU from Romania to Ireland. But guess what? The UK’s geographical area is right there: a big land mass that requires consideration if we are to really tackle the climate crisis. Wales was the first country in the world to declare a climate emergency, and we want to work with our neighbours. We have to, and we want to. The European Green deal must put all of Europe on the path to long-term sustainable growth, prosperity and well-being. The EU as a global leader in climate action, and the European Green Deal must ensure that environmental, economic and social policies are developed to secure just transition and to pave the way for positive and sustainable social, industrial and economic change. Wales will do its part, whether it’s inside the EU or outside.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our Parliament has recently proclaimed a state of ecological and environmental emergency. It is therefore now necessary to act to the extent of the urgency that we have decreed together. However, if it shows interesting intentions, the text that you have proposed to us for the vote does not take the measures to the extent of the urgency of the situation. Let's take a few examples: the target of a 55% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions was already that of the previous mandate. It is insufficient, we must go to at least 65% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 if we are to contain global warming. The text refuses to initiate the profound and necessary reform of the common agricultural policy, whereas the text presented today by the Commission does not allow the ecological transition of agriculture to begin. The text refuses to denounce the EU's trade policy and free trade agreements. In short, on all these points, this text is insufficient: I therefore unfortunately cannot support it.

name: Jessica STEGRUD
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for "We do not have all the answers yet. Today is a start of a journey, but this is Europe's man on the moon moment." Big words from The President of the Commission, Mrs von der Leyen. But to promise a moon landing, in this case a carbon neutral continent, without telling us how it will be, what the consequences will be or even what the effects will occur, it is not serious – it is populism.  Investing in one thing means refraining from investing in another. To spend thousands of billions on undefined climate action is to refrain from investment in, for example, security, health care or other technological development areas – the basis for future growth and prosperity. The fact that you also want to put down carbon-free nuclear power shows that in your quest for the moon you cannot even take off your ideological blinders.  No, what Europe needs are politicians who take responsibility, set realistic goals and are clear about the consequences. That is why I am voting against Parliament's proposal today.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, the Position of the European Parliament on the Green Deal is very important. I expected it to be both ambitious and rational. Unfortunately, it is more ambitious than rational, which is why I eventually had to abstain in the final vote. I have focused on two topics, and that is agriculture. It is important that sustainable agriculture is recognised that it can only be achieved by involveing farmers in meeting the objectives of the Green Deal. I appreciate that this rhetoric does not blame farmers for the state of our environment, but rather provides new opportunities for farmers to combat climate change. In this area, therefore, the proposal is acceptable. In the end, the vote on the amendment on nuclear energy was unacceptable to me. Fortunately, this report also recognises subsidiarity and the possibility of an energy mix for Member States. However, an amendment recognising nuclear energy as important for the fight against climate change has not been adopted, which is why I ultimately abstained.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Green Agreement because it accurately summarises the position of the European Parliament. It is a balanced proposal to achieve climate neutrality, protect the environment and achieve healthy, quality living within the planet's capabilities.  The proposal is therefore balanced between the desired objectives of tackling climate change, a fair transition to green energy and economic opportunities. It is crucial to ensure cooperation between all stakeholders, i.e. citizens, regions, local communities, the professional public, civil society and the economy.  The resolution links the achievement of a climate-neutral society with the overhaul of industrial and SME strategies. It emphasises the european Union's leading role and calls for an active boost to the rest of the world. We must see the Green Deal as an emergency measure and, at the same time, an economic opportunity, and thus also inspire other polluting countries to prevent or at least mitigate the future devastating consequences of climate change.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I supported this motion for a resolution. The goal is clear, the direction is undoubtedly correct. This poses a very important challenge for our Union, as well as for many countries, as well as for the Czech Republic. We still have many regions that are not ready for this change, to the objectives that we have presented. I believe that this also poses a challenge to modernise the European and national economies. What bothers me, however, is that some of the votes that have passed, in my opinion, are detrimental to the result. I am sorry that nuclear energy has not been supported.
