I must say that I was also surprised that Parliament does not want to quantify the impact of the various measures envisaged. These are all disappointments that I would normally show at least by abstaining or voting against. However, I did not want to send out this negative opinion, and I therefore supported this proposal. We must remember the damage we have done to the planet and start removing it, which is why I supported this proposal.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, I did not support the resolution on the European Green Deal today, although I support many of the proposals put forward by the Commission, such as increasing biodiversity, protecting soil, forests, etc. But in some areas, proposals go into extreme positions that will not lead to a set goal, but will, on the contrary, put an extreme burden on the citizens of our countries. I wonder if those who supported this today asked their constituents whether they would agree to the multiple increases in electricity or heat that these proposals will unfortunately bring. Whether you have also asked your constituents whether they agree that many existing jobs will disappear. I think you're hiding all these negative consequences from your constituents. And when I look at the protests and strikes in some Member States because of the slight increase in petrol prices, I wonder how you want to defend to the public the proposals that you supported today.

name: Alexandra Louise Rosenfield PHILLIPS
text: – Madam President, the EU needs to tackle the climate crisis right now. The European Green Deal is a major policy tool to help us finally address inequalities across Europe through the transition to a zero-carbon continent. This is why I’m so proud of the important role that we Greens have played. The European Parliament is finally addressing the need to respect our planetary boundaries, to phase out fossil fuel subsidies, and to ensure that women are at the heart of any green deal. But the work on the green deal is far from over. As Greens, we will keep pushing the Commission to implement a genuine green deal that integrates social protections, raises environmental ambitions and, crucially, engages people on this journey through citizens’ assemblies.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, there are many positive points in the European Green Deal resolution. Paragraph 20, for example, seeks to ensure the cost of building renovations will not be borne by the most vulnerable. There are concrete measures on the circular economy and important references to microplastics and support for upskilling workers. However, I couldn’t support the resolution as a whole. Too many red lines are crossed, it completely undermines the fight for real emergency level action on both the climate and inequalities, it completely ignores Mercosur, it praises gas as a transition fuel – which is madness, it refuses to call for a new common agricultural policy (CAP) proposal and this is the CAP from the Green Deal. The CAP is doing serious damage and by spending EUR 60 billion of taxpayers’ money on subsidies that mostly fund factory farms, while family farms are being destroyed and high nature value farms are struggling to survive. It also rolls back on Parliament’s current unconditional position on 55% emission reduction by 2030, qualifying this with an impact assessment.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, while we in the European Union are better than a lot of the world’s economies in terms of dealing with climate issues, it doesn’t mean that we are good enough. I voted against the resolution because it falls pathetically short of what is actually necessary to deal with the scale of the crisis before us. For me, it represents the fact – and some of the votes on the amendments show – that we talk the talk but aren’t prepared to tackle the vested interests who are responsible for the greater scale of emissions. The rejection of the amendment which pinpointed the top 100 companies responsible for 71% of the global emissions; the fact that we celebrate a so—called Just Transition Fund, but spend multiples of that amount on a common agricultural policy (CAP) programme which subsidises bad environmental practice; the fact that we facilitate natural gas, the emissions from which are now outweighing the benefits of reduction in coal, and we spend billions on the military and arms industry, which is developing a very serious impact on our carbon footprint. The very fact that we’re here is a pathetic insult to the type of action that we need to deal with the scale of the emergency.

name: Andreas GLÜCK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We do not agree with everything that was adopted and adopted today in the resolution on the Green Deal. Nevertheless, we did not want to reject this resolution, because we, as directly elected representatives of the European Union, must be involved, particularly on issues relating to climate and environmental protection. In particular, however, we cannot understand the critical attitude in the resolution on the European trade in allowances when it comes to extending it to the vehicle sector, to transport and to buildings. In all areas organised in the CO2 allowance trade, we will achieve the intermediate targets, in all areas that are not organised in the CO2 allowance trade, we will not achieve the targets. We therefore have a very, very valuable tool here, and we believe that the trade in CO2 allowances should be extended to cover the areas of both building heat and transport.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of the European Green Agreement because it is necessary, although it lacks a clear social dimension and remains within an unsustainable and unchanged way of economic thinking. I would like to point out that without an appropriate solidarity and social dimension of the European Green Agreement, both the EU, that is to say, the European Union, and social democracy will lose the support of the people. Because if it only benefits some and divides costs among all people, it is clear that there will be a revolt by people who are very difficult to convince. However, there is still time to rectify this with a special resolution on the social dimension of the European Green Agreement.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: Madam President, we would like to reiterate here how resolutely we are committed to at the forefront of the fight for the environment. This is vital for humans and biodiversity. On the other hand, it is not possible for us to admit that all-ecology is so restrictive in national sovereign policies and that this text entrusts the European Union with exorbitant and totalitarian powers. We have seen to what extent a certain bureaucratic and ideological up-to-the-endism has underpinned the entire text. We have therefore tabled an alternative resolution to give this project of the European Green Pact a much more responsible, coherent and realistic resonance, especially in view of the hundreds of billions of euros mobilised. It is clear that many groups in this House continue to support a soft consensus which, in our view, will ultimately be very damaging to Europeans socially and economically. It is therefore in all conscience and responsibility in view of the high idea that we have of ecology that we abstained.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, 50 years ago lions, tigers and wolves were all endangered. Today lions remain under pressure, tigers have flat-lined and wolves have rebounded. Why? Because broadly speaking lions live in poor countries, tigers live in middle-income countries, and wolves live in rich countries. The best thing that can happen to the environment is market capitalism. It was Karl Marx who taught that nature was a resource to be exploited, a doctrine that found brutal realisation in the smokestack industries of the Eastern bloc. Soviet Communism turned Lake Baikal into a sewer and the Aral Sea into a desert, and poured so much oil into the Volga that ferry passengers had to be told not to throw their cigarettes overboard. Reforestation, increase in biodiversity, reintroduction of endangered species, these things are overwhelmingly happening in countries that have opened their markets to the world and have become wealthy enough to be able to afford them. The clue is in the name. If you want conservation, back the Conservatives. (Laughter)

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: – Madam President, the European Green Deal brings great things, how to clean the air, how to conserve resources, how to revitalise forests, how to retain water in the landscape. But at the same time, the resulting text is too radical, it sets unrealistic objectives, and I could not support it, because the reduction target for 2030 is absolutely unrealistic, and the resources that the European Commission promised here yesterday of EUR 1 billion a year for the entire EU from the budget are literally a ridiculous amount like 'spitting in Canada'. And the two amendments that we have tabled in support of nuclear energy, which could help this transition, for example, people who are reliing on long-distance heating, have not passed these proposals, and I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, colleagues, I have strongly voted against the so-called European Green Deal. Not just because this is the strange document of some new cult that goes confidently towards a serious psychological illness, but because of the severe hypocrisy that comes streaming from this document. How dare you vote for a green deal, having voted just a month ago for thousands of empty trucks to drive up and down Europe, burn naphtha, only to steal the business of Bulgarian carriers and other eastern carriers? What's fair: burn the naphtha or vote for the new cult? This green deal implies the destruction of coal plants in Eastern Europe. Hundreds of thousands of people will be left out of work, but at the same time the chamber does not support the preservation of the most environmentally friendly electricity generation, namely nuclear power. That is, this hall forbids coal, nuclear power, gas, and only fins and bees remain. It's insane! At the same time, all infrastructure, all production is exported to China, the European Union is deindustrialized. I don't understand it, psychologists have to talk here.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I strongly support the European Green Deal. The scale of the challenge is such that we need wholesale revolution, not just in what governments do, but it is also very important what we get citizens to do. The burden and the cost must not fall on those with the least resources or least income. We need to ensure that the populists do not exploit the fear that people have around the change, and the onus is on us to make sure that the people understand the importance not only of their work continuing, but also the sustainability of the planet. I’m pleased that, with my work in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON), I’ve been able to lead on some of these issues for the financial services sector and bring in my report on benchmarks, which address this, but I’m very pleased to have voted for this and supported this.

name: Jackie JONES
text: – Madam President, I’m strongly in support of this cross-party motion for a resolution on citizens’ rights within the withdrawal agreement, and I express my commitment to supporting and fighting for EU rights in Wales, and across the UK of course, after Brexit. A new decade may have begun, yet the old ties refuse to be broken. With good reason. The EU and UK citizens’ rights are human rights. Human rights are universal and protected not only at the EU level, but at many levels. The rule of law is a key point there. The EU has a solid record on protection of human rights. Don’t step away from this. We need the EU to step up to protect the EU and UK citizens’ rights now more than ever. Send a clear message, a resounding message, throughout Europe that this Parliament sees and hears the difficulties EU and UK citizens face without an automatic registration system. Now act to protect those rights, please.

name: Antony HOOK
text: – Madam President, three million people from the EU 27 are part of our community in the UK. They include many of our teachers, nurses, doctors and farm, care and construction workers. They are our friends and neighbours. They are some of our spouses or parents of British people. I am appalled by the bureaucratic and threatening way in which the UK Government is choosing to treat European citizens. It deeply offends British peoples’ sense of fair play. What kind of government makes people who have lived somewhere for years, contributing to society under laws that said they always could, now ask for permission to stay? What kind of government asks them to produce documents they do not have, and gets so many applications wrong that 90% of appeals succeed, and then refuses to give them a document to prove their status? It’s the government of Boris Johnson, in power on a minority vote and leading us from four years of stagnation into disaster.  (Applause)

name: Judith BUNTING
text: – Madam President, it saddened me today in Parliament that we’ve had to pass a resolution to ensure the rights of the many EU citizens in the UK and of British citizens living abroad. Whilst I welcome that we passed this resolution, these rights should never have been put at risk by the British Government because of Brexit.  The very first thing that Theresa May should ever have done was to guarantee the rights of European citizens living in Britain. It would have been a strong negotiating position and taken away years of unnecessary stress and uncertainty. Now, we have a shoddy scheme, which depends on a PDF as a proof of settlement status, rather than any physical document or card. A PDF, we all know, can be doctored easily, so employers and landlords are, justifiably perhaps, concerned about forgery, which, once again, will lead to unfair discrimination. I hope that the British Government will listen to people’s worries about this, as well as concerns passed in the resolution today.  But British citizens are also worrying about their right to stay in European countries where they have made their homes. I would like to thank those Member States who are already offering generous terms of settlement to those UK citizens who have taken residence in their country. I urge those states who have not yet declared their intentions to do so and to make their decisions known in good time.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, the resolution makes reference to the Withdrawal Agreement as a balanced document. It is not a balanced document. If it was, we would not need to be passing the separate votes that are documented today. The reality is that European Union citizens have right to be fearful because the system in the United Kingdom that the Home Office operates is institutionally racist and institutionally xenophobic. Anyone who has ever had to deal with casework on this subject will know that. It is also a mistake to end freedom of movement. It is the greatest grab back of rights to the state from the individual since 1688. UK citizens who migrated to the European continent to make their lives see their life decisions made under one regime fundamentally altered under this regime by a decision of a minority of the British population and that is a great shame. It suggests in this resolution that these matters should be addressed before the Withdrawal Agreement is voted on. I don’t believe that that will happen so my support for that agreement is unlikely.

name: Jane BROPHY
text: – Madam President, I voted for this resolution concerning the 3.2 million citizens resident in the UK from the EU and the 1.2 million UK citizens resident in the EU.  Last year, the UK Home Office suggested that people who had not applied to formalise their status by 30 June 2021 could theoretically be deported. This has generated considerable anxiety.  This resolution stresses that Europeans living in the UK need to be issued with a physical document as proof of their right to reside. Not having physical proof has left EU citizens exposed to a massive risk of future discrimination. The upcoming European Parliament decision on whether to consent to the withdrawal agreement will depend on final assurances given by the UK on citizens’ rights. Finally, I voted for this resolution because it also encourages the 27 EU Member States to adopt measures that provide legal certainty for UK citizens in the EU.

name: Barbara Ann GIBSON
text: – Madam President, I remain absolutely convinced that the decision by the UK to leave the European Union is a huge mistake. However, if we are to leave, it is absolutely essential that the rights of EU citizens are protected, both those living in the UK and UK citizens living in other countries. Today’s resolution on citizens’ rights, and the overwhelming support of the European Parliament, was a clear message to the UK Government that their current approach is simply not good enough. There is nothing to be gained by treating people as bargaining chips. I am personally heartbroken and heartbroken for our country that we will leave the EU, but I was pleased to vote for a resolution that safeguards the rights of citizens in this process.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, I voted against this resolution because, whilst I constantly have argued since the referendum in 2016 that those EU citizens who wish to live in the UK should have their rights guaranteed and criticised the Tory government for not doing so, they should be offered settled status, this motion criticises the government for the wrong reasons and says the process should be put down as declaratory, which obviously puts the burden of proof on the government, not citizens, and is ridiculous. This deprives a nationally sovereign government of having control over monitoring what happens in its own borders. I also think this motion has been politicised churlishly by including within it the idea that freedom of movement is a great tragic loss for the UK because to note this just spits in the eye of those who have explicitly voted to leave the European Union with one key issue being freedom of movement. Not wanting freedom of movement is not about being xenophobic, it is not about hostility to people from European countries moving to or working in the UK. That is divisive scaremongering. It is about control of borders. That is a key part of sovereignty and the decisions about which citizens have both full rights and full duties and many people become British citizens from European countries because they want to enjoy those rights and duties, and I welcome them as friends and allies.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I must say that I regret that the British are leaving our community. We could have been stronger, perhaps some other countries rejoice – Russia and other great powers in world politics. On the other hand, I welcomed the fact that an agreement has been reached with Britain and I consider such an exit to be a much better solution. The agreement, as the motion for a resolution says, is fair and balanced. I believe that citizens' rights in the transitional period will be covered by this agreement. As for the future, I would like to stop there. It is important to say that the agreement declares a commitment to address this future period in a fair, balanced way. Unfortunately, this is only a declaratory commitment and it is important that we remember the rights of EU citizens in the British Isles and in future periods that are not yet covered. I would like us to remember the Scots, the people of Northern Ireland, but I think that is much more complicated. In any case, it is good that an agreement has been reached and, in the light of the above, I supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, before 31 January 2020, when I will be kicked out of the EU against the democratically expressed wishes of the people in the north of Ireland who voted to remain, I want to take this opportunity to thank the MEPs who voted for this resolution today and for your steadfast support for the Good Friday Agreement and all of its parts. This resolution deals, importantly, with the rights of Irish citizens in the north of Ireland to enjoy access and exercise our EU rights where we reside. As part of last week’s Stormont deal to establish the Executive, the British Government committed to change its immigration rules. Irish citizens born in the north will now be able to exercise their EU family reunification rights, addressing the Emma DeSouza case. However, Britain did not get the name ‘Perfidious Albion’ for nothing. They still deny Emma, and all of us born in the north of Ireland, Irish citizenship. My final warning to my fellow MEPs is this: beware of Perfidious Albion, a country you cannot trust that never keeps its word. Britannia will always, always, waive the rules.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, clearly the rights of over 3 million EU citizens in the UK and over 1 million UK nationals in EU countries must be safeguarded and adequately monitored by the Commission and the proposed UK independent national authority. Obviously, those rights provided for under the Good Friday Agreement must also be safeguarded.  We should also acknowledge the threat to the rights of all EU and UK citizens by the neoliberal ideology of the EU. The EU’s cap on national borrowing, as laid out in the Stability and Growth Pact and the Fiscal Compact, is a grinding austerity policy that has completely undermined rights to education, food, health and housing, as well as rights to decent work, fair wages and social security. In Ireland, even if we had a government with the mindset to tackle our terrible housing crisis – which we don’t have at the moment, they would be hampered by the fiscal rules. Likewise, our road infrastructure has been built not by the state but by public-private partnerships (PPPs), costing twenty times the money that it would cost if the state were allowed to borrow it itself. But, sadly, the EU feeds the private sector with its policies.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, I have to say I will miss both our colleagues here from Sinn Féin, Martina, but also the colleagues from the Brexit Party. I think the place is going to be poorer for all of their absence.  But I supported this motion simply from the point of view of protecting the provisions and the citizens’ rights enshrined in the Good Friday Agreement. We’ve had our Taoiseach Leo Varadkar and Boris Johnson celebrating the resumption of the Northern Ireland Assembly and telling us that the Good Friday Agreement is now back working again. I suppose the point I want to make is that if the Good Friday Agreement is working then what that means is that all of the people of Northern Ireland have to continue to have a birth right to identify themselves to be accepted as Irish or British or both as they choose and as set out in that Good Friday Agreement. Irish people living in Northern Ireland who haven’t sought British citizenship cannot and should not have that citizenship foisted upon them.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, two—and—a—half weeks prior to Brexit, we need to examine the implementation of citizens’ rights in the UK withdrawal agreement, because there’s a sense of uncertainty for millions of EU citizens – especially for those applying for ‘settled’ status. There are many unquantified issues on how the rights of both the remaining 27 Member States in the UK and UK citizens in the EU could be applied after the withdrawal. The EU 27 citizens, for instance, should – as a matter of urgency – be provided with proof of their rights to reside in the UK after the end of the transition period, and the British Government needs to stop creating anxiety and threatening EU citizens with deportation. These announcements are not productive and only generate additional turmoil. Prime Minister Johnson wants to agree on a positive future relationship by the end of December 2020 based on an ambitious free—trade agreement, but he has to know that the level of free movement granted for EU citizens after Brexit would be a key factor in deciding the degree of future cooperation.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, after years of agonizing negotiations we voted on the European Parliament's position to protect the rights of citizens after the withdrawal of the United Kingdom. We have done so sadly, because we will miss our British Europeanist friends, but we will not miss the seats of supremacist and reactionary national politicalism that have provoked Brexit.  But the message is clear: reciprocity. The European Union will treat Britons residing in Europe depending on how the UK treats Europeans based in the UK. And I say this thinking of the British ⸻treinta thousand⸻ who reside in the Canary Islands, at the same time as the workers who in Spain cross the gate towards Gibraltar ⸻diez mil every day⸻, maintaining the dignity of work in a corner where the British flag flies. But what I care to stress is that there is still a lot of work to be done to ensure what is unclear and must be cleared: the UK's participation in free movement, asylum and shelter policy, police and judicial cooperation against crime and the guarantee of security, both British and European , in the face of threats we share.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, a lot of this debate seems to have taken place in a parallel universe, one that barely intersects with the reality of what’s happening.  I was a regular and repeated critic of Theresa May’s grudging attitude and her slowness in recognising the rights of settled EU nationals. But the system is now up and running and is working far better than the reciprocal systems of any Member State that I can think of among the 27. It’s simply not true that people are denied – there’s no mechanism to deny people status. They can be asked for more proof. But all of these urban myths that we keep hearing – some of which came to me as a constituency MEP, and when I looked into them, they turned out not to be as they first appeared – are serving to unsettle and alarm our friends and neighbours from EU Member States. When I hear my Liberal Democrat colleagues in particular demanding written forms, or physical forms of ID, when they oppose ID cards as a party, and when I hear them criticising the UK Government without a word of criticism for Member States that have failed to reciprocate, I have to wonder what their motives really are.

name: Martin HORWOOD
text: – Madam President, can I enlarge on my vote just now for this Parliament’s resolution on the British Withdrawal Agreement, including its frank criticism of the UK’s inadequate and arbitrary settled status scheme, which is already unfairly treating our EU 27 friends, neighbours, colleagues and family members in the UK. And can I pay tribute to Guy Verhofstadt, who has won many fans in the UK for his relentless focus on citizens’ rights during this process – including those of Brits in the remaining EU Member States. In paragraph 20, the resolution recognises the many UK citizens who don’t want to lose their European citizens’ rights, and calls for this lost to be mitigated. This could mean associate individual EU citizenship, which I would strongly support. If the idea of international citizens’ rights for foreign nationals seems odd, there is a successful example – and it’s Britain. We have conferred citizens’ rights on Irish citizens in Northern Ireland and across the UK, and give other citizens’ rights – including voting rights – to citizens of Malta, Cyprus and other Commonwealth countries. So it can be done, and it would prevent this unique deprivation of rights from existing European citizens.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported today's resolution, I consider today's vote to be extremely important. In doing so, we have given a clear political signal that, as part of the post-Brexit arrangements, the rights of EU citizens living in the UK are extremely important to us. It is a strong policy and, in the future, when we address their final form, it must be said that, in addition to economic cooperation and benefits, maintaining the free movement of people and, above all, citizens of EU countries living in the UK is a clear political priority. I am from the Czech Republic, 35,000 Czechs live permanently in the UK today, and for us it is a political necessity to negotiate conditions at the final stage so that these people can continue to live with dignity on uk soil. So thank you for today's appeal and I was happy to support it.

name: Matthew PATTEN
text: – Madam President, I voted against the resolution on the Withdrawal Agreement for two really basic reasons. The first is that it was hypercritical of the UK in terms of the processes that it has put in place in terms of welcoming our friends who want to settle in the UK. But, in fact, the UK is way ahead of the other 27 Member States. It’s really important that rights are reciprocated for UK citizens and this resolution didn’t reflect that. The second thing is that this resolution, in its debate and proposal in terms of freedom of movement, completely ignores the referendum that we had in 2016. The ability for the UK to control its own borders is absolutely central to Brexit, and this resolution completely fails to recognise that fact. In fact, this resolution is really just a very naked ploy to sabotage the Brexit vote that we have in Brussels at the end of this month, where the Withdrawal Agreement will be decided – its final fate decided – by you, my colleagues, the MEPs here. That’s why I voted against this resolution.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I voted for this resolution on implementing citizens’ rights in the Withdrawal Agreement. I believe it gives clarity as to what happens in transition and what happens afterwards. As we’ve already heard, there are 3.5 million EU citizens in the UK who each have their own personal stories and situations, but they have one thing in common: they want to ensure a safe future for themselves and their families.  The UK Government has done everything possible to make things difficult. It has failed to provide a system that gives them full guarantees, or physical documents that would enable them to prove their status to prospective employers or landlords. Now this is a huge concern in my constituency of the West Midlands, and this is not hearsay. I have case-work that proves some of the awful experiences that EU citizens have had, and we forget that the EU migrants contribute GBP 2 300 more to the UK Exchequer than the average adult. But what is truly shocking is that the UK Government doesn’t seem to be as concerned about the plight of 1.2 million UK citizens living in the EU as the EU is about protecting its citizens’ rights. I hope that for those who are in this position, the Labour MEPs will continue to stand up for their rights until the very end.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, we must deconstruct the mechanics that lead to human rights violations around the world and observe that neo-liberal policies can only stand up to authoritarian practices and, ultimately, to a form of violence that has been chosen as a form of government. Neo-liberalism and authoritarianism work together. This is true in the world, but it is also true in France where we see how the current power brutalizes with ferocity social movements and where we see with some form of amazement how power stifles movements that could thwart the dark neo-liberal project. Today, in France, death can be the order for peaceful demonstrators, when police violence is increasing and when it is used to maintain the order of so-called weapons of war, which are nevertheless banned in many European countries. Today, in France, the rights of litigants, trade unionists and journalists are falling back, and with them the individual freedoms enshrined in our Constitution and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. All this worries, and one wonders: principles in principles tried, values in values denied, excess of power in excess of power allowed, what France is gradually being set up?

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, the European Union is and must remain the one to promote human rights in the world. Trade interests and agreements must also involve the condition of human rights, we cannot sacrifice them to commercial interests. It is therefore important for the EU to take advantage of both sanctions and positive incentives and incentives, e.g. in the framework of development aid, and to support those governments that seek to promote human rights in their countries. However, I am very disappointed that an amendment has not been adopted which talks about the situation of Christians, who represent the vast majority of religious groups facing discrimination, violence and death, and a call for their protection has not been accepted. I really do not know how serious the European Parliament is about protecting human rights when freedom of religion is one of the main human rights. And this proposal was rejected, which is why I voted against the motion for a resolution in the end.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, human rights are supposed to be universal and indivisible. They’re not supposed to be instrumentalised. But that’s exactly what we have in the European Union: instrumentalising human rights to advance foreign policy issues; to give out about the countries we don’t like – or, more particularly, the ones that the United States don’t like.  This was summed up graphically by the brazen illegal extradition assassination of Major General Qasem Soleimani and former parliamentarian Iraqi General Abu Omar Mahdi al—Mohandes, and the absolute silence of the European Union in the face of that made me ashamed that we would have the audacity to talk about human rights anywhere else. These were army officers with a record against ISIS, executed in the sovereign territory of Iraq, in a civilian airport in which I have been.  Can you imagine what we would have been saying if the United States’ Chief of Staff had been assassinated in Heathrow Airport by the Russians? I can tell you: we’d have been saying quite a lot, and this is the problem with this report. We talk to talk, we condemn the people we don’t like, and we say nothing about human rights violations at home. As my colleague said, the violent brutality of the French state against innocent protesters, and the irony that we talk about democracy while our Catalan colleagues are sitting in jail rather than taking their seats here with us. It is an absolute disgrace, which is why I voted against it.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Madam President, I also do not support the persistent willingness of the European Union to teach all the others how to behave in the field of human rights. We will have the right to be a teacher only when becoming champions, not self—declared human-rights defenders. But nevertheless, I voted in favour of this resolution by reason of just one paragraph: very important and mentioning that the problem of mass statelessness must be solved by 2024, not only outside but also within the European Union. And mass statelessness is a huge problem for my country, Latvia: every tenth resident of Latvia is stateless, deprived of a number of rights, including the right to vote in local elections (we recommend this for those who will stay in the UK and in the European Union after Brexit). These people were declared to be stateless just by reason of origin, despite the fact that the majority of them are local natives. By the way, in this resolution, the reason for discrimination by origin is not mentioned, and it is a shame.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this report. Personally, I consider the human rights agenda to be an important EU agenda. And I think it is a good thing that we are not only doing it on the territory of the EU Member States, but we are spreading it everywhere in the world. I supported the report, but I have one comment on it. If it is not to remain just an empty document, in words on paper, it is good that the European Commission should draw on this report and reflect the conclusions of this report in its day-to-day foreign policy. And I am very inclined to really take into account the human rights situation in that country for those countries to which we provide certain benefits, benefits, economic assistance. Because if we provide economic support and assistance across the board to those countries that are simply knowingly and flagrantly violating human rights, then the reports we are writing here make no sense and remain only on paper.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I supported this report, I think it is right that the European Union should build its defence and foreign policy in relation to multilateralism, in relation to NATO, which is undoubtedly our main security guarantor. NATO will continue to play a major role, with most Member States being part of NATO. I had some reservations about the part about the role of the European Parliament, which should strengthen its role as the third pillar of this policy. I believe that we should respect the leading role of the Member States and the Council in this area, let us say. However, it is good that the European Parliament has accepted this position on defence policy.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, thank you for the word and for the possibility that I can explain my position on the annual report, which I could not support. On the one hand, the report very aptly describes the threats and challenges that the European Union and its Member States must face. Whether it is, for example, the assertive behavior of Russian politicians towards their neighbors, hybrid threats or cyberattacks. However, as tensions rise in the Middle East, I would like to warn against erasing the clear line between who is evil and who is good. Who is the originator of the conflict and who is merely responding to it. Who aims to destroy other states and who, on the contrary, only wants to survive and prosper. In this respect, the EU should change its policy in the Middle East. It should clearly name Iran's current leadership as the greatest threat and, conversely, Israel as our partner. It should help the citizens of Iran who want change, and unfortunately I miss that here.

name: Guido REIL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I voted against the report because I am fundamentally opposed to the accession of the Western Balkans to the EU. The accession of Romania and Bulgaria to the EU and the resulting freedom of movement have already had devastating consequences for my home in the Ruhr area. This freedom of movement has brought us crime, prostitution, undeclared work and social fraud. It is precisely this social fraud and these degenerate social costs for the cities of the Ruhr region, which are completely bankrupt, that are devastating. This is not just what I say, as the SPD mayors of Duisburg, Gelsenkirchen and Dortmund say. What we need is less freedom of movement, not more freedom of movement.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the topical debate on the distortion of European history and the reliance on the Second World War (2019/3016(RSP)). I would like to inform Members that there will be no request for intervention in this debate, nor will the blue card issues be accepted.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: representative of PPE Group. – Madam President, this debate is not about history. It’s about our future, because neglecting historical facts means ignoring the future. More than 40 million deaths in World War II remind us ‘never again’. To start this war was the most terrible crime in history. Nazi Germany started the war and caused terrible crimes against humanity. Every German politician has to assume the responsibility of our country. But every politician, inside and outside of Europe, also has the responsibility not to play with history. I cannot – and we, as the EPP – cannot accept Putin’s attempt to rewrite history.  To be clear, the Soviet Union was attacked by Nazi Germany. Russia suffered tremendously during World War II, but to be clear, the Hitler—Stalin Pact was an agreement between two devils, two terrible dictators. The Hitler—Stalin Pact was the beginning of a raid on several European countries: Poland, Finland, Estonia, Lithuania, Latvia and Romania. The Hitler—Stalin Pact meant, for millions of European citizens in large parts of Europe, decades of oppression, fear, suffering and dictatorship. The Hitler—Stalin Pact was a crime against peace, freedom and democracy. More than 80 years after this Treaty, we, as the European Parliament, clearly say ‘never again’. Today’s EU and today’s NATO are the children of liberty, democracy and freedom for Central and Eastern Europe. We stand as one for solidarity in Europe. We remember history to safeguard our common future.  (Applause)

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for this opportunity to discuss an important topic indeed. I have heard and I acknowledge the concerns voiced by Mr Weber, and I’m aware of the statement referred to and of the reaction by the Polish authorities. I would like to use this opportunity to express my sympathy for all World War II victims. It is important to remember Europe’s past if we want to build its future. The topic of today’s discussion thus prompts a reflection on how Europe can learn from history and especially from one of its darkest chapters. As highlighted also by the European Parliament’s resolution of September last year, the authoritarian and totalitarian regimes which emerged across Europe in the last century remain a dark chapter in our continent’s history. The Second World War led to unprecedented levels of human suffering, both for the militaries and for civilian populations. Ten of millions of victims were deported, tortured, murdered under totalitarian regimes in Europe. Remembrance of the wars that ravaged Europe and its people should always prevent us from overlooking these horrors. For this reason, it is essential to find ways to strengthen our common values and the general principles on which the European Union is founded: respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. Fortunately, most of the younger generations in Europe have not suffered under totalitarian regimes. Yet there is now a risk that we are taking these common values and principles for granted. Europe’s tragic past should continue to serve as moral and political inspiration to face the challenges of today’s world. The common values that have enabled the longest period of peace in Europe must remain a cornerstone of our democratic society and need to be safely guarded and constantly nurtured. The experience of the two world wars taught us not to focus on differences but to create a common space to live, study and work. Most European societies have been learning over several generations the value of inclusiveness and tolerance. Despite these positive developments, Europe, unfortunately, did witness war, conflict and destruction in the 1990s, and here I speak of my home country’s direct experience, still quite fresh in our memory. However, this is an additional reason why we should all deeply respect the peace and security that the EU project has brought to our continent and why we should continue promoting its achievements outside its borders. Today our societies are facing different kinds of challenges: xenophobia, nationalism, populism, disinformation or violent radicalisation, just to name a few. These very complex issues cannot be solved with simplistic, quick-fix solutions. The Union must be vigilant and ready to fight propaganda which promises such solutions. Not only can these promises never be fulfilled, they also discredit our democratic institutions and authorities. They seek to divide our societies into us and them, friends and enemies. This undermines democratic and open political debate. Radicalisation and violent extremism gain ground. We all need to step up our efforts to prevent intolerance, racism and xenophobia. Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to conclude by stressing that our societies need to remember their own history in order to learn from the past and not repeat the mistakes for which they might have been responsible.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank you and the honourable members for this debate. Our collective history and how we commemorate and share it is fundamentally important for Europe’s present and future. As the now—famous quotation goes ‘everyone is entitled to his own opinion, but not his own facts’. The Commission’s role here is to talk about the facts. The European Commission fully rejects any false claims that attempt to distort the history of the Second World War or paint the victims, like Poland, as perpetrators. The Commission will not tolerate these attacks on Poland and stands in full solidarity with Poland and the Polish people.  The EU evolved out of the ashes of the Second World War and the holocaust and, in the context of the Cold War, these memories are the foundation of the European project and our responsibility for the future. These historical facts are not open for debate. The Hitler-Stalin Pact, signed by the Foreign Ministers of Nazi Germany, Ribbentrop, and the Soviet Union, Molotov, on 23 August 1939, paved the way for the Second World War. The Nazi-Soviet alliance enabled the attack on Poland by Nazi Germany on 1 September 1939 and, subsequently, Soviet troops on 17 September. These events marked the beginning of the Second World War and these are the facts.  We also must recall the occupation of the Baltic countries and Bessarabia, events hard to imagine without the existence of the treaty dividing the continent by a zone of influence of the evil regimes. We must highlight the horrors committed by both regimes without equating them – in particular, the unimaginable tragedy of the organised genocide by Nazi Germany, the holocaust, which consumed the lives of millions of Jews, and other atrocities that cost the lives of millions of Poles, Roma and many other nationalities.  Yes, history is complicated and we cannot forget about the role that the Soviet soldiers played in the crucial part of the war when Stalin and Hitler became enemies. It is a fact that Soviet soldiers were first to push out the German soldiers from Central and Eastern Europe after immense sacrifices by the peoples of the Soviet Union. It is a fact that they played a key role in liberating the Nazi concentration camp in occupied Poland, Auschwitz-Birkenau. We will commemorate the 75th anniversary of this event on 27 January.  Even after the war, many people from Central and Eastern Europe continued for decades to suffer under the totalitarian rule of communist regimes, regimes that were often installed without support and against the will of the local population. The European Union has established 23 August as the official day of the memory of the millions of victims of totalitarian regimes. The Commission is committed to contributing, in line with its responsibilities, to the promotion of the memory of crimes committed by totalitarian regimes in Europe and the Commission encourages the Member States to consider the possibility of adhering to this Europe-wide day in the light of their own history.  It is our duty to preserve the names of the millions persecuted and keep their memories alive and also to study diligently the root causes and behaviour of the totalitarian regimes, especially because today, 81 years after the opening of this dark chapter in European history, our common values of human dignity, fundamental rights, rule of law and democracy are challenged again by extremists, nationalists and divisive rhetoric and actions.  We have to recognise those facts to understand our own history and build a better future. The dream of the European Union was formed right after the war, with the clear aim to create new, strong foundations for long-lasting peace in Europe. This is why it is important for Europe to be very clear on these matters. Distortion of historical facts is a threat to our democratic societies and must be challenged wherever possible. Organised and targeted dissemination of distortions and disinformation is something we have to oppose and reject. I myself will work under my mission to strengthen the European democracy to allow us to live in freedom from these threats. Honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, I look forward to the debate.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – Dear sitting leader! On 8 May this year, Europe will celebrate the seventy-fifth anniversary of the end of the Second World War. This victory was forth by allies the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.  The Kremlin would very much like to capture this victory as its own, but it is disturbed by the truth that in 1939 the USSR agreed with Nazi Germany on the redistribud of Europe, which freed the hands of Hitler to attack Poland, conquer Western Europe, leaving Britain alone to fight the aggressor.  In fact, from 1 September 1939 to 22 June 1941, Stalin was an ally of Hitler, making the Soviet Union complice in the triggering of the Second World War. And Putin's attempts to misrepresent these historical facts cannot be erased from history, just as the victims, suffering and misery of the war-torn nations cannot be erased from history. That is what we must always remember in Europe. Thank you.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I take up a sentence from you, Mrs Jourova: 'Nobody has the right to their own facts', and after all that we have already heard, I would like to underline this sentence twice. I would like to take this opportunity to remind you why we are sitting here. The nucleus of the European Union, the beginning of cooperation between the peoples of Europe, was the ECSC Treaty. In its preamble, we can still read that this Treaty, which was essentially nothing more than the establishment of a free trade area for coal and steel, was concluded by the parties with the firm conviction that action and cooperation with each other and the establishment of common institutions are peace-promoting. We can see how successful this model is by the fact that we are not just talking about coal and steel here, but about much more. However, if we want to prevent the right to our own facts, we need European public opinion. You cannot decide on that, you have to do something about it. By defending freedom of the media, when newspapers are banned, when journalists are threatened or killed, or when public service broadcasting is also threatened in the states where it exists, then we, as democratic politicians, must speak up and resist these beginnings.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, the management of the past is always a very delicate matter. It may seem delicate, it is often laborious, but in any case it is indispensable. And I believe that Jean Kahn, who was the originator of the European Observatory for Racist and Xenophobic Phenomena, could have told us a word. Unfortunately, he left us in the meantime. He had been in charge of taking stock of all the aberrations that are still contained in the history textbooks today - it was rather the late 90s - and one of the biggest aberrations was a quote in an Austrian history textbook claiming that Austria had been the first victim of the Third Reich: a bedtime story. This is what happens when you do not deal with the issues of the past and when you do not have the courage to address them. Indeed, many participate in misinformation and distort historical realities, either by ignoring irrefutable historical evidence, or by refusing to refer to it or by failing to name them. The second case is even worse than the first. We could still find exeumental circumstances to explain the stupidity, but bad faith is unacceptable. What can we do about the deniers? What can we oppose the murderers of memory, as Pierre Vidal-Naquet calls them? I believe that we can do one thing, even if it will have no immediate effect: since the witnesses and survivors have almost all left us, we will have to replace the duty of remembrance with a duty of history. And I would like, in closing, to cite an example from which we must draw inspiration: the Federal Republic of Germany, the version of the former Bundeslanders, had the courage to face its past, and this Federal Republic of Germany has done so courageously, without covering anything in the history textbooks and in the public media. This was not the case in the new Bundeslanders. If you look at the afD's results today, I believe that the efforts invested in learning history are not in vain.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I want to thank Commissioner Jourová for having Poland’s back in this public discussion. Recently, we have been having an increasing number of historical debates, and it’s not easy dealing with these topics. It’s not our role and it’s not our responsibility to exonerate anybody from their historical record. Historical truth is not at the disposal of the powerful, nor at the disposal even of parliamentary majorities, but we must defend the facts as we best know them. That also applies to Soviet aggression, to Soviet suffering and to the role of appeasement in the run—up to the Second World War. But when a victim is being turned into the perpetrator of a crime, we have to speak up, and if a wolf cries wolf, we should call it out.  I believe that these kinds of conversations are rarely just about the past. Shifting historical blame can easily be a first step in the direction of identifying a target for more than just rhetorical aggression. Europe should beware.

name: Alessandro PANZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, there are many historical distortions in Europe over the Second World War. Premise: my intervention is not against the Resistance in Italy, on the contrary, we do not want to demonize, but it is necessary to make some clarifications. In Italy there was not a single group of partisans fighting against the fascist regime but there were communist, socialist, Catholic, conservative and republican groups. Yet, despite this, there seems to be a well-established and distorted narrative in my country that only one team has been the author of the fight against Nazi fascism. In the wake of this, some associations, even financed with public money, instead of explaining history in detail and objectively, do not miss an opportunity to side politically with the left, in this case in Italy. During the Civil War, which took place between '43 and '45, heinous crimes were committed by both sides. But on those committed by the fascists there is wide and fair emphasis, on those committed by the partisans it is as if a manhood of impunity and forgetfulness had fallen. Take, for example, the story of Rolando Rivi, a 14-year-old seminarian murdered by partisans, or the more than 2 600 women raped and murdered without a fair trial, on the sole pretext of being friends of fascists. Yet today it is easier to hide behind any 'Beautiful Hello', as some Members of this House have unknokno faredly, when we know, as you know, that 'Bella Ciao' was not the partisans' ion. I will end, Mr President, by quoting a great Italian left-wing journalist who disappeared a few days ago: 'Everyone knows these things or has heard them say and no one dares to bring them back and tell them for fear of being pointed out as a fascist'. Thank you for your intellectual honesty, Giampaolo Pansa.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: To some extent, however, I must now point out the length of the speeches and perhaps once again the fact that these topical and event debates do not generally accept blue card questions or give off-the-list speeches. It is not a question of this subject, but of the fact that this is a topical debate.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I wholeheartedly thank all of you for adopting the September resolution on common remembrance, which is a very balanced and factual one. Since the very beginning, both parties to the Hitler—Stalin Pact used lies, smear campaigns and cheating to discredit their opponents and victims. Well after advancing the holocaust, Hitler accused Jews of waging the Second World War. Months after committing a war crime on more than 20 000 Polish members of the elite in Katyn and elsewhere, Stalin informed Polish Generals Sikorski and Anders that they had been released and had escaped to Manchuria. Later, during the negotiations for ending the Second World War in Potsdam, there was yet another war crime perpetrated against Poles and Lithuanians: the so—called Augustów roundup. Unfortunately, in his smear campaign against Poland and other countries, President Putin uses exactly the same methods as both parties to the Hitler—Stalin Pact. Moreover, he is engaged in glorifying Stalin’s activity and using it as contemporary policy. We have to raise this issue.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Madam President, The Second World War was humanity's greatest failure. The collapse on the New York Stock Exchange not only meant problems for banks and factory workers, but also plunged tens of millions of people into poverty and hunger, grabbing every straw that would give them hope for a better life. Unfortunately, in Europe it was fascism and Nazism. While fascists in Italy and Spain and the Nazis in Berlin cheered their bloodthirsty dictators, Czechoslovakia was betrayed in Munich by its own allies. Europe failed – it watched the violations of the agreements, did not help the anti-fascists in Spain, and sold Czechoslovakia to the Nazis. The penalties for these failures were, for example, Auschwitz, Dachau, Terezín, Lidice. Millions dead and a continent destroyed.  Lately, it's fashionable to confuse causes and consequences. Let's not take this fashion wave and re-write history accordingly. Let us respect those who have fallen so that we may live here today. A criminal must remain a criminal and a liberator a liberator.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, we understand your concern, because, despite the anti-communist decisions of the European Parliament, the campaign of lies, the meddd of history, the provocative equation of communism with the monster of fascism, and the billions of euros for youth care programmes, you have not been able to rewrite history. For this reason, you have been holding the anti-communist machine for months in high turns: with the despicable anti-communist resolution of September 2019 and with successive anti-communist debates in every plenary. Anti-communism is in the DNA of the European Union. The people know this and see it as the result of this policy: the weakening of fascist and criminal groups, including the Nazi Golden Dawn in Greece, the prohibitions of communist parties in European Union countries, such as Poland and the Baltic countries, the restriction of the action of the communists, the restriction of their participation in the elections, the persecution of militants, the removal of historical monuments. You're not going to make it! As much as you strive to baptize the day of anti-fascist victory on a Day of Europe, the truth will shine! Because this year marks seventy-five years since the end of the Second World War, when Hitler fascism was crushed by the struggle of the peoples, led by the Communists, the Soviet Union and the Red Army. The future of the peoples is incompatible with capitalist exploitation, poverty, war and refugees. Socialism is the future!

name: Andrzej HALICKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I'm Polish. As the initiator of this debate, I would like to thank Parliament and all political factions very warmly on behalf of the Polish public for their solidarity, because we really need this solidarity. I would like to thank the European Council and the Commissioner for their very clear and strong voice, because we must be together when attempts are made to fals up history, because there is no agreement on this. But this is not a debate about history, it is a debate about the European Union, about our community, about security, because those politicians who accept want totalitarianism, be it Stalinism or Nazism, want to build authoritarian governments themselves and use their power in the same way to lose millions, because so many victims have brought these conges in the last century to Europeans.  A politician who disregards history and who accepts totalitarianism cannot call himself a European, and we must stand together in solidarity and give strong resistance and a strong voice against such tendencies.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab When, 30 years ago, the Congress of People's Deputies of the Soviet Union condemned the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact – a pact that Stalin described in a telegram to Ribbentrop as a "blood-cemented friendship between the two countries" – it seemed that this chapter of history was closed. Today, there is an attempt to revise those assessments, including the falsion of historical truth with regard to Polish. My country's participation in the fight against Hitler cannot be questioned. Poles in no sense cooperated with The Germans, fought with them on all fronts, organized a strong resistance movement and underground administration. They also suffered the greatest losses. The recent insinuations from Moscow that concentration camps in Poland were being built not accidentally, but because the social climate was conducive to this, are an outrageous manifestation of bad will and arrogance. Before the war, Poland had the largest Jewish community in Europe, and this fact was decisive for the Third Reich. It was he who caused the numerous German Nazi death camps to be built here.  The emerging attempts to fals up the history and memory of World War II require strong opposition.

name: Nicola BEER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has As Vice-President, I am responsible for the House of European History. Places like this are becoming increasingly important at a time when the lessons of history are not only forgotten but distorted, and malicious historical cliffs are not only commonplace in Internet forums. That is why, in commemoration of the Second World War, I would like to draw your attention to an issue that is very close to my heart: anti-Semitism. A distorted depiction of Jewish history only made possible the persecution and cruel murder of six million Jews. Today, 75 years later, such distortions find their way back into our society in the form of conspiracy theories. With the boycott of Jewish goods, the BDS movement is reminiscent of the "Don't buy from Jews" signs. Jewish citizens are once again being disused with caricatures, The history of Israel is being distorted, its right to exist is being denied – or the unilateral voting behavior at the United Nations, where anti-Semitism of authoritarian states is regularly played into the hands of authoritarian states. We also need training to recognise camouflated anti-Semitism. This teaches us the actions of civil servants, especially judges in the Second World War. Let us therefore, together as Parliament, as the Commission and the Council, enforce the application of the code of conduct to combat illegal hate speech on the Internet and the definition of anti-Semitism by the International Alliance for Holocaust Remembrance!

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Anyone who knows a bit about history knows that Putin's statements were historically wrong and that Poles have every right to be outraged by it. However, I do not think that this is a debate that belongs here. This is a debate for historians and feuilletonists. It is not a debate for politicians, many of whom, especially among the Greens and the left, who are unfortunately not here today, have not even successfully completed their history studies. Politicians are elected – and I see a lot of people up there who probably don't want history to be debated here – politicians are elected to shape the future, not to discuss the past, even if that is always interesting, of course.  Nor should we react, like the Pavlovian dog, to any provocation by Putin, and we should start debates here in the European Parliament on his statements. As I said, I understand the outrage of the Poles, but the European Parliament is the wrong forum for such historical debates.

name: Dace MELBĀRDE
text: – Dear sitting leader! Commissioner, colleagues, i would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work. After my education, I am a historian, so I am happy to continue this debate. On 13 October last year, the Kremlin announced the seventy-fifth anniversary of the liberation of Riga by the Kremlin with a salutation, ignoring the fact that 13 October was a fictional date, because there were no real battles in Riga with the German army, in fact the Red Army re-occupied Latvia.  The great heroic of the Patriotic War also conceals the cooperation of Stalin- Hitler, the USSR and Nazi Germany during the first 22 months of war and the destruction of the statehood of Poland, the Baltic States, followed by mass deportations, instead of recognising and condemning the USSR's co-responsibility for the cause of the war and the destruction of independent states.  Highlighting unpleasant historical facts for the Kremlin, such as a video produced in 2017 by NATO on the resistance of national guerrillas to the Soviet regime in the Baltics, is described as Western support for the nazi revival. Colleagues, the remembrance of the Second World War is based on a professional, objective assessment of history, bringing to the fore the honour of the victims of war and totalitarianism, rather than the glorification of war and violence!

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her "Never again fascism, never again war!" That was the oath of Buchenwald. We on the left are committed to this. But racists and fascists who threaten lives, sabre-rattling, rearmament and war are once again a bitter reality. From our human history we know about the force of fascism, about the brutality of a world war and about the importance of anti-fascist resistance. In September last year, however, the majority in this House thought they could equate Hitler's Germany with the Soviet Union. Anyone who serves this history-climbing, branding every political alternative to capitalism with the theory of totalitarianism, has actually learned nothing, but nothing at all from history. He will learn nothing from history and make the same mistakes over and over again. No, ladies and gentlemen, the honorable struggle of the Red Army has freed us from the darkest of stories. Those who do not know history cannot shape their future. I would like to thank the Red Army, i would like to thank the resistance fighters, and I would like to thank all the allied allies who have enabled us to have our free future today.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: – Madam President, the European project born after World War II, of which we are the heirs and which we have a responsibility to continue to push, began to walk because previously liberal democracies had won over totalitarian regimes in that horrible war. The European project was built on the defeat of Nazism and fascism. It is impossible to understand the European project outside the values of democracy, the rule of law and human rights which those regimes systematically violated.  Spain, on the other hand, has not built its democracy on the defeat of Francoism. The dictator died in bed and his cultural heritage is still very much alive today. Too alive. The Spanish transition did not have much to do with the rupture that countries like Germany or Italy did in the 1940s or Portugal in the 1970s, which are now settled democracies and which did break with their previous totalitarian regimes. And understanding this is essential to understand the deep roots of the authoritarian drift in which the Spanish State is today embarked. Today Spanish nationalism believes that to defend the unity of Spain it is justified to run over fundamental rights. And the judicial dome is a very good example of that. It is a nationalism heir, to a large extent, to Franco's nationalism, which is the kind of nationalism against which the European Union has been built.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, the lord who preceded me in the use of the word is persecuted in Spain by judges for stealing, stealing public money. And yet it can be expressed freely in this Parliament. Do you think Spain is an authoritarian country if a person who has stolen ⸻and is pursued by judges for stealing⸻ speaks freely in this Parliament? More freedom, it's impossible. This year we're going to celebrate the 75th anniversary of many things. Among other things, the end of World War II. But World War II did not end in the year 45. World War II ended when the Berlin Wall fell, when the Red Army withdrew from Eastern European countries, when we defeated fascism, nationalism, and, yes, communism.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on the subject of memory in this parliamentary term, the European Parliament has not proved itself well. In September, against the will of my group, it was decided, however, to bring to the vote a resolution which ended up being perceived by our citizens beyond the text, not as a condemnation of totalitarianism but as an equalisation of Nazism with the extremely varied historical experience, including in Europe, of social communist thought and policy. Although the media have made the text confusing but basically harmless in terms of consequences, many have felt equally offended. I apologise to them, because this institution has failed to give a message of shared memory. Leaving history to historians, I say that we must start from what has truly united the European Parliament on these issues, with clarity. On 25 October 2018, we clearly called on the Member States to ban neo-fascist and neo-Nazi organisations, which are still proud of dictatorship and our past. It is time to do so, and I want to say to Mr Panza of the League that "Bella Ciao" is the song of the Resistance, not only in Italy. Our Europe was born out of the resistance and sacrifice that he has denigrated here today.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: I will say this in English because you might listen to me. You spoke so fast that the interpreters could not follow you, so I’m very sorry. Next time, a little bit slower, please. Thank you anyway.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: – Madam President, Russia's attempts to rewrite history are indeed nothing new, and it is unfortunately a very common part of Putin's propaganda: not only in relation to the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact, but also, for example, in 1968. Nevertheless, as the European Union and as the European Parliament, we cannot go through this Putin attempt to go through silence. We must reiterate once again and clearly the historical fact that the cynical cooperation of the two totalitarian regimes has led to disproportionate horrors, suffering not only in Poland, but also in other occupied states. Out of respect for the victims, we cannot remain silent and must stand in solidarity with Poland and other states, because this is our common history. The European integration project is a historic response to the cynicism and suffering that this pact is symbolic of. If today we allow Putin's propaganda to challenge this critical point in our common history, it will be the beginning of the end of our project.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is right: no to the distortions of history. No to the distortions of the present, however. People wonder what this very expensive Europe has changed since the Second World War to the present day, 2020. Unfortunately, the answer is nothing, nothing has been changed: in the Second World War there were wars with missiles, with tanks, and there were precisely conflicts between the European Member States. In 2020 there are economic wars, trade wars and conflicts between European states. Continuous conflicts are there today, continuous conflicts were there before. We also see this on the dramatic scenario of Libya: Italy's position on the one hand, France's position on the other, and the non-existent Europe that shifts its gaze to the war in Libya. If avoiding wars for Europe and for the European project is to look away, it is certainly not the right way forward. Conflict over food labelling, conflict over daylight saving time. However, the enlightening President Sassoli has finally arrived, who will remove the conflicts of the Member States by removing the flags of the founding countries of this Europe from the benches of this Parliament. I would like to remind the President who pays for this bandwagon: it is the people of Europe and they are the countries of this Europe.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have a point of order: would it be permissible for Parliament to call a spinner a speaker who says that nothing has changed between the Second World War and today?

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The blue card speeches will not be granted in this debate. Was this a point of order or was this a blue card? Unfortunately, that is the end of the world.

name: Izabela-Helena KLOC
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for President Vladimir Putin's recent attempts to re-write the history of the Second World War come as no surprise. However, we must remain vigilant. Poland, together with other central and eastern European countries, is a witness and victim of Nazism and communism. The alliance of these dictatorial systems has caused tens of millions of casualties and material losses on an unimaginable scale, and we will continue to remind all our friends in Europe that a free, peaceful and prosperous European Union is only possible through liberated states, first from the black and later from the red plague. Flirting with these ideologies can have unforeseen disastrous consequences. Every enthusiast of President Putin must keep this in mind. Rapprochement is possible only if freedom and truth are mutually appreciated. Otherwise, every Putin enthusiast will fall into the same old red tsar trap as many generations of thinkers and politicians. The foundation of mutual relations must not be the historical policy currently being conducted by the Russian President. It requires full condemnation.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, the strategy of the right is clear. Mobilising the majority in the European Parliament, it tries to promote anti-communism by rewriting history by spreading the most reactionary designs and forgeries. But history is not rewritten and the truth does not change. There is no lie here that can be shouted here to hide the collusion of the great German monopolies with Hitler or the conniving responsibilities of the great capitalist powers, such as the United Kingdom or France, which paved the way for the beginning of World War II. There is no lie here that they will erase the hard-hitting and decisive role of the Communists and the Soviet Union in the defeat of Nazi-fascism, at the immense costs, human and material, for the Soviet Union, which no other country has endured. A smokescreen that escapes the debate on how European Union policies promote setbacks of a civilizational dimension, attacking social and labour rights, national sovereignty and democracy, and which are, as in the past, at the root of the resurgence of far-right and fascist forces.

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: – Madam President, today’s issue is not about our understanding of history. We know very well our history and the tragedies of our history which were brought about also by Stalin. Today, we are having this debate because we were very much surprised by the recent performance of Mr Putin, by his Soviet-type propaganda attack on real history, by his strange attempts to convince everyone that Poland was guilty by itself, that Hitler and Stalin divided her and occupied her. Today we’re standing together for the defence of the true history of Europe and we are standing together with Poland against this Kremlin propaganda attack. I will end with a very simple statement. Mr Putin, you will not succeed in your attempts to divide Europe on the history issue. We are standing for the truth because truth makes you free, and that is the strength of Europe. We would like to wish the same sense of real truth and freedom upon the ordinary Russian people. The history lesson is very simple: the truth, in the end, wins. It will win also in Russia – I hope soon.

name: Massimiliano SMERIGLIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Second World War was unleashed by the National Socialists in order to establish in Europe and throughout the world a racial and anti-Semitic dictatorship, dedicated to the Shoah, that is to say, to the final solution, the disappearance of ethnic groups, religions and political ideas considered to be enemies. Against this danger, different forces have coalesced and, by coalescing, they have won, they have defeated the Nazi demon. It is never wise to compare and build similarities between different historical events and to do so for political calculations. Rather, learning from history means grasping the degenerative elements, the cultural humus that led to the Holocaust, capturing them in the present, and today the common sense fueled by far-right forces is steeped in racism and anti-Semitism. Our democracy must today fight against the danger of a new fascism. We should devote this debate to the millions of people tortured and killed at Auschwitz because it is there, among those crematoriums, that the historic necessity of the European Union was born, against the nationalism and racism that are demons of our Europe.

name: Cristian GHINEA
text: – Madam President, I come from Romania, a country that suffered both from fascism and communism, and let me not thank the Red Army, as my colleague Demirel from the Left Group said earlier.
