I don't thank the Red Army. The Red Army overtook, did not liberate Romania, the Red Army killed and raped people in Romania.  This Parliament has voted on a resolution indicating the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact as one of the causes of the outbreak of war. That's right, this pact allowed the Nazi regime to invade Poland and start the war. Part of Romania's territory was at the same time invaded by the Red Army. That was an age of the sins, which we have to part with. Germany disavowed the Nazi regime, Mr Putin praises the communist regime. That's why Mr. Putin is a jerk. I declare my solidarity with Poland in the face of this new rhetorical aggression.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, the current majority of the European Parliament is anti-Russian. In its desire to attack Russia by all means, it gave in to the temptation to rewrite the history of the Second World War in the resolution it voted on 19 September 2019. In it, she writes that "the Second World War was triggered as an immediate consequence of the infamous German-Soviet non-aggression pact Molotov-Ribbentrop." Of course, this pact did exist. It illustrates the crimes committed by the USSR throughout its history and which must be denounced. I myself paid tribute to the 80,000 Estonians who were victims of communism in Tallinn. But to say that this pact was the main cause of the Second World War is a distortion of history that I refuse to accept. Leave it to historians to write history, ladies and gentlemen, this story that will judge your attempt at manipulation harshly.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, of course, my sympathies are with Poland and the Polish people. Poland was occupied by two hostile forces and was divided. The Polish people, their true patriots and patriots, fought their "Craiova Army" to defend Polish independence and their homeland, and they should be congratulated. But when we speak, dear colleagues, about the facts of World War II, we must not silence the crimes of the Bolshevik regimes. And I will remind you of some of them, because they are silenced by the people on the left side of the hall, who still wave the flags with the red five-pointed. Let me remind you of the Bulgarian motor ship Struma, with 767 Jewish Bulgarian sailors on board, sunk by a Soviet submarine in the Black Sea. Let me remind you, by the way, that Bulgaria is the only country that saved its Jews during The Second World War. Let me remind you of the Macedonian Bloody Christmas, when Tyto's criminal Bolshevi regime killed 25,000 Bulgarians without trial and conviction and displaced another 130,000 Bulgarians, waving the red flag with the five-pointed flag. These crimes must be reminded, reprimanded and convicted. Eternal glory of the Bulgarian heroes in Macedonia, shame and disgrace for their murderers!

name: Niyazi KIZILYÜREK
text: – Madam President, if our aim is to learn from the past, the first thing to recall is that nationalism, irredentism, racism and fascism mean war. Adolf Hitler pursued his war policies with these ideological tools. The great historian, Eric Hobsbawm, is accurate when he says that the real reasons for the Second World War are two words: ‘Adolf’ and ‘Hitler’. Unfortunately, some are referring to the Molotov—Ribbentrop Pact as the main reason for this war and forget that almost all nations were involved in appeasement policy. Distortion of history only condemns us to repeat our past mistakes. For a perpetual peace, we have to learn from our own misdoings, look critically into our own history and struggle against nationalism, racism and anti—Semitism.  The construction of a common European identity should not be based on otherisation of any kind. We cannot demonise others in order to construct our own identity. What we need is to struggle against nationalism, and we need to be self-aware about our own dark pages.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Voices from both the far left and the far right show that this debate, initiated by members of the Civic Platform and the Polish People's Party, is very necessary. I, unlike some of my colleagues, am surprised that President Putin changed his mind, because when he paid tribute to Poland as the first country invaded by Hitler on Westerplatte, he did not say anything like that. When he paid tribute to the murdered Polish war time in 2010, he did not blame Polish. And I would remind you that Adolf Hitler also believed that it was Poland that started the war with the Gliwice provocation, which was clearly operation Abwehr. I therefore ask the Russian President if he really wants to speak with one voice with the then German Chancellor. It's a bad idea. I think he should get off that path.

name: Juozas OLEKAS
text: – Dear President, I am Lithuanian, I am left, but I am also born in the deportation lager. That is why I am pleased today, as both the left and the right say they know the crimes of fascism. We Lithuanians condemn because we have also donated almost 200 000 Jews to our citizens, but Stalin, the Communists of Stalin, had already exiled several tens of thousands of our citizens from Lithuania before the Nazis entered Lithuania, and after the war they exiled several hundred more and killed them. Therefore, when it comes to one authoritarian regime that kills people, we must not forget another. And if we want to build a democratic Europe, then we need to talk about it. And it seems very important to me to those of our colleagues here in the European Parliament who do not know this, so that they know this and that we can build a democratic and free Europe.

name: Ivars IJABS
text: – Dear sitting leader! Russia's propaganda attempts to distort the history of europe's 20th century are, in fact, part of a broader strategy. These are attempts to undermine European unity by throwing us all back into the past. And in the Baltic States, this sounds particularly terrible when trying to justify the Molotov-Ribentrop Pact and justify the occupation of the Baltic States and the division of Poland. Such propaganda is based on extreme nationalism, the search for external enemies and the influence of major powers. It was the European Union that was once the european union to protect against such demons, but today, authoritarian populists, who find this style of policy attractive, are also taking effect in some countries of the European Union. We must not allow autocracy to divide Europe, so it is much more resilient to the European Union, a historical story based on the fundamental values of the European Union : human rights, democracy and the denial of any totalitarianism.  The House of European History in Brussels is a good example of this, but it is certainly not enough. Thank you!

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: – Mr President, communism, Nazism, Islamism, they are of the same religion, very bloody. And we should learn a little from that here in Europe not to allow such things to come to power.  But enough of Finland's history that the Winter War, which Finland went all alone against that left-praised Red Army, has not been discussed here. And that was entirely due to the division of stalin and Hitler's spheres of interest. In it, Finland was placed under The Russian or Soviet Union. They shared it, but Russia did not succeed because Finland, as a gutsy people, was fighting back. Now history is being written in Russia in the way that Finland started. Small Finland started that war, even though the division of interests had already been made before that, so history is written like this. We should learn from this.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The official Russian historical narrative about the causes and course of the Second World War is a series of monstrous lies. They are intended not only to distract from the Soviet Union's responsibility to provoke this conflict, but above all to influence the international community. Particularly outrageous are the allegations made against Polish, who was the first and biggest victim of Hitler's compromities with Stalin. World War II would not have erupted without the Third Reich and Soviet Union pact in August 1939. No lies by Vladimir Putin will undermine this fact. If a nation or state cannot take responsibility for its own crimes but pass it on to the victims of that crime, it cannot be a credible partner on the international stage. The Kremlin's lies about the recent history of Europe say a lot about russia today, but they say nothing about who is responsible for the hell of the Second World War.

name: Alexander ALEXANDROV YORDANOV
text: – Madam President, Putin's attempts to deny the Soviet Union's guilt for the beginning, but also for what happened after the end of The Second World War, must be strongly condemned. The Bulgarian tragedy began in early September 1944, when the Soviet Union declared war on us. The Russians and communists call this war "liberation." This is a lie, the Soviet Union imposed a criminal communist regime in Bulgaria. Tens of thousands of Bulgarians – the elite of the nation – were killed. Concentration camps are open, an illegal People's Court is held. Today's Russia, as successor to the Soviet Union, owes an apology not only to Poland and the Baltic states, but also to Bulgaria. I call on a united Europe not to allow individual countries to flirt with today's Kremlin regime. We need to counter the Russian hybrid war against Europe. I hope that there will be no European leaders who will be on the so-called "no-go zones" this year. "Victory Parade" in Moscow.

name: Petar VITANOV
text: – Madam President, in September last year, a resolution was adopted in this Chamber on the importance of European historical memory for the future of Europe, where the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact was declared the culprit for The Second World War and communism and Nazism were equated. The resolution does not mention at all the concepts of fascism, anti-fascism and anti-fascist resistance. Yes, we must not deny the disastrous effect of the 1939 pact, but we must not completely ignore historical facts such as the collusion agreements concluded between Nazi Germany and Britain, France, Denmark, Poland, Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, and the disgraceful Munich Agreement predetermining Hitler's further aggression. Here the question is not about Russia and Russian propaganda, but about ourselves. By rewriting the story, we are taking a hit on our own credibility. The direct transfer of history to politics leads to a replacement of historical truth and directly to a rematch that is already visible in many countries in Europe. It justifies the crimes committed by Nazism against humanity and encourages the revival of neo-Nazism, which we in Europe must strongly oppose.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Van Rompuy, for his excellent work The events leading up to the Second World War and the Second World War were very tragic for all the peoples of Europe. Genocide, the Holocaust and the loss of the independence of several European countries for decades because of the Soviet occupation. There are a number of European countries whose people suffered from both Nazi Germany and the Soviet occupation and repression. It is therefore completely inappropriate – now decades later – to try to justify the crimes and agreements of dictators Hitler and Stalin and to try to seek them as justification. Many European nations lost their independence for decades and also lost tens or hundreds of thousands of people. And you have to learn from this tough experience. This generation of people is disappearing from us, who have a personal memory of what preceded these crimes and how it became possible, which has changed in European societies. It is therefore particularly important that new generations also come to understand what happened in Europe and which allowed both hitler and Stalin-led regimes to commit crimes. And there is no way to help you rewrite history and justify the crimes committed by these dictators.

name: Marco DREOSTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the worst form of historical distortion is silence. For half a century, Italy and Europe wanted to forget what happened to thousands of Italians forced to abandon their homes and property in Istria, In Fiume and dalmatia. The history books have omitted the tens of thousands of Italians brutally murdered in the karst foibe by the Titini partisans. Today many want to continue to forget: communists of the third millennium continue to call Norma Cossetto, a young student of letters and philosophy brutally raped by Yugoslav partisans for the sole fault of being Italian; theatrical performances such as Simone Cristicchi's "Magazzino 18" are boycotted by social centers and the left, and films such as "Red Land" have difficulty finding space in theaters and television schedules. "Prisoners of Silence" is a book by Giampaolo Pansa, a recently deceased Italian journalist, who broke his silence on the Italian left to talk about precisely these issues. "Prisoners of silence" are those to whom, as our President of the Republic Sergio Mattarella reminded us, the distortion of history has even precluded the comfort of remembrance and memory.

name: Raffaele STANCANELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to take advantage of this interesting debate on the distortion of European history to mention Giampaolo Pansa, one of the most highly regarded Italian journalists who died last Sunday and who did not belong to my political party: a left-wing journalist. Pansa had the courage to go against the current, rereading some of the most controversial pages in Italian history of the twentieth century. His 2003 essay entitled "The Blood of the Losers", in which he recounted the crimes committed by communist partisans after 1945, cost him accusations of revisionism by the left and some political forces that like to call themselves democratic. In fact, it was not revisionism at all, but the correct narration of events that happened on horseback and after the Second World War. The Italian right has for decades been kept away from the exercise of government responsibilities because of an ad excludendum convent based on the use of history for political purposes. We want this not to happen again.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, we have come together in this debate precisely because President Putin is unhappy with our work. Last year, in a resolution, I condemned the agreement between the two tyrants, Hitler and Stalin, which culminated in the annexation of the Baltics, the occupation of Poland and, of course, my country, Romania. Through this secret understanding, my country has lost territories that have never been returned. I'm not talking this out of the textbooks. I am one of those who were born in a territory annexed by the USSR and today, the Romanians of Bessarabia are subject to this propaganda system that Putin defends. I have said it all the time to Russian politicians, to those in Moscow: this propaganda must stop. Their response was to receive a ban on entry into the Russian Federation. We must fight further for the truth, we must fight to keep alive the memory of our forefathers.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, the truth is that this debate seems to me to be appropriate because there has been an attempt to falsify history and, unfortunately, this happens very often.  E day in the House, Mrs Widdecombe of the Brexit party said that the original European Union project was a free trade association and that, if we had not made progress in integration, the United Kingdom would continue with us. Well, it's a clear falsehood. The draft European integration was, from the outset, supranational in nature and the Schuman Declaration said precisely as early as 1950, that it was the first step for a federation for Europe.  But this debate also highlights that when we look at history from our national perspective, we always see the atrocities that others commit and tend to obscure those committed by our ancestors. That is why what we need is a shared European history, which highlights the tragedies and good things that all Europeans have done.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, mr President, I would like to – (DE) Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, history is becoming a tool of politics when it is used by chauvinists and nationalists seeking to rewrite it. In Russia, history is used to bring the country's population against European countries, as well as to divert citizens' attention from current problems. The distortion of history is not possible without removing the seekers of truth. This Friday, a verdict will be handed down in Russia against the memorial historian and human rights campaigner Yuri Dmitriev. Dmitryyev dedicated his life to preserving the memory of the victims of Stalin's repression. And there are millions of them. Thanks to him, the mass tombs of the victims of Stalinism were discovered in the Karerian region. Soon, authorities spread a rumor that the discovered tombs were buried not by the victims of Soviet terror, but by the Finnish-killed Red Army soldiers. Mr Dmitryyev was arrested shortly after the false charges. It is an attempt to erase the crimes of Stalinism and Putin takes it as stalin's methods of action. Judging by this and other cases of distortion of history, it becomes clear that fans of the verse of the Molotov-Ribentrop Pact seek to manipulate the history of the 21st century as well. Thanks

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for In September 2019, on the 80th anniversary of the outbreak of World War II, the European Parliament adopted a resolution clearly indicating that the non-aggression pact signed on 23 August 1939 by Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union, known as the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact, and the secret additional protocol annexed thereto, in which the two totalitarian regimes divided Europe and the territories of independent states into their zones of interest, was the direct cause of the outbreak of the war. As a result of this pact, Poland was attacked by Germany on 1 September 1939, and on 17 September other countries in Central and Eastern Europe were attacked by the Soviet Union.  In response to this resolution, the current President of the Russian Federation, Vladimir Putin, has already questioned these historical facts several times in public statements in an attempt to hold my country, Poland, accountable for the outbreak of World War II. Parliament should once again condemn Russian attempts to falsified history and cover up crimes committed by the Soviet totalitarian regime and oblige the Commission to strongly counter such efforts.

name: Peter POLLÁK
text: – Madam President, in a few days' time, exactly 27 January, we will mark the 75th anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz concentration camp. A camp where the Nazis killed millions of innocent people, just because many believed or at least did nothing against the devil, Adolf Hitler, especially his thoughts on the superior race. There is no superior race. There's no inferio person. Millions of people died just because they were Roma or Jews. If Hitler had won the war, I wouldn't be here today because I'm Roma. It is a disgrace to this Parliament that people who deny the Holocaust are sitting in this room as well. Dear fascists, the Holocaust has happened. Don't make up and twist the tragic events of The Second World War. During The Second World War, people also died because many were quiet. We can't be quiet today. Today, we cannot be quiet when fascists twist the past and report hatred. We can't be quiet, we can't accept any hatred for the sake of otherness. Because hate is the way to hell.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear President, World War II has left an indelible mark on Europe. Today, even though we sit at the same table and live in peace and mutual respect, we should not forget that before and even after that war our positions were not equal.  Some had imperialist ambitions, some saw a solution to their national issue in cooperation with them. Some of these ambitions were defended, and some were usually "cannon fodder". After all, we didn't all have the same liberators. Some are indeed free of terror from Western, democratic powers, and others are captured again by communists. World War II covers a series of local conflicts that had a completely different historical background.  All things considered, it is clear why the memory of this war is somewhat different across Europe. What is most important is that crimes and criminal ideologies are condemned and that we clearly distance ourselves from all totalitarianism, whether Nazi, fascist or communist.

name: Rasa JUKNEVIČIENĖ
text: – Dear President, I want to start with a more fun one. First of all, I would like to thank the Russian President, Putin, for making a huge public advertisement for the European Parliament resolution that we initiated and adopted. Secondly, Putin relied on material still classified archives in Russia, using them as a tool of information warfare. I propose that President Putin not selectively, but completely open up the archives of Stalin's times. We need to know how Stalin refused to accept Jews from Hitler's occupied Poland in 1939. Putin could order the return of kgb archives stolen in 1991 to Lithuania. We want to know how the anti-Soviet resistance commander Lithuanian Jonas Žemaitis was killed in a Moscow prison. The world needs to know how in 1944 The Red Army was allowed to rape women, destroy civilians just after crossing the border of Kaliningrad Region. How to cut the abdomens of pregnant women and pulled unborn newborns from them. Instead, however, we see Stalin's worship promoted by the Kremlin. Totalitarianism begins with lies. Our attachment is to defend the truth in order to defend the peace we have won.

name: Lucia ĎURIŠ NICHOLSONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, in the twentieth century, nazi but also communist regimes brought mass murders, genocide, deportations and huge loss of life. They should be a sufficient warning to future generations, but they are not. In my own country, too, neo-fascists swapped their people's uniforms for suits and moved to parliament – including here in the European Parliament. A politician who openly promotes communism, a criminal ideology, is the head of parliament's committee on relations with the European Union. I'm ashamed of it. But at the same time, I want it to be a wake-up call for all of us. We must therefore begin to address the real causes of support for extremists, namely corruption, lack of media literacy, unsatisfactory history education and, last but not least, our tolerance for politicians who have doubts about the Holocaust and spread delusions and hatred, which is the basis for the epidemic of extremism.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, let me remind you that the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact was actually a demonstration of how close totalitarian regimes are to each other. The attack on Poland on both sides, by Germany and the Soviet Union, in September 1939 gives us the right to regard the Soviet Union as an aggressor, in fact, despite the fact that it ultimately made a major contribution to the defeat of Germany and also made great human sacrifices. Russian President Putin and some Czech Communists question the true nature of the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact. Moreover, they accuse Poland of actually being an aggressor because it merged with Germany in the 1930s. That's a lie. Je voudrais répondre à M Lebreton, qui est parti, que nous ne sommes pas antirusses. Nous voulons dire que nous sommes contre les mensonges historiques du président Poutine parce que nous ne voulons pas que les guerres et les dictatures with répètent en Europe et nous voulons transmettre ce rappel aux générations futures.

name: Javier ZARZALEJOS
text: – Madam President, when we talk about the past from a political institution, we cannot forget that we are not historians. But we are a product of history. And to be faithful to this story we cannot forget — remembering the verse of the Argentine poet Jorge Luis Borges about Buenos Aires – that Europe was not united by love, but by horror. The fright of the Holocaust, of destruction. The horror of supremacist nationalism, which today still has heirs in this House that are allowed to give lessons to an exemplary democracy like the Spanish one. The horror of Nazism and communism. The scare of Molotov and von Ribbentrop.  That is why we must be vigilant in the face of attempts at distortion of European history. In the face of attempts to whiten the mass crime of Nazi death camps or the Soviet Gulag. Because the suffering of Europeans at the hands of these criminal regimes is non-negotiable. This suffering of Europeans is the very subject of which this Union is made as a project of peace and freedom.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I’d like to thank the honourable Members for their views. Allow me to repeat, in conclusion, that if one Member State were singled out in efforts to distort its historical role, the European Commission would always protest and counter disinformation and fake information, while preserving freedom of the press and media pluralism. Hannah Arendt famously noticed ‘the ideal subject of totalitarian rule is not the convinced Nazi or the convinced Communist, but people for whom the distinction between fact and fiction and the distinction between true and false no longer exist’. I want to fulfil my mission to build up the resilience of our democratic systems by strongly focusing on education, plurality of media and, in particular, by keeping close to the facts and evidence. Only through clear and loud action can we keep the distinction between true and false.  Allow me to express hope that, with the approaching a 75th anniversary of the end of the worst war in the history of humanity, we will not see the multiplication of efforts to distort history of the event and to mask victims as perpetrators.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, we need to learn a lot from our history in these times in which our common values are fragile and need to be upheld. The future of Europe should be based on our common values, mutual understanding of our tradition and shared awareness of the history of Europe, including totalitarianism. Thank you very much once again for your attention.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. It is entirely appropriate to mention the distortions of history in a European Parliament which, in this very area, has been particularly distinguished. There may be differing views on the course of the last world war, and it is clear that totalitarianism of any kind must elicit the strongest condemnation on our part. But it is also up to us to recognize without passion and without bias to whom Europe truly owes its liberation from the Nazi yoke: that is to say to all the allied forces, the United States and eternal Russia, which, from the height of its twenty-seven million deaths, will have paid a high price for victory. As such, the resolution of 19 September 2019, an eminently political and nuanced text, does not grow our institution in any way. It has also been widely commented on in Russia, up to President Vladimir Putin himself, permanently compromising our relations with this great power, now unavoidable on the international scene. Historical truth is ill-suited to ideological quarrels or prejudices. Better yet, it must be the sole debate of historians, far from partisan divisions and divisions.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – We recently voted in favour of an EP resolution condemning the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact as the reason for the German invasion of Poland and the start of World War II. We recalled the heroic struggle of Poles with two aggressive totalitarianism – national socialism and communism. This apparently did not appeal to the KGB colonel, President Vladimir Putin.  Today we are returning to the struggle for remembrance as a result of the information war that Putin has waged against Poland and the countries of Central and Eastern Europe. It would therefore be appropriate to ask President Putin where the German tankers were practicing before Hitler denounced the Treaty of Versailles and the Germans could have tanks? Where did Heinz Guderian learn the art of commanding armoured troops? Who secured power for Hitler by banning the Communist alliance with the Social Democrats in 1932, though that could sink the Nazi Party once and for all? Isn't Bolshevik Russia, isn't Stalin?  Israeli journalist Eldad Beck tells Putin about speaking in Jerusalem at the 5th World Holocaust Forum: "75 years ago, the Soviet Union arrested Raoul Wallenberg, the Righteous among the Nations of the World. This is something that President Putin should talk about, as well as other anti-Semitic crimes committed by the Soviets before, during and after World War II."  Putin's deceitful words have brought "historical war" to the EP. Perhaps we will finally see a condemnation of the communist crimes of the USSR, whose heir appears to be Putin's Russia.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. – Rewriting history cannot and must not be a political activity. For decades, the Soviet Union destroyed historic buildings, controlled education systems, introduced new values with the help of propaganda art, literature and ensured strict censorship. Intimidating, she tried to control people's lives and thoughts. Today, the Kremlin is taking the same soviet propaganda techniques to rewrite history by ordering the hanging of commemorative plaques, controlling people working in universities, often using law enforcement that obeys politicians , as it does in the case of the January 13 case. All available channels are used – in the hope that repeating the same thoughts – they will be able to become in society. Our reaction is therefore particularly important today. Whether we allow the Kremlin-controlled media to spread propaganda freely in the countries of the European Union or not. Whether we are opening the way for 'cultural projects' with hidden objectives and, finally, are we taking part in the events commemorating the second world war in Russia and putting our heads in silence when we are told that the Molotov-Ribentropo Pact and the sharing of Europe were a strategically important step.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the ongoing hearings in accordance with Article 7(1) OF the EES on Hungary (2019/2986(RSP)).

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, respect for the rule of law, a pillar of our common values, is at the very heart of our Union. It directly influences the daily lives of our citizens and the environment in which our businesses operate. Shortcomings in this area make our societies and our Union more vulnerable, both internally and externally. The very fabric for our societies rests on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. These elements are interlinked, interdependent and mutually reinforcing. One cannot exist without the others.  Article 2(1) procedures are ongoing. One regarding Poland, and the other regarding Hungary. Concerning the procedure with regard to Hungary, which was triggered by the recent proposal of the European Parliament in September 2018, two hearings took place last semester at the General Affairs Council on 16 September and 10 December 2019.  The first hearing was general in scope and covered all the issues raised in the European Parliament’s recent proposal. The second hearing focused on specific topics: freedom of expression, including media pluralism, academic freedom and independence of the judiciary, as laid down in the standard modalities for hearings as referred to in Article 7, approved by the Council. Last July, the Finnish Presidency updated the Parliament on this procedure and conveyed the Parliament’s views during Hungary’s first hearing.  Ahead of this first hearing on 4 September, together with representatives from Croatia and Germany, the Finnish Presidency also met the chair of the LIBE Committee and rapporteur for this file. On 10 December, right before the second hearing, an informal exchange between the ministers and the European Parliament took place. On that occasion, Parliament had the opportunity to present its recent proposal and views on the recent developments in Hungary. To conclude, during the Croatian Presidency, it is our intention to continue to keep the Parliament regularly informed on the developments concerning the Article 7 procedure regarding Hungary.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for including on today’s agenda a debate on the situation in Hungary. It is essential that all EU institutions contribute, within their respective roles, to upholding the rule of law in the EU. In November, President Ursula von der Leyen recalled in this House that the rule of law is our foundation and can never be compromised. We must ensure that it is respected and upheld everywhere, with every country treated equally. She added that we must focus on dialogue and prevention but never hesitate to take all necessary measures. As regards the situation in Hungary, the Commission has already explained on different occasions that it shares an important number of concerns expressed by the European Parliament in its recent proposal triggering the Article 7 procedure. The Commission has also made very clear that, whatever position the Council will be taking on the Article 7 procedure, it must ensure a fair handling of the reasoned proposal put forward by the European Parliament. Most recently, the Commission stressed this again during the hearing of Hungary in the General Affairs Council on 10 December. Let me briefly update you on developments in Hungary that have occurred in a number of areas covered by the European Parliament’s reasoned opinion. In the area of the rule of law, new legislation with substantial changes to the structure and functioning of the judicial system was adopted on 10 December without public consultation or consultation of the Venice Commission. We are assessing that legislation. On 10 September 2019, the Hungarian Supreme Court issued a judgment declaring unlawful an order by a district court judge requesting a preliminary ruling of the Court of Justice. This may have an impact on the EU preliminary reference mechanism. The National Judicial Council is still facing difficulties in counterbalancing the power of the President of the National Office for the Judiciary, who is in charge of the management of the judicial system. In the area of media pluralism, last December, six international organisations of journalists and media published a report stating that, since 2010, the Hungarian Government has systematically dismantled media pluralism, in particular because media ownership is concentrated in the hands of the Government and the media market is distorted by state advertising. And further developments raised concerns. The impact of the merger of more than 400 media outlets into one single holding has been analysed by a report published in July by the Centre for Media Pluralism and Media Freedom (CMPF). This report concluded that the establishment of this merger will exacerbate the overall risk to media pluralism in Hungary. The report pointed to the government decision to exempt the merger from the scrutiny of both the National Competition Authority and the Media Authority. As regards academic freedom, you will be aware that the Central European University had to relocate its US-accredited academic programmes from Budapest to Vienna. Also, a new law on the financing of research has been criticised by the national and international scientific community because it detached 15 academic research institutes from the independent Hungarian Academy of Sciences. The Commission is following closely all these developments and has already shown that it is determined to use all the instruments at its disposal to address the concerns raised by certain measures adopted by the Hungarian authorities. In particular, the Commission has launched a number of infringement proceedings against Hungary. These relate to the rights of civil society organisations, academic freedom and the rights of migrants and asylum seekers. The Commission is also using other instruments such as the European Semester. On 9 July 2019, the Council, following a Commission proposal, recommended that Hungary strengthen judicial independence and reinforce its anti—corruption framework, including by improving prosecutorial efforts and access to public information. To conclude, I would like to recall that the Commission remains available to engage with the Hungarian authorities on resolving rule-of-law issues. This is a matter of common interest for the EU, the Member States and citizens.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: f'isem group PPE. – Sur President, erġajna qegħdin nidssdd s-saltna tad-dritt. Huwa ta' tħassib li dan is-suġġett qiegħed jerġa' jqum. Il-pożizzjoni tal-Partit Popolari Ewropew dejjem kienet ikeara u konsistenti, ma' kull pajjiż. Irridu li s-saltna tad-dritt tkun imħarsa dejjem, f'kull żmien, b'mod 大ar u bi proeddikeuri trasparenti. Hedge frog nemmnu u hedge jibqa' t-twemmin tagħna. Għaliex mingħajr ir-rule of law l-istituzzjonijiet jiġġarrfu, il-protezzjonii-ittadin titmermer, il-fidu大ja fil-pajjiż tonqos. I'm not going to be able to do that. U għalhekk din l-Unjoni, dan il-Parlament għandu jkun l-għassies tas-saltna tad-dritt. Aħna rridu nkunu fuq in-naħa ta大-ikeittadini Ewropej, fuq in-naħa tas-sewwa, fuq in-naħa tal-ustizzja u ma' dan m'gandux ikun hemm kompromessi, la minn xi pajjiż u lanqas mill-Unjoni Ewropea u l-istutizzzzjie tagt. Il-Kummissjoni Ewropea, min-naħa tagħha, trid ukoll tibqa' tħares il-valur tas-saltna tad-dritt. Qatt m'huwa a&e-a-sibbli li xi pajjiż jiggarantixxi s-saltna tad-dritt u oħrajn le. Il-valuri li fuqhom hija mibnija l-Unjoni Ewropea għandhom jibqgħu jgħaqqdu flower-pajjiżi flimkien u, filwaqt li nassiguraw dan, irridu li jissaħħu l-mekkaniżmi li bihom is-saltna tad-drittkun t imħarsa. Il-methododi li huma wżati bħalissa ma jagħtux fidu大ja ne大essarja li大-ittadini Ewropej. Hemm bżonn ta' bidla, bidla li ma tistax tistenna. Hemm bżonn li jiddaħħal mekkaniżmu ta' skrutinju li jkun japplika għall-pajjiżi kollha bl-istess mod, bl-istess kejl. Biex nikkonkludi, hawk pajjiż għandu jkun taħt il-lenti kontinwament. Hekk inkunu verament qegħdin nirrappreżentaw dawk li eleġġewna. Hekk inkunu qegħdin nipproteġu li大-大ittadini tagħna kontra min jipprova jnawwar is-saltna tad-dritt.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, 17 months have now elapsed since the procedure against Hungary under Article 7 was triggered. Has it changed the situation in Hungary? Back then, the European Parliament claimed that Hungarian authorities were limiting the freedom of media, the judiciary and universities, denounced its corruption and violations of minority rights. In the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), we are now working on a report on the situation in Hungary, but even without that report, the situation is clear. Hearings held under Article 7 brought no progress. Of course, this is not only a problem in Hungary because, likewise, Article 7 is ineffective with regard to the situation in Poland. Let’s face it, the European Union now has no capacity to quickly restore the rule of law in its Member States. This is why the time has come for a new mechanism. To begin with, let’s tie the extent of the country’s compliance with the rule of law to EU funds.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – (start of speech off mike) Mr President, I came here with the thought of actually saying that, while we welcome the hearings organised by the Council, we are concerned about the lack of involvement of the European Parliament and about the next steps in the  procedure, and so on, but I really don’t want to talk about procedure. I have changed my mind. I want to talk about the fact that it is a disgrace what you are doing to your own country, Mr Orbán. It is a disgrace what you are doing to the place that Hungary deserves in Europe. It’s a disgrace what you are doing to media freedom, to academic freedom, to artistic freedom, to civil society, to all kinds of freedom. You know, nobody made anyone join the European Union. It is a choice towards progress and a commitment to European values that your country made and you disrespect this choice. You disrespect it. Hungary grew and developed so beautifully using and with the help of European money. So did Poland. And now you are literally building empires of hate, of disinformation and of manipulation using European money. You are a disgrace and, by all means, if we don’t have enough procedure then we should make procedure. If we don’t have legislation then we should make legislation, and take every measure needed to prevent you and anyone embarrassing their own country in this way. Perhaps just a last thought for the Council: you know, sincere cooperation and transparency do not hurt, particularly if they serve the best interests of the citizens and of the Union and European values.  (Applause)

name: Gwendoline DELBOS-CORFIELD
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, as Parliament's rapporteur on the Hungary issue, I would like to point out that the Finnish Presidency has done a serious, determined and courageous job. I hope for the same behaviour of the Croatian Presidency. The procedure under Article 7, paragraph 1 of the European Union Treaty on Hungary must continue. We were concerned at one point that the situation was extremely frozen. Thanks to the hearings organised by the Finnish Presidency, we have seen a small evolution, just a small evolution. Today we call on the Croatian and German presidencies to continue the good work done by the Finns. These hearings were an important first step, because it was not easy for peers to assess another Member State and, of course, we innovated quite dramatically. We must continue on this path. Another hearing may be possible, particularly on the question of the use of Eu funds, which could be a next topic. Ms Jourova, you raised the issue of media independence. Could it be that European funds were used to enable media concentration in Hungary? That is a question we should be asking ourselves. I would also like, and I must do so, to remind us here, as Mrs Strugariu said, that we also have an institutional problem. Parliament is still not officially received at these hearings: we can also improve. This resolution, which we will vote on tomorrow, refers to two procedures: one against Poland, the other against Hungary. There is an unfair treatment in both cases. In the case of Poland, the Commission is heard. In the case of Hungary, we, Parliament, have not yet been heard formally, and the informal meetings are not satisfactory. This cannot continue: you are setting a precedent that does not create equality between our three institutions, and that must stop.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, in this case of the implementation of Article 7 against Hungary, the Commission has a role only to ensure the secretariat of the Council, because it is indeed up to the sovereign nations and themselves to decide this debate, which is by no means legal but indeed political. While the European Parliament has rushed to initiate proceedings against a Member State whose leaders are democratically elected, the angry federalists who are fed up with the successive electoral successes of Viktor Orban would like to act in this Chamber, but the treaties do not allow it. Fidesz with its Prime Minister achieved the highest score in the European elections, almost 50% of the vote. This relentlessness against Hungary is indeed born of Viktor Orban's legitimate, intelligent and courageous refusal to reject the suicidal policy of distributing migrants in the European Union. The "Stop Soros" law is just a bad excuse: to see you protest against this law, which increases transparency regarding the funding of NGOs, shows your absolute bad faith. Throughout texts and motions, you denounce Russia's supposed interference in the political life of nations, and while this Hungarian law implements a concrete solution of transparency, you find it undemocratic. Peoples are no longer unsying with your bad faith and your totalitarian project that wants to set them in step to obey financial interests without a homeland, and this procedure is doomed to failure. By jointly attacking Poland on a different legal basis, but indeed, because it also rejects your plan for migration subversion, you have in advance condemned your ugly procedure, and I welcome that.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once upon a time there was a government legitimised by democratic elections. There was once freedom of self-determination, the right to protect one's borders, to love one's religious and cultural roots, but came the red guardian of the treaties, Frans Timmermans, armed with socialism, bureaucracy, arrogance, and came Article 7. This story takes place in Hungary or Poland, but it could happen anywhere. Unum castigabis, centum emendabis: with the political use of Article 7 you want to strike a people to educate one hundred. Those who sit on these benches will never presume to consider themselves superior to their own people, but we think we know them, so I will tell you first: prepare for a new Article 7 procedure as soon as your people in Italy too are given the opportunity to vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I am proud that the European Parliament has taken a position on the issue of developments in Hungary; that we have taken a stand for the rule of law, for democracy and for human rights.  Under Fidesz's rule, we have seen how media freedom has been curtailed. We see how NGOs and civil society are being persecuted and how academic freedom is being attacked – this is the first time that a university has had to be moved. We see the government attacking migrants' rights and banning homelessness and rebuilding cultural institutions. We are also now seeing the restriction of the freedom of the courts by the new law, which has entered into force this year.  I think it is also worth mentioning the NY Times review which shows that Hungary's use of EU agricultural subsidies is full of corruption and profiteering oligarchs, and is being used by Fidesz to strengthen the party's power. One might ask: what is the goal? Well, let's be clear. It is to strangle any form of opposition, to strangle the involvement of the citizens, and this is, as has been said here before, a totally unacceptable development. It cannot be called democracy and it cannot be called respecting the rule of law.  There are lots of citizens in Hungary who want a different development. Those who stand up for human rights, for the rights of migrants, for the rights of the homeless, for women's rights, for LGBTQ people and for democracy and the rule of law. And with all of them, we fight side by side.  But this is also a European issue. Should Hungary, as a non-functioning democracy, sit and make laws for the rest of us in the Council, laws that apply in our individual countries? No, we can't have that. We are grateful that the Finnish Presidency has taken hold of the Article 7 procedure against Hungary. But, as in the case of Poland, things are not moving forward – quite the contrary: things are going in the wrong direction.  We want to see the Commission do more. We also want to see a mechanism that is effective in terms of monitoring the rule of law, and not least, now that we are negotiating the Multiannual Financial Framework, that is when we should set the tough requirements. There should be not a single euro for those who do not respect democracy and human rights.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, among the common values on which the European Union is founded, the rule of law is the bulwark of respect for civil liberties and fundamental rights, in a context of separation and restriction of public authorities. A government which seeks to preserve and strengthen its power by undermining the independence of the judiciary, freedom of expression or academic freedom cannot hide behind the justification of having been democratically elected. When this happens, it is not only the citizens who are harmed, who are suffering a compression of their rights: the credibility of the national and European institutions and the confidence in cooperation between States in order to achieve common objectives are also lost. Violations of European values have been under discussion for years in several Member States, as in the case of Hungary, but the procedure laid down in Article 7 is far from offering an effective remedy. The difficulties in achieving the majorities required for the adoption of sanctions make this procedure essentially non-functional and unsuitable for its purpose. The Government of Orbán is also well aware of this, so sure of its impunity that it continues the authoritarian drift undertaken. As has therefore been called for on several occasions, I hope that an impartial European mechanism will be set up which, on the basis of objective indicators, will be able to offer, country by country, effective and appropriate methods of monitoring and intervention, both for the prevention of serious violations of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights, and for the application of effective sanctions when violations have already been established.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I sincerely regret that the debate on Hungary has become a permanent item on the agenda in the European Parliament. Not only because, procedurally, Parliament would no longer have a role in the Article 7 procedure, but also because the whole debate is not about real facts, but about a political witch hunt. Parliament is an independent co-legislator. I do not understand how we question the Council's independence of this kind. Accusations are made, but almost no one wants to know the facts. The accusers do not care that the Hungarian Basic Law guarantees the institution of judicial independence. He does not care that in Hungary we have proclaimed a zero-tolerance policy against corruption. He does not care Hungary gave the Roma strategy to the European Union. He does not care that the majority of the Members sitting here are from the left-wing media. From the left-wing media that the government is supposed to have blocked. They are also not interested in the 160-page legal factual compiled by the government. We are in the midst of another debate on decisions, which is contrary to the letter and spirit of the EU Treaty. Aggressive political attacks cannot settle disputes. We learned that during communism. Thank you.  (The speaker agrees to answer a 'Blue Card' question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, first of all, a small correction. We’re not actually having a debate on Hungary; we’re having a debate on the attitude of the Hungarian Government, which is not the same. The title is very precise. I was referring to the statement by a colleague. I have a question, though, if you’ll allow me. You keep repeating the same thing, saying that we are making allegations. Dear colleague Szájer, can I ask my question? Can I? You keep repeating the same allegation, namely that we are informed by the left-wing media. I’m not really sure what left-wing media are, but never mind. Do you include in the left-wing media three successive EPP-led European Commissions? The Venice Commission? The OECD? Need I go on? They’re all independent institutions – they’re not left-wing or right-wing – if anything, they are indeed EPP-controlled – the Council, the European Parliament, in the majority – left-wing, right-wing, part of your Group: where are the left-wing media you’re referring to?

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: blue-card answer. – Only about five NGOs have been giving you information. I know this because I worked with you on the Sargentini report. That’s why you took out the Roma parts from it, because you realised that it was all lies. These media are giving you wrong information. I invite you all to come to Hungary and see it with your own eyes.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Only yesterday, the Advocate General of the European Court of Justice once again requested the conviction of Hungary, and this is certainly a neutral body, as perhaps Mrs Jorka also acknowledges. This time, because Orban's law on the gang-making of NGOs violates the European Charter of Fundamental Rights. It is good that we have the European Court of Justice at this time, because, let us be honest, the Article 7 procedure against both Poland and Hungary is at an impasse. When the parents of the European Union invented this procedure, they did not think it was possible for two Member States of the European Union to deviate from the fundamental principles and values of the Union. This is precisely what has happened, and not only since yesterday, and, Mrs Metsola, no, the PPE-DE has not always been coherent lyrise on the side of the rule of law, but, particularly when it came to the Hungarian case, the PPE-DE has refused for years to find the clear words it would have needed. We have the European Court of Justice, but we must not rest on our laurels. We need more measures, and above all we must prevent these regimes from buying the support of their people with benefits from European subsidies. That is why we need to find clear rules and financial sanctions in the next multiannual financial framework. If You cancel european values, there are consequences. But it is also true that the people are not the government. There are many good democrats in Hungary, and there are many, many friends of Europe. We must help them, we must stand by them and we must give them a platform here.

name: Anna Júlia DONÁTH
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. As we have heard from many of our colleagues, the Hungarian Government has been stealing EU money for a decade, destroying the unity of the European Union and destroying the rule of law. So far, the EU has not taken any real steps to stop this. It further allocates EU funds, which are then used to enrich themselves and build their power, rather than schools, hospitals and jobs. The procedure we are talking about has so far not pacified the Hungarian Government at all, and even Viktor Orban sees any action by the EU without consequence as an encouragement.  Anyone who listens to Hungary knows full well that, since we have been deboking the procedure, at least one whole Sargentini report has been destroyed in my country, and this is no longer just about the rule of law. They are so accustomed to being without consequences that the Prime Minister is not afraid to make salon-racist remarks about gypsies in Hungary. There will be no consequences, he says, and he can safely say it until the performance of the EU leadership shows otherwise.  They are in full contrast to European values, as long as we hold the u-turn here, without the European Council of Heads of State having a meaningful say in the proceedings against the Hungarian Government. It would not be the rigour of punishment, but the inevitability, that would be the deterrent. I'm asking that we finally act on this. Thank you.  (The speaker agrees to answer a 'Blue Card' question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Sven SIMON
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her report, It is very important in the debate that we distinguish between facts and political claims. That is why it would be very important to give concrete facts and legal examples in such a speech, which are based on the rule of law, which are well documented. That is very important. Do you agree with me?

name: Anna Júlia DONÁTH
text: "Blue Card Answer" – As we've heard from a lot of people, the table is full of facts. We know exactly what's going on from different reports. You can come to Hungary, you can feel what's happening on your own skin.  It is not possible to separate what the facts are and what the policy is, because all the Hungarian Government is doing is over-politicising the matter and pointing out to different laws from different Member States that it exists here and there, but in the very whole of which a system has been built in Hungary, it does not exist anywhere. The rule of law is being ethiced, and you really have to live there to feel on your skin that freedom is waning.  I'm sorry, it's a policy as long as this system is maintained by a two-thirds majority, it can't be a political decision, "..." " (the President shall withdraw the floor from the speaker)"

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr What is the purpose of Article 7 on citizens' rights continuing to be oppressed, while the governments of other countries choose not to intervene? How serious must the situation be before the EU puts its foot down? What will have to happen before the EU Heads of State or Government do what Parliament demands? Is it the case that the problem is really that the governments of the Member States are so afraid of being scrutinised themselves? In that case, it is pure hypocrisy.  Europe must act now, otherwise we will all lose the confidence that the voters have given us.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Before I give the floor to the next speaker, I would like to say two things: Firstly, because I see an increased mood for blue cards, as well as requests for 'catch-the-eye', in the really serious debate, I will receive a blue card from each speaker – the one who will pick up the blue card first. I also note that colleagues who have simultaneously asked for the floor with the 'catch-the-eye' procedure are asking for a blue card. Keep in mind that I will take this into account as a criterion. If someone makes use of the blue card, they may not be preferred for the catch-the-eye process.

name: Tom VANDENDRIESSCHE
text: Mr President, the European Union's criminal proceedings against Member States such as Hungary and Poland are not at all about infringements of the independence of the press and judiciary. Otherwise, a country like Belgium with its subsidised media and its politically appointed judges would have long been prosecuted. What it is about is that they want to remain boss in their own country. They want to preserve their sovereignty, their freedom and their identity. Who can prove them wrong? This European Union offers no solutions, neither for the euro crisis nor for the migration crisis. Instead of subsidiarity and cooperation, this elite opts for a superstate and coercion. Countries that don't fold penalize them. You are destroying Europe with this European Union of dictates and bureaucrats. With Brexit, a first country is already leaving. How many more countries will have to follow before you finally start listening to the people?

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The Sweden Democrats disagree on the Article 7 procedure against Poland and Hungary, and we still support that.  Our dissent is still based on the assumption that we regard Hungary as a sovereign, democratic state which must be given the right to decide for itself within its democratic process. We regard this reaction from the European Union and from a wide range of countries as excessive and somewhat hysterical. We do not see at all that democracy, human rights or the independence of the judiciary would be threatened in Hungary. The Hungarian people must be given the opportunity to decide on their own, within the framework of the democratic process, how to govern their country.  The EU is doing all it can to reduce national pride. It has gone so far as to even want to ban national symbols in this House, such as a flag on the table. I think it is absolutely preposterous. I am and will always be a proud Swede, I will continue to wear national symbols, no matter what the EU tells me.  Now I want you to listen carefully, everyone. All of you in here are nationally elected to represent your national voters and should be proud of it.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Mr President, I would like to pay tribute to my friend, the brilliant English philosopher Roger Scruton, who sadly died this week. Before Christmas, he was awarded the Hungarian Order of Merit in recognition of his contribution to liberating East European countries. Part of that struggle for freedom for countries like Hungary and Poland was regaining their sovereignty from USSR domination. How ironic, then, that these Article 7 proceedings are being used against Hungary for daring to assert its democratic sovereign decisions today. This time it is the EU, not the Soviet Union, acting as a bully, deploying soft authoritarian tactics. I personally wouldn’t vote for Fidesz or Orbán, but the Hungarian electorate did, in huge numbers. I personally am passionate about free speech and press freedom, but unlike some hypocrites in the EU who regularly censor ideas they dub as hateful, I genuinely respect diverse decisions made by diverse electorates around Europe, even if I don’t agree with them. You say diversity is an EU value, but you ban diversity of opinion. You say liberal freedom is an EU value, but you illiberally deny free choice politically. You launch witch-hunts against those who don’t conform.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, my compliments to the Council and to the Commission are also to the Commission. I'd like to remember the essentials. The European Union is a club of democracies that are governing respect for fundamental rights, separation of powers and the rule of law – and so it is essential that, whenever there is a failure, a break in this principle of the rule of law, and in this respect for these pillars of our democracies, whenever this exists , there is a mechanism to be able to ascertain whether or not the Member States of the Union comply with this principle. It is true that there are problems with Hungary today, that there are problems with Poland, that there are even problems with Malta, but it is also true that Article 7 is not working as it was due. And so it is essential that, in this debate, we are able to advocate for a mechanism that can monitor and that can verify compliance with the rules of the rule of law in all Member States without making any discrimination and without giving aso to any idea that there is an individual persecution of this or that. And that said, I hope that the Hungarian and Polish governments will be able to take positive steps and give signals that will even dispense with article 7.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. Anyone who naively believed that, after the Sargentini report condemning the Orban government, Viktor Orban would trample on the brakes and stop, I think he can admit that he was wrong.  On the contrary, what has happened is that the Orban regime continues to push it with floor gas. Only since the adoption of the Sargentini report has Orban abolished the independence of the Academy of Sciences, attacked the courts, bled out independent theatres, continued to appoint party members to head supposedly independent institutions, and now hears that he wants to take EU funds away from Budapest and opposition-led municipalities.  And in the meantime, of course, he's going to keep stealing, stealing and stealing. That's his main program. In the last few years, his own stooge, Lőrinc Butcher, has gone from a simple village gas Hungary the richest man in the world. He's made more fortune in a few years than the Queen of Britain. That's where we are. Viktor Orban, as an illiberal elephant, is crushing European values while blackmailing and threatening and attacking the Hungarian people with eu money that the Union did not intended for him, but for all Hungarian citizens.  I hope that I will not tell anyone anything new in this room now when I say that Orban will not stop. Orban will not turn back, at least as long as we are just expressing regret and expressing concern and writing longer reports. Viktor Orban does not understand civilized European solutions and things. He made a living as a true Eastern despota, so that if someone hits his hand hard and says, so far and no further, it's not your money, it's the money of the Hungarian people, you can't treat it like your own! We need action! Orban and his government must finally be punished, because this is the only way to protect the Hungarian people. This is Hungary of the Hungarian people, it is also in the interest of the Hungarian people, and it is also in the interest of the European Union.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the People with a Romno background in Hungary face massive discrimination. Children from Roma families are locked away in separate classes, the teaching is deficient. Children can hardly read and write after the end of school. This deprives them of any educational opportunities. Just last week, a court in Debrecen awarded these families damages for the institutional segregation of their children – and rightly so, and proof of the institutional racism in Hungary that the Orban government is responsible for. But how does Mr Orban react? Instead of protecting children, he is pushing for their exclusion. It calls into question the case law and once again incites racism or anti-Gypsyism. Stop rushing against minorities, migrants or dissidents, Mr Orban! And you, dear CDUler, finally be credible and exclude Orban's Fidesz from your group! And to the EU Heads of State or Government: use the Article 7 procedure to rein in Mr Orban! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the "blue card" procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for accepting this blue card. You know that we work together very closely on the Roma. Therefore, I would like to ask you, Mr Franz: can you tell me another country that has done more for the European Roma than Hungary? Please, tell me another country that has done more for the European Roma than Hungary.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The wrong question is, dear Mr. Livia. I would like what you say to be the truth. But we have evidence and facts. Just a few days ago, this judgment of a court has shown it openly. You can't deny that, that's the truth. Let us talk about the facts and evidence and how we can actually change this situation for these people. We both do that, we try to do that. But we can't build this on lies or any brains, we have to take the evidence and actually try to work it out and change it. That is our approach.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, colleagues, what is happening, it is the criminal proceedings against Hungary and Poland, of course, that are a witch hunt. A witch hunt because the peoples of Poland and Hungary have sovereignly elected their sovereign governments. This is the will of the peoples of Poland and Hungary. The real reason you don't like them, dear colleagues on the left (those of you who are more proud of the red five-pointed than your national flag) is that you do not like the policy of Poland and Hungary regarding illegal migration, regarding same-sex marriage, in terms of gender propaganda, in terms of Mr. Soros's stock. This, in fact, you do not like and do it in the form of a purely totalitarian and Bolshevik dictatorship. You deny the freedom of the Hungarian and Polish people to choose their governments and to know how to manage Poland and Hungary. Not you, but they will decide how to manage Poland and Hungary. I know that some of you are ashamed of your nationality, but let me tell you, many empires have tried to erase our national feeling and failed, and you will not succeed. (The Speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: blue-card question. – Mr Dzhambazki, do you agree with me that it is more the way that autocratic or totalitarian dictators work to try to get all the institutions in one country under your control, to have no one who is of a different opinion to yourself? And do you agree that that is exactly what is happening in Hungary?

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – An unsymable colleague, this is exactly what is happening not in Poland and Hungary, in Poland and in Hungary, Poles and Hungarians choose their governments. This is happening here in this room. When you disagree with us, you accuse us and do not let us express ourselves and call us by different names. That's totalitarianism! This is a violation of freedom of speech! This is the new left liberal Bolshevism!

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all here in agreement that defending the rule of law is fundamental. But what is this about, what is it about in Hungary? Are elections free? Yes. Are there opposition parties, is there political pluralism? Yes. Does the press have the right to criticize the government? As far as I know, there was no journalist murdered in Hungary and some of them did not have the same energy here a few weeks ago, when we were defending the rule of law, precisely. Was the government legitimately elected? Indeed. So now we can continue like this, we can continue without facts and in a free way to insult the choice made by Hungarian voters. It is quite possible here to have political disagreements with Mr Orbon, and that is entirely legitimate, but we do not have the right to turn political disagreements into criticism of the rule of law without dramatically overdoing what the preservation of these fundamental principles should be for the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8, of the internal regulation)

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: 'blue card' question. First question: are elections really free if there is no free media? Second question: does it take murder of a journalist to prove that there is no freedom in the media? Third question: even if elected by the majority of voters, can the government act against the law, against democracy, control of the judicial system, the media that should be free, etc.?

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: answer 'blue card'. "Dear colleague, three answers. The first is the media that criticize the government in Hungary and these media do exist and they are even read and listened to, fortunately. The second, yes, when you murder a journalist, something dramatic is going on and there are no proceedings against Malta under Article 7 today and that is a problem of course. And third point: you said to me, Madam, you insulted me for the speech I have just made, you have spoken of shame. I say that those who are organising today the rift between the peoples of Europe in the name of these principles which they claim, while they are betraying them precisely by the procedures they demonstrate without facts, these, yes it is true, should... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the And again Hungary! Opposition protests, outcry in the cultural landscape of the international public – no matter what. As in the past, there is only one party in Hungary, only one opinion. In the future, the government wants to have a say in how much money municipal stages will receive and how directors will be appointed. The new National Cultural Council will be responsible for the strategic management of the cultural sector. We must not be naive. Political control of cultural institutions borders on censorship. Dissenting opinions should not find a platform, this is brainwashing in the already washed-up, so to speak. And yet there is no clear response from the Commission and the Council. The ever-changing anti-democratic developments in Hungary are a scandal that our citizens quite rightly no longer want to accept. That is why it is time for clear consequences!

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, the developing rapprochement between Britain’s new government and Hungary’s President Orbán should ring alarm bells for all democrats. First we have conservative adviser Tim Montgomery call for a special relationship between London and Budapest, and then Orbán praises Johnson as one of the bravest European politicians. With the government opposing any parliamentary oversight of the process of negotiating our future relationship with the EU, are we seeing the UK on the way to becoming a fake democracy on the Hungarian model? Since 2010, Orbán’s Government has attacked media freedom, limiting access to certain sympathetic journalists. Johnson is threatening to abolish the BBC licence, boycott the Today Programme and castrate the lobby system that holds government to account. This government is politicising media relationships as never before. Orbán endorses Brexit because it represents a move towards authoritarian government and illiberal democracy. Johnson’s Tories have fallen over themselves to roll out the red carpet for the Hungarian leader. This is deeply worrying, not only for the UK, but also for the EU.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, the EU is not a casual partnership or a simple calculation of costs and benefits. We are a community of values, and everyone who participates must respect those values: human dignity, freedom, democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights. Because without these shared values as the foundation for our cooperation, this cooperation in Europe can never be future-proof. That is precisely why we must remain so keen on these values in all eu countries. And this Parliament found a year and a half ago – and we supported it – that these values are at risk in Hungary, and those concerns have not been allayed in the last year and a half. It is therefore good that we have this debate today and that we can vote on that resolution tomorrow. But the real conversation must take place in the Council, and that is not happening enough: countries do not dare to speak to each other enough. So let this also be a call to the heads of government. Show that for you too, the rule of law, human rights and democracy are more than just campaign material and nice talk. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I fully support my colleague's statement, but I have a dilemma, some kind of split self, because on the one hand you are saying on behalf of your political group that European values need to be defended, that we need to talk, and on the other hand there are hungarian colleagues who deny these values. Do you in your own group talk about this and have a clear position on which side do you stand or not?

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Biedroń, it’s not my job to solve your dilemmas. You can do that yourself, I think. We are discussing this in our Group, we are discussing this in our family, and we will discuss this in the future. This is all that I have to say to you about it. You take care of your Group. Good luck with your Maltese colleagues. We will discuss it in our Group.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Orbán continues to intensify its attacks on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in Hungary. While the EU has failed to make progress on the issue, the situation in the country has deteriorated drastically. If there were an EU prize in creativity, the Hungarian Fidesz Government and their friends in PiS, Poland, would win by far for their creative methods of constantly violating the eu's fundamental values and laws.  It is clear that the Article 7 procedure has stalled. It is time for us to put in place a new common European mechanism for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. At the same time, we must also proceed with strong proposals for sanctions. Moreover, if Member States refuse to respect the eu's core values, as set out in Article 2, they shall not be able to access the common financial assistance.  Our citizens will not continue to accept that money from the EUROPEAN Union is being misused and used to attack our common values.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Respect for common values and the rule of law are the cornerstones of our society. But how this becomes a social norm and how it can be controlled is already an opportunity for debate. We could witness an exchange of views dissecting such issues if Parliament were to face this issue. But that's not what he's doing.  The Hungary the proceedings against the Commission under Article 7 re-heats along the lines of findings which cannot be fitted into the rules. The procedure was initiated by Parliament, but must be carried out by the Council. The powers of the institutions cannot be intert placed together. We should not allow him to articulate ambitions beyond the treaties.  The draft decision fears the undermining of common European values, mutual trust and the credibility of the Union. So far, two central and eastern European countries have been prosecuted and we are pretending that other Member States are perfectly fine on the issues under consideration. I am afraid that in the eastern half of the Union, it is precisely the double standards experienced by individual Member States that are ethinging citizens' trust in the Union. This should be combated, colleagues.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Mr President, it was almost one and a half years ago when the European Parliament asked the EU Member States to launch the Article 7 procedure against the Hungarian Government, and all we have seen since then is one and a half years of hesitations in the Council, pushing the hot potato from one presidency to the other. Prime Minister Orbán is not hesitating. He continues to undermine judicial independence, to destroy media pluralism and to incite xenophobic sentiments, and as a European Union, we let him do it.
