The Council continues to block progress on Article 7. I urge the Croatian Presidency to take the Article 7 process forward seriously and make it a strong priority. And colleagues, I wonder whether the Fidesz delegation, by the next plenary, will be sitting at the far right where they actually belong. Sokan, sokan Magyarországon hisznek még demokráciában, hisznek még az Európai Unióban, és mi mellettük állunk.

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Thank you very much for the word. My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. First of all, let us look at why the issue of Poland and Poland is Hungary now, for reasons that have been made. That's because the left-wing factions made it a condition for the maltese journalist's murder to take place here in December. The threads of the Maltese murder led to the Socialist Prime Minister, but nevertheless, shamefully, the European left factions only agreed to the debate on this issue if Hungary and Poland were on the agenda in January.  The Hungary against the police are false. The world of justice, science and education is free and independent in Hungary. Freedom of speech is alive and well, and the press is very diverse. It must be said clearly: Hungary has a political dispute with the left-wing forces. This political debate is about the future of Europe, the sovereignty of nation states, immigration and the protection of European Christian culture. And the left is abusing the concept of the rule of law when it wants to punish dissenting people in a political debate with legal procedures. Thank you very much.  (The speaker agrees to answer a 'Blue Card' question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Katalin CSEH
text: blue card question" - Thank you very much. What a rare moment for a Fidesz politician to take up the debate. In Hungary, this has not been the case since you have been in government. I have a very simple question for you: if Viktor Orban and fidesz believe that everything is right with the rule of law in Hungary, why are they so opposed to linking EU money to guarantees of the rule of law? You don't think that's worth a confession? Thank you very much.

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: "Blue Card response" – This is 100%, 100%, that left-wing forces are abusing the concept of the rule of law and degrading it into a political weapon, because they are not willing to accept any political opinions or positions other than their own. You are the enemies of tolerance and democracy as a consequence.  Then we can talk about the rule of law if we apply to everyone what we say about it under the same conditions and we look at everyone equally. That is not the case at the moment, it is being used as a political witch hunt.

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, more than a year and a half ago, Parliament voted to trigger Article 7. Since that solemn moment, the Hungarian and Polish governments have continued to violate the principles of the rule of law one by one. Since that day, the Council has been holding hearings, requesting explanations, requesting clarification, questioning experts and... and nothing at all. Nothing, or worse than nothing, since European funds continue to enrich Mr Orbon's relatives through skewed calls for projects. To be clear, our money enriches those who trample on our principles. We will not be taken seriously until we use the fiscal lever. Let us hit where it hurts, let us condition access to European funds to full respect for democratic rules. In Warsaw, in Budapest, everywhere, NGOs, young people, students are mobilizing, political parties are joining forces to defend democracy and so far we are leaving them alone in their struggle. It is time to show that we are more than doormats on which Mr. Orbon and his friends can happily wipe their feet. This is not a political battle between groups, it is a battle for European democracy.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: Mr President, the rule of law implies the rule of law over political power in a state. It is one of the fundamental pillars of the functioning of our democracies and the community of values that the European Union represents. Governors and governed are required to observe it. Just yesterday, the Advocate General of the European Court of Justice added another log to the pyre of the rule of law in Hungary. It stipulates that the Hungarian law on the financing of NGOs would be contrary to the principle of the free movement of capital, contrary to respect for privacy and contrary to freedom of association. This inverted Echternach procession with Hungarian sauce, one step forward two steps back, is simply not acceptable. The defence of the rule of law can only be governed by one direction in all Member States, regardless of the political colour in power. This is the conviction and message that a true Christian Democrat should carry and defend tooth and nail.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The truth is that it is shocking that there has been no adequate response from Hungary or the Council with regard to the Sargentini report of 2018 here in the European Parliament. Instead, the Hungarian Government continues to openly violate EU law and is increasingly becoming a sham democracy with limited freedom of the press, without independent jurisdiction, a university is being expelled, NGOs are being harassed, and the Council is watching. Tacitly accepting developments in Hungary and Poland means nothing less than abandoning our common European project. As a S&D Group, we therefore call on the Council and the Commission not only to continue the Article 7 procedure with the necessary seriousness, but also to conclude the law that attaches EU funding to respect for the rule of law.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The rules in the EU are clear and the division of labour between the institutions is clear. You on the left want to break that. The left-liberal draft resolution contradicts the treaties in two places. One is that the EP wishes itself a formal presence at the Council meeting. This is stated in the resolution of both the Council and the EP's legal services, which is hidden from MePs, that it is against EU law.  The other is that it would extend the procedure under Article 7 to an area which is not the subject of the Sargentini report. This would therefore not stop in any legal proceedings. I ask on what basis do you want to lecture Hungary on the rule of law?  Commissioner, I regret that the Commission is assisting in this. Please don't mix law and politics. Always be informed from an impartial source. If a rule of law inquiry was initiated equally for everyone, we would be partners. I ask the Croatian Presidency to conclude this procedure as soon as possible. Thank you.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, ten years ago Viktor Orbán came to government in Hungary with an overwhelming majority electoral prize and, since then, the situation has not only worsened but has been chronicized. Time and again the question of Hungary returns to the European Parliament.  At that time I chaired, as chairman of the LIBE Commission, as I am now, the first delegation to examine the impact of its measures on freedom of expression, academic freedom and the protection of minorities. But now the offensive insolidarity with the rest of the Member States on migration, asylum and refuge and allegations of corruption in the management of European funds are added. And all, invoking most of them. And it must be remembered that it was never true that democracy is simply the government of the majority. And no electoral victory allows them to disassociate the the most from European values and principles. Democracy is not the government of the majority, but the protection of minorities and adhere to the rules of the game, the rule of law.  That is why we tell the Commission that of course it has the full support of the European Parliament, not only to promote the procedure initiated by this European Parliament, but to bring to all its consequences the linkage of access to European funds to full compliance with the rules of the rule of law and the protection of democracy and fundamental rights.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, the European Union has no future unless it recognises the sovereign rights of each state to conduct an autonomous policy in areas not within the exclusive competence of the Union. No responsible statesman will jeopardise national security to accommodate Brussels. This Union is a club with certain rules. As there are those who look at these rules sometimes to circumvent, so there are those who impose their interpretations.  Let us not forget that when finances and human rights are at stake, many Member States have circumvented European rules, some on many occasions, but none have been stigmatised or punished in the way they want to sanction Hungary and Poland. The question is why.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Honourable President-in-Office. All of us who have been in the European Parliament for many years can follow the multi-year pogrom over the Hungarian Government, led by Viktor Orban. The Hungarian Prime Minister has always held direct account of this temple of democracy and has denied the accusations. In Hungary, there is no risk of serious violations of European values, so I do not support the resolution tabled, which is full of arbitrary assessments. The facts demant the resolution. Ceu still operates, but without privileges, the media space is more plural than in other Member States, according to Justice Scoreboard, Hungary ranks in the upper half of the Union. However, they are countries in the Union where they kill journalists, they pump out European funds corruptly, spend money on terrorists and illegally imprison the leader of the political opposition. However, the central European institutions do not move. These are double standards and this does not contribute to the strength of the Union.

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to come back to certain issues raised during this debate. On a positive note, let me recall that the Hungarian Government has decided not to push through the controversial reform establishing a separate administrative courts system. However, new legislation was adopted in December introducing structural changes to the functioning of the justice system. In particular, it relates to the appointment of judges to the Supreme Court, introduces new possibilities for the public administration to challenge final judgments before the Constitutional Court, and reorganises the courts hearing administrative cases. We are analysing this new legislation. At this stage, I would only regret that such reform has been carried out at a fast pace without consulting the Venice Commission and without public consultation. I note that the new legislation does not intend to address the existing concerns about the increasing challenges that the independent National Judicial Council faces in balancing the powers of the administrative authority managing the judiciary. These challenges have led the Council to adopt the country—specific recommendations on judicial independence already mentioned by Vice—President Jourová. The fact that the President of this administrative authority resigned in November to become a member of the Constitutional Court does not resolve the structural concerns related to the possibility of arbitrary decisions in the management of the judicial system.  Another issue that the Commission is analysing relates to the judgement of the Supreme Court of 19 September, declaring unlawful an order by a district court judge requesting a preliminary ruling of the European Court of Justice. The implications of this judgment, including for possible disciplinary proceedings, call for a careful assessment because the very functioning of the EU legal system requires that national courts have unimpeded access to the European Court of Justice. I’ve heard a lot of comments about Roma discrimination. The European Union’s Racial Equality Directive prohibits discrimination on grounds of race and ethnicity in education. The Commission has initiated an infringement procedure against Hungary regarding segregation of Roma peoples in mainstream education and is closely monitoring the steps being undertaken by Hungary to remedy this situation.  The Commission has zero tolerance towards fraud with the EU budget and expects the same level of commitment from Member States, which are mainly responsible for the management of some three quarters of the budget. The Commission conducts audits when there are reasons to do so and can take the necessary measures to protect the EU budget.  The European Anti-Fraud Office plays a key role in this regard, and you know the Commission has proposed a regulation on the protection of the EU budget in case of generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law in a Member State. It is a tool to protect the EU budget and ensure sound financial management. The reasoning is simple. In order to control the use of EU funds and to protect the EU’s financial interests against corruption and fraud, each Member State needs an independent justice system, effective investigation and prosecution services, and an effective functioning of public authorities implementing the Union budget. If these functions are endangered by a generalised rule of law deficiency in a way which affects, or risks affecting, the Union’s financial interests, the Union would be empowered to suspend, reduce or restrict access to EU funding in a proportional manner.  The proposal is currently being examined by Parliament and the Council of the European Union and, if adopted, could make an important contribution to the protection of the EU budget.  I have heard also, Mr President, calls for a new rule of law mechanism. I can assure you that the Commission is working on a comprehensive European rule of law mechanism as a matter of priority. It will cover all Member States and provide a synthesis of significant developments related to the various competences of the rule of law, including for example, systemic problems with a process for enacting laws, lack of effective judicial protection by independent and impartial courts, the capacity to fight corruption, and issues in relation to media pluralism. This will allow us to identify and prevent, early on, rule of law—related issues.  To conclude, I regret that I cannot report improvements of the situation in Hungary since the tabling of the European Parliament’s original proposal.  I hope that the debate today will help the Hungarian authorities to further reflect on the concerns expressed. The Commission stands ready to engage with the Hungarian authorities on resolving issues.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me assure the Honourable Members once again that the Presidency and the Council, as a whole, attach great importance to upholding the rule of law and the protection of the fundamental rights. It is the joint responsibility of the EU institutions and the Member States to respect, protect and promote our common values. The Presidency will pay particular attention to the views expressed here today during this debate. As the rapporteur noted, the Finnish Presidency regularly informed the European Parliament about the Article 7 procedure regarding Hungary. Let me reiterate our intention to continue with this practice. The Presidency will also report to the Council about its contact with the European Parliament on its recent proposal.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I have received, in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure, a motion for a resolution. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 16 January 2020. Written declarations (Rule 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – The rule of law in the European Union is being tested. In Malta, the Prime Minister resigned in the wake of corruption scandals, and the Romanian government has also fallen for the same reasons. A journalist has been killed in Slovakia, and the Czech prime minister is alleged to have misused European funds. In Spain and France, protesters are being beaten. Poland also has trouble ensuring an independent judiciary, and hungary's complaints have been dragging on for a long time, and Slovenia is also in this group of risk, as the Government of the Republic of Slovenia refuses to enforce the judgments of the Constitutional Court.  The way in which we are dealing at EU level with the problems associated with the rule of law is unacceptable. Especially in the European Parliament, it is obvious that the procedures are politically motivated, as they are always initiated by the opposite political option. The merit of democracy is that we respect different opinions. However, the basic blame must be clear.  I am in favour of monitoring the functioning of the rule of law systematically and with the same criteria, taking into account historical developments and the right of the state to maintain its sovereignty within the framework of common principles.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. – The fact that I only record my position in writing in the debate on the rule of law in Hungary has a clear reason: I wanted to indicate that the procedure initiated under Article 7 is slow and cumberious, and that the new parliamentary debate brings nothing new, but only provides a repeat stage for illiberal anti-Europeanism. I consider it an achievement that the final Parliamentary resolution, in line with my objection, makes a substantive criticism of the inefficiency of the Article 7 procedure.  However, it is important to continue to point out that a year and a half ago the European Parliament adopted by a two-thirds majority a resolution which stated that Hungary was at risk of serious and systemic damage to EU values. Since then, the Institutions of the Union have been throwing the case like hot potatoes. Back in the day, few were more determined and belligerent than I was when it came to arguing for the rule of law report adopted by the European Parliament, which I voted for. There was no media that was treasonous with a foaming mouth that I would not have gone to and confronted the loud-mouthed people with the truth of the items recorded in the parliamentary document. Even when a puppet depicting me was menacingly hung from a tree, it didn't deter me. My position has not changed, and I would still vote in favour of the report recording the crimes of the Orban government. However, instead of a new showcase debate, the substantive continuation of the procedure and the deduction of conclusions against the Orban government are finally needed.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the ongoing hearings in accordance with Article 7(1) OF the EES on Poland (2020/2510(RSP)).

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, as already expressed today in the previous debate, we cannot stress enough the importance of the issue being discussed here, and the essential place of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in our societies. The EU strategic agenda for 2019-2024 recalls that the rule of law is a key guarantee that our common values are well protected and complied with.  As to Article 7(1), the procedure regarding Poland which was triggered by the Commission: three hearings took place in June, September and December 2018 and at the General Affairs Council. Subsequently, the Council was kept regularly informed about the developments in Poland. In the course of 2019, relevant updates on the state of play were provided and discussed at the General Affairs Council in February, April, July, September and December.  The Croatian Presidency will ensure that the General Affairs Council remains seized of this highly important matter. At the same time, we hope that the ongoing dialogue at a political level between the Commission and Poland will bear fruit. Today, we will take careful note of the intervention from the Commission, as well as of the outcomes of your debate.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament for having included in the agenda the state of play as regards the rule of law in Poland. It is essential that all EU institutions contribute within their respective roles to upholding the rule of law in the EU. I am aware that Parliament has followed the situation in Poland very closely and that you have been regularly updated by the Commission. Last December, Commissioner Reynders had the opportunity to debrief the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE).  Today, the Commission’s intervention will focus on the most recent developments. Let me start with developments in the Court of Justice of the European Union. On 5 November 2019, the Court of Justice, in full support of the Commission’s position, ruled that by lowering the retirement age of ordinary court judges and by granting the Minister of Justice discretionary power to prolong their active service after reaching the new retirement age, Poland had introduced unjustified discrimination based on gender and breached the principle of judicial independence and irremovability of judges under Article 19(1) of the Treaty on the European Union.  On 19 November 2019, the Court of Justice issued a preliminary ruling concerning the independence of the newly created disciplinary chamber of the Supreme Court. The Court of Justice held that it was for the Polish Supreme Court to assess whether the new disciplinary chamber was independent and provided a number of precise elements to be taken into account.  On 5 December, the Polish Supreme Court, based on the criteria set out by the Court of Justice of the European Union, ruled that the disciplinary Chamber of the Supreme Court did not meet the requirements of EU law on judicial independence and was not, therefore, a court within the meaning of EU law or of national law. We have observed a number of reactions from the Polish authorities criticising the Supreme Court ruling. In this regard, I would emphasise that respecting judgments that apply a preliminary ruling from the Court of Justice is of key importance for the uniform application of EU law.  As regards disciplinary proceedings, the Commission decided on 10 October 2019 to refer Poland to the Court of Justice in relation to the new disciplinary regime. In particular, the Commission considered that the new disciplinary regime did not provide the necessary guarantees to protect judges from political control of their judicial decisions.  The situation continues to be very serious. Despite the preliminary ruling of the Court of Justice and the judgment of the Supreme Court, ordinary court judges who seek to implement these rulings are subject to disciplinary proceedings and the disciplinary chamber continues to operate in full. These developments create a risk of irreparable damage for judges, who may become subject to a final decision taken by a disciplinary chamber which has been found not to be independent.  The continued operation of the disciplinary chamber, combined with the launching of new disciplinary proceedings, increases the chilling effect on the Polish judiciary. Polish judges who consider sending preliminary references to the Court of Justice are particularly affected. For these reasons, yesterday the Commission decided to make a request for interim measures in the context of ongoing infringement proceedings for the Court of Justice to suspend the functioning of the disciplinary Chamber of the Supreme Court. These measures are urgent and needed in this specific case.  The Commission stands ready to continue the dialogue with Poland on the rule of law situation with a view to finding constructive ways forward to resolve the issues at hand. Another important recent development relates to a draft new law governing the functioning of the judiciary and currently being discussed in the Polish Parliament. The draft legislation touches upon matters such as the independence of the judiciary, further raising the Commission’s concerns in this area. For this reason, on 19 December, I sent a letter to the Polish President, the presidents of the Sejm and the Senate, and to the Polish Prime Minister on this draft legislation. The aim of the letter was to recall that the Commission wants to work with the Polish authorities to strengthen the rule of law by preventing problems and by working towards resolving them when they arise. In the letter, I encouraged the Polish authorities to consult the Council of Europe’s Venice Commission on this draft legislation and called on all state bodies not to take forward the proceedings on the new draft legislation before carrying out all the necessary consultations with all stakeholders. I underlined that any legislative development must comply with the requirements underpinning the EU legal order and should not lead to a further deterioration of the rule of law situation in Poland.  The Commission welcomes the fact that the President of the Senate has requested an opinion from the Venice Commission, which visited Poland on 9-10 January and is due to provide an opinion on the draft law. The Commission stands ready to engage in a constructive dialogue and is in regular contact with the Polish authorities with a view to finding constructive ways forward to resolve the issues at hand.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Poland’s place is at the very heart of the European Union. Poland is the beating heart of Europe. Poland joining the European Union meant that we could start to move past five decades of historical division and suppression. It meant hope for Poland and hope for Europe. Polish citizens are European citizens, just as Polish judges are European judges. Being a Member State of the European Union is about both rights and responsibilities. It is both give and take. We share history, and we must share a future, and it is because of that shared future that we cannot be silent when the rule of law is under threat in Poland or anywhere. We cannot be silent when an electoral majority is used as an excuse to justify the unjustifiable. We cannot be silent when Polish justice is put under threat, and we will not be silent. The term ‘rule of law’ is not a phrase bandied about that means nothing. It means freedom; it means equality; it means rights. Ultimately, it means Europe. Without the protection of the rule of law, our Treaties risk becoming nice words printed on expensive paper, and without a truly independent judiciary, there cannot be rule of law.  Before this is spun as a partisan manoeuvre, let me be absolutely clear: standing up for the independence of judges to perform their function without fear or favour is not an attack on the Polish state, or far less on the Polish people. It is about protecting the European way and about protecting the people of Poland.  Finally, let me salute the courage of the Polish judges who are with us here today.  (Applause)  We will not let you down. We will not let Poland down. We will not let Europe down.  (Sustained applause)

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Vice-President Jourová, Commissioner Reynders, today we have been able to hear here, at the headquarters of the European Parliament, the dramatic testimony of Polish judges and magistrates of flesh and blood, on the brink of tears, denouncing the abuses, intimidation and harassment they suffer as a result of their judicial function, which calls for independence , as enshrined in European law.  In just two years we have seen a hit-and-run succession of at least three legislative initiatives of the same smutering majority in the Sejm, in the Polish Parliament. I insist that no democracy is simply the government of the majority, let alone when that majority is based on a majority electoral award that does not correspond to the pluralism of Polish society.  Poland is a great country. It is the largest territory and population of the great expansion of 2004. Its first constitution, from 1791, is even before the first French Constitution of the revolutionary period and yet the european Parliament's concern with the rule of law in Poland is justified and comes again and again to our discussion. This has been highlighted by the Court: judgments which clearly show that the Judicial Office and the Disciplinary Chamber replacing the Supreme Court are incompatible with Article 19 and 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which has also been binding since the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty , also for Poland. Therefore, the message is clear. We must tell the judges and magistrates and the lawyers and judges from all over Europe who demonstrated this weekend, this Sunday, in Poland: "They are not alone, you are not alone". The European Parliament supports the independence of justice, fundamental rights and democracy. And the European Parliament requires the Commission to link access to European funds to strict compliance with the rules of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I guess you can be pretty sure that something pretty serious is happening when judges are taking to the streets to protest. And, indeed, it is serious: we have an EU Member State government – one of the biggest EU Member States governments – conducting a ruthless intimidation campaign against judges who are simply trying to protect their independence from political control. And more than 40 of them – and some of them here – have been targeted by disciplinary proceedings and smear campaigns orchestrated also with the help of the Ministry of Justice.  Let’s be absolutely clear on this: this kind of repression of independent judges is without precedent in the history of the European Union. And if this new legislation is passed, it could even happen that judges could be fired for interacting with or implementing the European Court of Justice rulings, which constitutes quite a blatant and clear challenge to the idea of the European Union as a community of law and common values. Unfortunately, in the Article 7 proceedings so far, the Council has been acting in a fairly opaque and timid fashion, unlike the Commission, which has thankfully acted with this request for an interim measure. But national governments can no longer duck their responsibility when it comes to protecting European values: as has been said, Polish judges are European judges, and the situation in Poland is a European problem. Without judicial independence, there is no European Union.  (Applause)

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I was also one of the people who had the pleasure and the honour today to speak with the representatives of the Polish judges, lawyers and prosecutors. To be honest, there was one sentence said in that meeting that impressed me a lot, and that I wanted to repeat here in this Parliament. One of the representatives said: ‘I swore an oath on the Polish Constitution when I started my job, and with all I do I’m trying to stay true to this oath and defend the rights of Polish citizens’.  To me, this really encapsulates what kind of people we have to protect in situations like this: these are the kind of people that defend the rule of law, defend our democracies, and are the backbone of our democracies and of the systems that all of us have been profiting from in the past. Judges, prosecutors and lawyers are one of the fundaments of this tripartite system, and that is why protecting them really also means protecting the separation of powers, and thus our democracy. Indeed – and colleagues have mentioned it – what we have seen in Poland in the past years is an organised campaign against that very important backbone, and the Commissioner has mentioned the latest developments in this field.  This Parliament and the EU institutions have taken steps in order to defend the rule of law and European citizens in Poland, but I believe that the Article 7 procedure has actually proven to very often come too late and be too inflexible to meet all these attacks that have been happening. I think we need to have a more holistic vision, and the rule of law mechanism that is going to be proposed is one of the instruments that we need, together with budgetary measures and, of course, enabling civil society, enabling these representatives to work together.  Let me finish by saying that I really hope the Croatian Presidency is going to follow the Finnish example in standing up for the rule of law, but just be assured that – no matter what is going to happen – this Parliament will continue to stand up for the rule of law and democracy in the future.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and for the real, i would like to thank the – Mr President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Van Rompuy, for his excellent work I speak in my own language – Estonian this time. Firstly, I wish the strength of our Polish colleagues. Let's hope you make it. To the previous speaker, I would like to say that the Polish judge with whom you spoke and who had pledged his vow to defend the Polish legal system had to take his oath during the Soviet Union in Poland, when Poland was occupied by the Soviet Union. Otherwise, he wouldn't be fired under the new law. So he worked not for Poland, but for the Communist regime, and you can say 'Shame!' here, but learn history!  Secondly, I would like to say that three months ago there were elections in Poland and 43% of people supported the conservative party in Poland. 43%! That's a fact. They have a strong mandate for reform. Thirdly, when we talk about the rule of law and values, I will conclude, and please be a gentleman and do not interfere, you can also remain silent and then speak. I want to say when we talk about values, that there was a debate on World War II before, and I heard a number of speakers paying tribute to communism, the Soviet Union and the Red Army for how they saved the world. I ask if this is really in line with european values of approving the regime that killed 20 000 Polish officers in the Forest of Katyn? Are these European values? Think about it!  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 171(8))

name: Mikuláš PEKSA
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. – Mr Colleague, I would like to ask you, after all you have mentioned here, if you could wait for the next item where we will discuss the criminally prosecuted Czech Prime Minister Andrej Babiš, who, according to the slovak court's opinion, used to be an associate of the Communist secret service and used to be in the Communist Party. At the moment, it is meeting within the European Council, and at the moment it is also contributing with its voice to the fact that it is not possible to solve the problems that we see in Poland and Hungary. So I'd like to ask you if you could wait here and be as vocal as you were in this case.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: blue-card answer. – Unfortunately, they haven’t attributed my speaking time for the next session, but I will be in the House so I will try to get my speaking time with a blue card or catch-the-eye. So I think it’s a very good idea, and thank you for reminding me.

name: Beata SZYDŁO
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur Courts in Poland are independent and free. Poland is a law-abiding country. In Poland, judges can protest and no one brings out law enforcement against them. Anyone who claims otherwise is lying.  All Poles sitting in this Chamber know this, including the judges who have been invited here. Four years ago, exactly a few days from now, this inglorious anniversary will pass, the Polish opposition organized a debate against Poland. On 19 January 2016, I had the honour of representing my country as Prime Minister of the Polish Government during a debate at the European Parliament in Strasbourg. At that time, we talked about the situation in Poland, about reforms, about everything that is necessary to achieve and what the government of Law and Justice has undertaken to trust in democratic elections by citizens. During these four years, we have carried out a great many social, economic and administrative reforms. The Poles appreciated this and trusted us again, once again gave us a mandate of trust to form a government and continue these reforms that had begun. A lot of good has been done in these four years, but Poles still expect all the reforms, including justice reform, to be carried out, because the justice system is to serve the citizens, not to protect some of the certain privileges that a particular group wants to retain.  On Polish several occasions, this government, including myself here four years ago, has explained why reforms of the justice system are needed, a system that has not been reformed as the only one during the transition period, and it can be said that it is so far a relic of a communist state in a democratic Member State of the European Union. The European Commission knows this, you also know this here in Parliament, because we have talked about it many times, and that is why we have undertaken these reforms. We have made these changes in accordance with the Polish Constitution, in accordance with European legislation, but above all in accordance with the will of the Poles, because this is our sovereign. We have always been open to dialogue and we have always been open to explanations, but for this dialogue to be conducted, there must be will on both sides, and I have the impression that the European Commission and the European Parliament simply do not want this ... (The President received the speaker's vote) (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Mrs Szydło said that everything that is happening in Poland is constitutional. We do not know whether it is constitutional, because Prime Minister Szydło is the person who ordered the judgments of the Constitutional Court not to be published, and that is where the violation of the Constitution in Poland and the violation of the rule of law in Poland began. She is also a person who is not impartial in this matter, because it is in her case that there are cases such as 26 hearings to God of the guilty spirit of Sebastian K., so I suggest very much to the governing...

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, I have to tell you that the 'blue card' is there to ask a question, not to take part in the debate. I am sorry.

name: Beata SZYDŁO
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This was not a question, but Mr Sikorski has lied at the moment and I should actually take him to court, because there are no legal proceedings against me – that is, firstly, Mr Sikorski. And let you read comprehension. You are a liar and you are unseasy to have a mandate to give poles.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, I would be very careful with such speeches, where one assumes something to the other. That is why we are having the debate on the rule of law in Poland. That is the issue. The Commissioner has already given the introduction.

name: Konstantinos ARVANITIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, although we are sceptical about the European Union's interventions in Member States, as we in Greece have bitter experience with the Memorandums and with the Troika, in this case Poland, I agree, and we agree as a group, on the drafting of an interim report concerning not only the judicial system but also all the fundamental rights that are in crisis as we speak. This was the position of our group from the outset and of the entire progressive arc, as you have heard here. At the moment, in Poland, the judiciary as a whole is being demoted for the benefit of the executive, and the independence of the judges is at stake — we heard them today. They intend to make it illegal even to bring an action before the European Court of Justice. We stand by the judges in their particular battle, just as they must stand in solidarity with the right of vulnerable groups for freedom of the press, for the right to assembly and association, for workers' rights, for women's rights, for people at risk. This is the Europe we want. This is the Europe we want, not the Europe of fear, obscurity, the restriction of rights. Good luck to the judges.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: I have to apologise to you for being one step further because of the 'blue card'. After the group spokesmen, we are now entering into the debate of the individual Members.

name: Andrzej HALICKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mrs Szydło, I would like to thank you for your In a democracy, the sovereign is the law, the constitution must be respected, not broken. No one gives the right of any political party, even the ruling party, to violate the constitution, to violate the treaties, because this debate is not about Poland, this debate is about the protection of the rule of law and the protection of the European Union. And Polish judges, simply because they want to exercise the law and act in accordance with the treaties, cannot be thrown out, they cannot be disciplined. The Union has the right to react and has a duty to react then, which is why we thank the Commission for its activity. But I also wanted to say, as head of the Polish delegation of the EPP within the European People's Party: of course we are in favour of a resolution that protects and strengthens the Union, because these are our civic expectations too. Without the rule of law, there is no freedom.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – Mr President, we are seeing in Poland today the perpetual carnival of destruction of the Polish judiciary. I’ve been observing this process for years as a deputy Commissioner for Human Rights and now as a Member of the European Parliament – the dismantling of the Constitutional Tribunal, control over the National Council of the Judiciary, monopoly to appoint judges, the Supreme Court. Now we are seeing the proposed muzzle law, which will make it possible to limit judges’ independence even more. There is no doubt that all these changes are in complete violation of the rule of law and I am sorry to say that the actions undertaken by the civil society so far, the protests of judges and the triggering of the procedure under Article 7 have all been insufficient. This is why the time has come for further steps. It is necessary to suspend the operations of the Supreme Court’s disciplinary chamber and it is high time to tie the country’s compliance with the rule of law to EU funds.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the European Commission for its determined intervention, but in the direction of my Polish colleagues from the ECR Group, you justify your purge of the judiciary by referring to Communists. Well, apart from the fact that that’s already 30 years ago and some of the judges are actually rather young, what strikes me about this is that some of the parties in your group, like, for example, the Dutch Forum for Democracy, is using the exact same language in my country to attack to the judiciary there. We’ve never had any Communists in power, so it is a very clear pretext to grab power over the judiciary.  What also strikes me is that you’re going straight against the interest of your people. The Polish people are amongst the most pro-European in the whole European Union, but if you don’t recognise the European Commission, the authority of the European Court of Justice, the decisions of this House, or indeed the EU treaties then we’re talking about a de facto ‘Polexit’. Now, did you tell your voters that before you went to the elections? Or did you lie to them? Please turn around, come back into the fold, respect European values and keep Poland firmly in the heart of the European Union. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Dear Colleague, you are using phrases that you have no idea about. Please give any example of a purge of judges in the Republic of Poland, in a free, sovereign country. Please give examples of violations of any European values. Yes, Poles love the European Union, and yes, they want changes in the justice system. Please give one example specifically, and I ask the President that, in fact, each of you who speaks should not only speak with newspaper titles, but give concrete examples, such examples simply do not.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card answer. – Ms Zalewska, you don’t have to take my word for it. You can take the word for it from the Polish judges who are sitting in the public gallery. If you don’t listen to the judges, who have who have sworn loyalty to the Polish Constitution, you might actually listen to the impartial opinion of the European Court of Justice. If you don’t recognise the European Court of Justice, you cannot be a member of the European Union.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: – Mr President, last weekend judges from over 20 European countries gathered in Warsaw to support their Polish colleagues in their fight to protect the independence of the judiciary, and they were supported by many Polish citizens who demand European action.  We applaud the Commission’s call to the Court of Justice to impose an interim measure on the Polish Government to stop the disciplinary chamber. Yet as we know, this procedure covers only one of the many threats to the Polish rule of law.  While judges from all over Europe speak out against these dangerous reforms and violations, our government leaders remain silent. There are no recommendations to the Polish Government, no regular hearings and no legal steps taken, such as interstate complaints. These are all measures that the Council can take without unanimity.  My question to the Council, and through the Council to the other Member States, is a simple one. How far does the Polish Government need to go before you will start actively defending our European values?  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I do not want you to have the impression that this is a Polish-Polish war, so I will not refer to my colleagues from the Civic Platform who are hyperactive, but I will ask all the previous comers from other groups and from other countries. Where have you been when, under the rule of those who sit on these benches today, the special services entered the editorial board of the weekly "Wprost"? Where were you, as was the "Fork" action, when the spirit of the guilty fans was retained to God? Where were you when there were police provocations and independence marches were broken up? Where was the European Commission at the time?...

name: Othmar KARAS
text: I would just like to stress once again that we are sitting here to debate the council and Commission statement on the ongoing hearings under Article 7(1) of the EU Treaty. The basis is the Commission's report, and this basis has shown facts that we are now debating here. I therefore come to the answer to the honourable Member's question, and then we move on in the debate.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: blue-card answer. – I can’t reply to this question, because it’s completely arbitrary. What we are discussing here is the threat to the rule of law in Poland. A real democracy recognises the separation of powers and the checks and balances that we need in order to respect not only the majority, but also the minorities, and the rights of everyone in a country. Now this is under threat, and I would really hope that the Polish people – and especially Polish politicians – really look into the facts and look at the rule of law and the rules of the European Union to see where they are falling short.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report I am a practising lawyer in Germany and, of course, the judges are appointed by the Ministry of Justice. Separation of powers means that the judge is free in his decision on a case-by-case basis. But for God's sake, it does not mean that the judges choose themselves who becomes judges, what the rules of procedure are, etc. This is a Polish peculiarity that the judges determine their own colleagues, their presidents and their successors. And it is the old practice that has now been overcome that undermines the separation of powers. Separation of powers means that the judge is bound by the law, but it does not mean that he invokes himself, he promotes himself, and he also controls himself whether he abides by the rules. That is the difference. In this respect, I am very impressed, as is being called for here in the name of the separation of powers, to maintain precisely this breach of the separation of powers by the old rule. And I hope the Polish Government will stick with it.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Since we currently have several 'blue cards' at the same time, which are always handed in very late with hand signals, I would ask you to use the electronic system so that I know the order and, on the other hand, I also know who wants to ask the question in order to introduce a specific order into this rather heated debate.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner Jourová said she encouraged the Polish authorities to consult the Commission on changes to the justice system. Commissioner Jourová, I would like to say to you that the European Union is not a union of the republics of the Member States, but a union of states that want to carry out a common mission, but each state is sovereign and, in accordance with the Treaties, each State retains competence in terms of justice.  Poles are a proud, law-abiding and democratic country, and we certainly do not deserve to see a good name for the Polish European Parliament. So why is this happening? Because we have an opposition that has set itself the goal of reporting on Poland and building false information around Polish. This is an example of misinformation, of harming your homeland. Look, there are people from all the Member States from different political parties, but no opposition to their homeland behaves as shamefully as representatives of the so-called European coalition.  Ladies and gentlemen, if we do not know what is going on, then I ask you to check how far you can go in the appropriation of national competences, because you want to get on the road to federalisation, and I am surprised, because you will go back to Polish, as you will explain from the fact that you demand that funds be associated with the rule of law ... (The President interrupted the speaker) ... when this rule of law is broken.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – You always demand specifics, so I wanted to ask a specific question. Please point out to me the specific laws and specific provisions of your judicial reform law that improve and reform the justice system in Poland, so that it truly respects the tripartite power, is constitutional and serves the Poles.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – If you had the ability to read comprehension, this question would not have been asked today, because I assure you, Madam MEP, that all the laws we have proposed are improving the justice system, and in Poland, ladies and gentlemen, the justice system has very often been oppressive towards citizens and therefore needed to be improved. Law and Justice won twice because we agreed with the Poles that we would reform the justice system.

name: Sira REGO
text: – Mr President, judges persecuted for demanding respect for the rule of law, establishment of LGTBI people-free zones, criminalisation of sex education in schools, persecution of freedom of expression and the right to information. In short: human rights violations.  It is dramatic that this is happening in an EU country. We should be demanding, and not only so that the Polish Government does not go unpunished and complies with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, but also with the role this House plays in normalizing far-right hate speech. Let us not forget that to have the far right to put a president of the European Commission is to normalise to the far right. That approving Europe's racist policies is strength is to integrate the narrative of the far right. That rewriting history, denying and criminalizing anti-trade fights is a concession to the far right.  Let us not be complicit in those who want to return us to the darkest stage. Let us regain the spirit of anti-progressive Europe.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, as a lawyer, I am deeply moved by the march of Polish judges last Saturday. We ask the Polish Government to respect the Polish Constitution, which is a European constitution too; to respect Polish judges, who are European judges too; to respect the Polish judiciary system, which belongs to the European system too – the same thing we ask of every single country, no matter if it is from east, west, north or south. We are defending the right of the Polish people to have an independent justice system they can believe in. We are not attacking the Government of Poland, but defending the people of Poland. If we have to choose between this Polish Government and the Polish people, trust me: we know on which side we will stand. To conclude, to my colleagues in the ECR Group: sincerely, do you realise how much your government is damaging your country? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to say that the Polish citizens whom you have spoken about – and I thank you for this – have won law and justice six times, and we thank you for your concern. I wanted to ask you, because you are here relying on the European Union, which is also very important to us, we are a Member State. How would you comment on the fact that your country – of course, had the right to do so – rejected the judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union on Catalan parliamentarians?

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Brudziński, I have two words: one in English, and another one in Spanish. In English: you are lying. In Spanish: está mintiendo. The Spanish Supreme Court accepts the sentence of the European Supreme Court, so there is an absolute difference. The Spanish Supreme Court respects the rule of law. You are lying, and you are a liar.  (Cheers and applause)

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yesterday, the European Commission asked the European Court of Justice to immediately suspend the PiS-controlled disciplinary chamber for judges – an important step. I hope that the Commission will act just as decisively and, above all, quickly once the latest anti-state law has been passed. That is being debated in the Senate today. In the Senate, by the way, the PiS lost its majority at the last election. And then you see what happens in such regimes when you lose power: the Senate president has since been covered in a dirty campaign. Over the weekend, thousands of people, especially lawyers, took to the streets – courageous people. And here we have very brave people – judges and prosecutors – who have come here. I hope that I have understood correctly to Mrs Szydeo that these people who have come here, as a result of having spoken to us here, do not face any consequences if they come back to Poland. I take you at your word. And I am curious to hear what you say about the many judges who are already suffering consequences because they wanted to apply European law, for example. What is happening in Poland at the moment is highly dramatic. It is nothing less than an attack on the foundations of the European Union. The government wants to de facto ban judges from applying European law. And if there is always talk here of communism, why did you, please, nominate someone for the Constitutional Court – Stanislaw Piotrowicz – who, in the 1980s, as a prosecutor in communism, persecuted opponents at that time? Please explain this to me.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In reference to the previous speaker, if our regime is so bad because it got too little support, what to say about your party, a regime that got twice as small.  But returning to the most important issues, it is characteristic that you are saying very generally today that the law is being broken in Poland. None of you have said what exactly is the politicised choice of judges in Poland, and you know why? Because if you did, questions would start to arise, such as the question to Commissioner Jourova, how are judges elected in the Czech Republic? Please say this and compare it with Poland, and then you would all see what one big lie is all about. It is good that you from Germany have also spoken, because you say that we have a politicised choice of judges. Do you know that in Poland judges choose judges? And do you know how judges are elected in Germany? Quite recently, a Member from the Bundestag became a judge. And you are telling us cheekily that there is a politicised justice system in Poland, and not in Germany? This is the pinnacle of cynicism, I will say more, you are talking about freedom to manifest. Did you know that those judges who sit here had the protection of the Polish police, as they protested? And now let the French judges and French lawyers say how forcibly they were brought out of the court of appeal in France. And what, and with us, the rule of law is being violated, and in France it is not? After all, this is ridiculous and you know it very well. Poland bothers you because it no longer sticks to the German leg, that it gets up from its knees, does not agree to accept as many migrants as you want, does not agree to accept such amounts of technology, just wants to be a sovereign, personal state, and that bothers you.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Anna Júlia DONÁTH
text: blue-card question. – Mr Jaki, I know you are really good – like your Hungarian friends – on pinpointing other Member States, but let’s get back to the Polish issue. Today, as you are well aware because you were there, the Polish judges presented in Parliament the changes to the Polish court system. Elements of these are against EU law, as confirmed by the European Court of Justice – such as the disciplinary courts. My question is this: what public consultation preceded the adoption of the law? According to the judges, there was none. Will your government amend the law according to the European Court of Justice decision, or will you follow your Hungarian Government friends and ignore the Court’s decision, like always?

name: Patryk JAKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – It is, moreover, characteristic that you are saying something about breaking the law, and you do not indicate any specifics. But it is very good that you mentioned the Judgment of the CJEU, because a Spanish colleague accused my colleague, in turn, of lying about the Spanish case. If so, if you say that you will abide by the judgments of the CJEU, Then I ask the question when you will release a colleague from prison. Please, you follow, please tell me when.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, it was a historic image in Warsaw on Saturday: judges from more than 20 countries taking to the streets with their Polish counterparts against the erosion of the rule of law. It shows how dire the situation is, because the adoption of the muzzle law is taking another step towards demolishing the independence and freedom of expression of judges in Poland. And the rule of law cannot function without independent and impartial justice. A Member State where Lady Justice is taken away from her blindfold and has to look through the lens of the incumbent can never provide the protection that society deserves, nor can it ever cooperate within the EU with other countries on the basis of mutual trust. So, full support for the European Commission's approach. We will continue to protect the Polish rule of law. We will not leave the Polish judges out in the cold, because their struggle is a battle of all of us.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Democracy in Poland in danger! There, despite massive protests, parliament passed a law to further discipline judges. They face fines, downgrades or dismissal if they challenge decisions of another judge, court or chamber. Quite rightly, we are talking here about a 'muzzle basket decree'. Today's debates follow many other debates in recent years, and quite honestly, I feel like I'm in the movie "Groundhog Day" or German "And every day the marmot greets". How much longer does the Council intend to stand idly by and invoke non-transparent hearings that lead to nothing? And for how long does the Commission intend to settle for infringement proceedings or official letters? Finally, use all the instruments for a democratic and constitutional Europe before it is too late!

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Mr President, without our values – the values of human rights, freedom of expression, democracy and, crucially, the rule of law – the European Union cannot exist. These very values guide our work here in the Parliament day after day, and are the very essence of what makes us Europeans. That’s why we’re having this discussion here today, because in Poland these values and principles are sadly at risk through the actions of the current government.  Action taken to change the situation through the initiation of the Article 7 procedure has regrettably shown little progress. There are two options on the table. I sincerely hope, firstly, that the Polish Government changes course and takes action to respect the judiciary as outlined in the Commission’s recommendations of December. I urge them to do so and to stop the denial we’re seeing here today. However, should this not occur, the second option must be advanced: the Council must take forward the Article 7 procedure and make effective use of it.  A holding pattern is no longer acceptable, and I stand with the Justices from across Europe who, upon seeing and injustice happening, move to the fore to stand up for the rule of law – the rule of law that is worth protecting.

name: Włodzimierz CIMOSZEWICZ
text: – Mr President, the government ruling Poland continues demolishing the rule of law. In December, the lower chamber of the Parliament adopted a bill which opens the way to punishing the judges who implement the verdicts of the Court of Justice of the EU. If that happens, judiciary independence will become non-existent. The Speaker of the Senate, who came to Brussels to discuss the issue with Ms Věra Jourová, was officially accused by the government of damaging the basic interests of Poland, and the attorney—general publicly commented on the possibility of accusing the speaker of unconstitutional activity. At risk is not only the rule of law, but – later on – also democratic rights and freedoms. The situation requires urgent and decisive action by this Parliament, the Commission and the Council. It is a test of the credibility of these institutions.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I will react a little unconventionally first to my colleague Jaki, who mentions the judiciary in the Czech Republic. Mr Colleague, I was Minister of Justice in the Czech Republic for 5 years and was in charge of reforming the Czech judiciary. We had similar problems to you with communist judges. And we have never, for example, intervened in our reform to purposefully lower the retirement age of judges. We have never made purposeful political changes like you do in Poland, even though we have had similar problems in our justice system. So please do not mention the Czech Republic and please try to reform your justice properly in the style of the rule of law. Mrs Jourová does not have it easy, she must now communicate with your government, and I hold Mrs Jourová's fists to convince the Polish Parliament that it is possible to reform the postcommunist judiciary while respecting the rule of law. We have done this in the Czech Republic and it is up to you to fulfil the principles of the rule of law while having effective non-communist justice.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Law and Justice, I have bad news for you today. Yet the free courts have not perished while we live. So that you do not know how long you are screaming, so that you do not know how many muzzles you tried to impose, any leashes they tried to put on, then Polish society will take to the streets for as long as it takes, in defence of the Constitution, in defence of the rule of law, to defend constitutional order, and this solidarity will also be shown here in the European Parliament, because your actions, your elite, because you talk a lot about elites, is a threat not only to the rule of law in Poland , but for the European Union as a whole. Therefore, I warn you, if you continue down this path, you will be even more alone and will move closer towards Belarus and Russia, because you are going to use the same manipulations in Poland as you do there in Belarus and Russia. You talk a lot about elites, but who makes up the elite today? It is you in Poland who have created a new neo-communist elite. You have the public media in your hands, you have parliament, you have a president, you have your representatives in the courts, so you will never broken our solidarity.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, I am from Romania, and in Romania the previous government attempted to weaken the judiciary to affect the rule of law. We saw how people decisively – big numbers – came to the streets to defend the rule of law and they came out with the European flag in their hands, expecting that the European Union and the institutions of the European Union would stand by their side. So what did we do? The President of the country convoked a referendum and the people spoke loud and clear. More than 85% of the people said: we want a strong judiciary, we do not want overnight, un-transparent changes to the judiciary, we do not want mass pardoning and mass amnesty. So this is why, from the European Parliament here in Strasbourg, I say to the people of Poland: we hear you, we stand with you, we defend you. And I say the same to the judges in Poland: it’s our duty; we will fulfil it; we will stand with you to defend European values in every corner of Europe. Any attempt to weaken the judiciary, any attempt to intimidate judges, is unacceptable, and the European Parliament will fight strongly. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Dear Sir, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. You have used very clear and strong words, and I have a question about how befits a blue card. I wanted to ask you what you would call the use of discipliners, the discipline of judges, the de facto persecution of judges – I will say specifics: one of them is here in the gallery, his name is Waldemar Żurek, Judge Juszczyszyn, Tuleja, Markiewicz, who is probably fifty-five – for applying European law, for the judgment of the European Court of Justice and for asking questions for a preliminary ruling to the European Court of Justice. What would you call it?

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: blue-card answer. – Whenever politicians want to appropriate all power, then they want to neutralise any form of opposition. They will attack opposition; they will attack an independent judiciary; and they will just want judges and prosecutors under their control. It’s always a bad sign when politicians and governments want to limit the independence of the judges, of the judiciary. Never should judges obey politicians. The judiciary is an independent power in the State, and this is how it should be. (Applause)

name: Bartosz ARŁUKOWICZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today you had a small example of what kind of team today rules Poland. Yelling, aggression and such momentum propaganda that pours from morning to night, but it's not really about Poland today. This debate is today about the future of Europe, about the future and security of our children, their freedom, because if we allow lawlessness and violations of the constitution to spread anywhere in Europe, it will be our fault. If we allow our spines to be broken anywhere in Europe, defiant judges are destroyed simply because they do not want to listen to party hangovers, it will be our fault. If we allow innocents to be blamed and acquitted of guilt anywhere in Europe, it will be our fault. If we here in Europe allow this kind of propaganda to flood us every day, then we will lose Europe, and there are those who say that these kinds of people play in Putin's orchestra. Ladies and gentlemen, this is no longer an chamber orchestra, it is a symphony orchestra that enters our Europe, into our home.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, none of you can say a word against me that I am biased against Poland. Personally, I am a friend of Poland and I will always defend czech-Polish friendship. But to tell you the truth, when I read your proposal for judicial reform, I got a chill on my back. I do not compare Poland in any way and I do not judge in any way. I have also defended you very often, but let us use this debate not to split up and fight together here, but to sit down at the same table and start debating this reform. This is not about us wanting to corner or criticise someone, but we just want to say clearly here that some of the steps in your reform are behind the red line that we in the Czech Republic have not crossed either.

name: Ben HABIB
text: – Mr President, Poland is one of the greatest nations in Europe, and indeed in the European Union. It has a long history of democracy. In fact, it practiced a form of democracy before any other modern nation in the European Union. Poland fought for 45 years for its freedom against the USSR. It is not for an institution which has, itself, appointed a political court – the ECJ has 28 political appointments amongst it, or for an institution which has a government in the form of the Commission that is entirely unelected, to hold to account the Law and Justice party, which has been elected twice to govern Poland on its manifesto, including the reform of its judiciary.  So what I have to say to the Law and Justice party is this: do not put up with the ignominy of this institution. Polexit. You will find a friendship in the United Kingdom. We will support you.  (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Mr Biedroń, i would like to thank you for your comments. For now, it is closer to Belarus and to Russia, because those who support you in the elections are those who are their direct heirs and their, say, pseudo-values. Enough of it! Secondly, who of you has read with understanding at least one law reforming the courts? I bet no one. After today's debate, I believe that this has not happened. Commissioner Jourova, i would like to thank you for your comments. You say, you say that you have to listen to the judges. When will you come to Polish and talk to those affected by the justice system? There are thousands, thousands of them. The last victims are, for example, a man who only inadvertently threw mud and was murdered. Do you know what the judge did? He said they beat so that they didn't want to kill. Do you know that I am also injured as a Member of the Sejm? I burned the parliamentary office. The tormentor is still in the wild, and I and my husband tremmy every day about whether or not they will set fire to our house. And there are thousands of such people, Commissioner Jourova. When you come to Polish, talk to those who are harmed by justice? And that is what I have to say to you. You give yourself a say... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Didier Reynders
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me address some issues raised during the debate, at least about the rule of law in Poland. I would like to come back to yesterday’s decision of the College of Commissioners to request the European Court of Justice to take interim measures in the context of ongoing infringement proceedings, to suspend the functioning of the Disciplinary Chamber of the Supreme Court. As Vice-President Jourová explained, despite the preliminary ruling of the Court of Justice and the judgment of the Supreme Court, ordinary court judges who seek to implement these rulings are subject to disciplinary proceedings, and the Disciplinary Chamber continues to fully operate. In view of the risk of irreparable damage faced by judges in Poland, I instructed the Commission’s Directorate-General for Justice already in December to closely monitor the situation and to prepare the necessary to enable the College to take the decision on interim measures, which was taken yesterday. It was urgent and needed. Regarding the new draft law currently under legislative process in Poland, the Venice Commission is due to provide an opinion. It is important that the recommendations of the Venice Commission are fully implemented in the legislative process. The Commission has invited Polish authorities not to take forward the proceedings on the new draft legislation before carrying out all the necessary consultations. The opinion of the Venice Commission will also feed the Commission assessment. I also again heard calls for a new rule-of-law mechanism. I can reassure you that the Commission will work on a comprehensive European rule-of-law mechanism as a matter of priority. It will cover all Member States and provide a synthesis of significant developments related to the different competences of the rule of law, including, for example, systemic problems with the process for enacting laws, lack of effective judicial protection by independent and impartial courts, the capacity to fight corruption, and issues in relation to media pluralism. This will allow us to identify and prevent early on rule-of-law-related issues. I want to insist, after some remarks, that each justice system is different and must always be looked at in a comprehensive manner. You cannot single out one specific provision from one Member State and compare it with a provision of another Member State without looking at the context of the legal system and the whole system of checks and balances in that Member State. As held by the Court of Justice in its rulings, although the organisation of justice in the Member States falls within the competence of the Member States, the fact remains that, when exercising that competence, the Member States are required to comply with their obligations deriving from EU law. The rule of law is our foundation and can never be compromised. We must ensure that it is respected and upheld everywhere. To conclude, the Commission will continue to monitor the situation in Poland very closely and remains ready to engage in a constructive dialogue with the Polish authorities. The introduction of infringement proceedings does not exclude dialogue. I will be in Zagreb at the informal ministerial meeting of Justice and Home Affairs Ministers on 23 and 24 January. I invite the Polish Minister of Justice, Mr Zbigniew Ziobro, to take advantage of this opportunity and to engage with me in a constructive dialogue.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me assure you once again that the Presidency and the Council as a whole attach great importance to this issue. We believe that only a joint effort by the European Union institutions and the Member States alike will allow the Union to effectively ensure that the rule of law remains the cornerstone of our common project. As I said, the General Affairs Council has discussed the situation in Poland over the last two years, and our Presidency will make sure that it remains seized of the matter. Regarding the question on dealing with the Article 7 procedure in respect of Poland in the Council, you are aware that the Presidency cannot pre-judge the Council’s deliberations, nor the outcome of its procedure. All the recent legislative developments in Poland are being followed, so that the Council can have a full and up-to-date picture of the situation on the ground for its future considerations.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: At the end of the debate, a motion for a resolution was tabled by five political groups on the ongoing hearings under Article 7(1) TEU on Poland and Hungary. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 16 January 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Parliament must be clear: Poland is a country where the rule of law is respected and the public manifestation of political views is protected. I say this not only as an MEP, but also as a former Interior Minister. Recently, there has been a march of those who defend themselves against the democratisation of the judiciary without incident. Although he was in contrast to the current government, he was calm and had proper police protection. The marches of the victims of the judiciary, who support the democratisation of the judiciary, had similar protection. The Polish police are not political. According to cbos research from March last year, 75% of Poles appreciate her work. 90% of my compatriots believe that life is safe in Poland.  Meanwhile, the state of our democracy is judged by Members from countries such as Germany, where the politician of the ruling party, as in Poland, becomes a member of the constitutional court. There it is not controversial, and with us it is called politicization. Similarly, the tone of French politicians is astonishing. The whole of Europe has seen people being cured in the streets and beaten during anti-government demonstrations. Why do you treat Poland as a second-class country to translate? I appeal to the opposition not to drag Europe into internal disputes. Let us talk about the countries of the 'old Union' where cars are burning. Let's talk about those where journalists die. Let us be honest in the debate.

name: Leszek MILLER
