text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Respect for the rule of law in the Member States is fundamental because a smooth and independent judicial system of the European Union guarantees every citizen an equally legal protection regardless of which Member State he or she is in (civis Europaeus sum).  The fundamental link in this system is national courts, which, together with the Court of Justice, are the key to deepening European integration and integration by law. A law whose meaning and substance goes beyond the application and interpretation of the Treaties (Article 19(1) second sentence of the TOU) and prejudges the autonomous nature of the EU legal order. In this context, every aspect of the functioning of the European Union and the loyal cooperation of the Member States requires absolute assurance of judicial independence, so that the court can always objectively and without fear of possible sanctions to assess whether Union law is applied in a given case and how to ensure its effectiveness properly.  In Poland, unfortunately, for a long time there have been increasingly audacious attempts to subjugate the judiciary to the ruling majority. The Constitutional Court has been in breach of the law, the system of institutional discipline of judges has been expanded and legislation is proposed restricting the freedom of judges to rule and apply EU law. I therefore believe that the European Parliament cannot remain passive and must take a clear position, as only the Union still has any way of stopping the authoritarian impulses of an absolute parliamentary majority in Poland.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the resumption of prosecution proceedings against the Prime Minister of the Czech Republic for the misuse of EU funds and potential conflicts of interest (2019/2987(RSP)).

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me first assure you that the Council attaches great importance to making sure that EU funds are used according to the rules and that expenditure respects the principle of sound financial management. I am aware of allegations, including in the media, against the Czech Prime Minister regarding a possible conflict of interest in respect of EU subsidies from the European Structural and Investment funds. I also understand that the Czech authorities are further investigating the case. You will understand that it is not for the Council to comment on ongoing national investigations. Let me therefore stress here that it is important to let the judicial instances do their work properly. I’m also aware that the Commission, as they indicated in the plenary in December, has conducted an audit, and I will listen to what the Commission will tell us today. Let me assure you that we agree that it is of the utmost importance that strong mechanisms are applied to protect the Union’s financial interests and to make sure that the money is spent in an appropriate and lawful way. The Council has therefore strongly supported different initiatives that strengthen the protection of the Union’s financial interests, such as the creation of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, which will become operational later this year, or the Directive on the Fight against Fraud to the Union’s Financial Interests by means of Criminal Law. While I cannot provide any Council views on specific cases of fraud or corruption allegations, I will carefully listen to your debate.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members thank you for the opportunity for the Commission to present the state of play in this matter. Let me start by making three points very clear. First, the Commission has zero tolerance for fraud or misuse of EU funds. Second, the Commission always diligently follows up on information or complaints with respect to conflict of interest in all Member States. Third, the Commission has been and is taking broad and coordinated action with respect to alleged conflicts of interest in the Czech Republic. What are the facts, and where are we in the audit procedure? The Commission services carried out audits in the Czech Republic in January and February 2019. These audits relate to the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. They are currently at different stages of the procedure. The audits for the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund are now in the follow-up stage. The final audit report provided to the Czech authorities does not represent the final step of the audit process for the European Regional Development Fund and the European Social Fund. The contents of the final audit report should therefore remain confidential until the procedure is closed. This means until the Commission has taken a final position as appropriate, in relation to the follow-up that the audit team will give to it. For the rural development investment measures, the Commission has communicated its letter of findings to the Member States, including preliminary conclusions and recommendations to avoid any situation of conflict of interest in the future. The contradictory procedure is ongoing, and the next step is a bilateral meeting with the Czech authorities. For all funds, the whole procedure until adoption of possible financial corrections can take up to 24 months. Confidentiality of the audit is a basic principle and of utmost importance. The Commission must ensure a fair and robust process. Former Commissioner Oettinger and now Commissioner Hahn have shared preliminary information with the Committee on Budgetary Control of this House, in camera. Under the confidentiality rules, I will therefore not comment on the substance of the audit findings today. Let me assure you that, while the audits go on, the EU budget is fully protected. No payments from the EU budget under the European structural and investment funds are being made to projects that could potentially be concerned by alleged conflict of interest. In relation to the Rural Development Fund, the Commission is not reimbursing to Czech authorities the amounts related to projects that could be potentially concerned by the alleged conflict of interest. Let me now say a few words on the Stork’s Nest project. The Commission and the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) have reacted promptly to investigate potential fraud with respect to EU funding for the Stork’s Nest project. In December 2017, OLAF finalised its investigation. It recommended to the Commission to recover the full subsidy. OLAF also recommended to the competent Czech judicial authorities to take into account all of the findings in the ongoing national judicial investigation. The Czech authorities withdrew the project from EU financing and recovered the funds from the beneficiary. Consequently, there was no impact on either the EU or the national budget. The ongoing national judicial investigation is the exclusive competence of the Czech authorities. Finally, as regards the situation in other Member States, the Commission will equally follow up on allegations of non-resolved conflicts of interest in other Member States. In addition, the Commission is providing support to all Member States to correctly implement measures aimed at avoiding conflicts of interest.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: for the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, representatives of the European Council, this debate is aimed at audits and investigations, but nevertheless, let us take it a little more generally. Let us talk about the principle of the European Union. We have been assured several times by Commissioner Hahn that they are all measured on the same meter. I will tell you the experience of how it happens in the Czech Republic, for example, when there is an error in drawing on a European subsidy. A financial control is immediately initiated, the payment is immediately claimed back and immediately if you have violated the laws of the Czech Republic, you will be prosecuted. But that's just not the case.  We have made some new regulation, in which Prime Minister Andrej Babiš, by the way, was also involved as Finance Minister, and this regulation, suddenly when it concerns him, we cannot enforce it. The Council has said that it will not interfere with the ongoing investigation, which is what we expect, but we want a clear view from the Council as to whether the Prime Minister can really , in the light of the audit report and the confidential information provided to certain media outlets in relation to it, take part in the investigation and in the adoption of the new budget. And that is what this debate should show. Otherwise, I was supposed to have a minute and a half on the schedule, so I don't know if that was the case.

name: Lara WOLTERS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, in November, over 200 000 people took to the streets in a demonstration against Prime Minister Babiš in Prague, and afterwards Mr Babiš insisted that that demonstration – as well as the investigation by the European Commission – are all part of an undemocratic plot against him. I disagree with that ridiculous conspiracy theory. The Commission is doing its democratic and its legal duty, and more particularly, its duty towards the Czech citizens that are demanding justice.  The leaked Commission audit of December is dry and factual, and it establishes that Mr Babiš is in a clear conflict of interests, as he’s using taxpayer money to enrich himself. The millions in question have to be paid back, and we need that new rule of law mechanism that’s been proposed to ensure the independence of the national bodies that the EU has to rely on. Let’s stand up for Czech citizens today, and let’s make the EU budget autocrat—proof.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: for renew. – Mr President, who knows me – and many of those fellow Members are sitting here today – knows that I have never resisted constructive debate on any subject. But if the debate is to be constructive, it must be built on solid foundations. And that condition is not met here today. We have no more than impressions, prejudices, perhaps personal animosity and, above all, we are transferring the domestic political battle from the Czech Republic to EU soil. Let's summarize what we're talking about. As regards the audit – and the Commissioner has said this here – standard communication is taking place between the Czech Republic and the European Commission. In other matters, standard work of Czech law enforcement authorities takes place, a standard process takes place at the level of Czech justice. Let us honor the presumption of innocence. Because no matter what conclusions we come to here today, these processes will continue.  In such a situation, this point is completely irrelevant to me on the agenda, devoid of meaning and justification. Therefore, I have no choice but to state that the debate carries a political overtone and that, unfortunately, the hard work of some of my Czech opposition colleagues has been heard. However, I find it inappropriate and extremely unfortunate in terms of the credibility of our work that the European Parliament is being drawn into national political competition.

name: Viola VON CRAMON-TAUBADEL
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The situation in the Czech Republic is worrying. One of the richest people in the Czech Republic, Andrej Babic, decides on the policy of that country and at the same time he votes in the European Council on the agricultural and structural policy that has made him rich. This is traditionally called a conflict of interest. But we should not be deceived. It is not the cause of the problem, it is just a symptom. Nevertheless, he is paralysing the country, he has his fingers in it everywhere. In addition to politics, he is gradually taking over the media and a number of economic sectors. He also has strong economic interests in other EU countries, from Hungary to Slovakia to Germany. Nevertheless, he is just one of many oligarchs who have become rich thanks to EU funds. The shocking thing is that we do not even know exactly to what extent Babic and other oligarchs benefit from the European Union budget. Because neither the Commission nor the Member States have enough information to be able to track exactly where the money from the agricultural budget or the Structural Funds actually ends up. We urgently need more transparency. We need a new system to stop this abuse and misallocation of EU subsidies. Without clear rules in the event of conflicts of interest, without rules on property disclosure and without strong conditionality, we will continue to keep this corrupt system alive. But even without political pressure to unravel the nested corporate networks on the land market and to bring to light the landowners who are really behind it, we will not solve this problem. Democratisation and the end of communism have led to enormous changes in land ownership in many countries, and unfortunately it is clear that it is often not the people actually working in the agricultural sector who benefit most from privatisations, but it was the economic and political elite. It has determined the rules, and in the end it has made use of state property. And the EU is making this historical injustice even worse, because in these countries a large part of the payments go to very few landowners and not to those whose existence should actually be preserved with agricultural subsidies.

name: Ivan DAVID
text: For the ID Group. – Mr President, I am not a supporter of Prime Minister of the Czech Republic Andrej Babiš, but I care about democracy. Prime Minister Babiš graduated from the privileged Faculty of Foreign Trade, joined the Communist Party and cooperated with the Secret Service, fulfilled the conditions for representing the Czech Republic abroad. As an expert on the environment during the great privatization after 1989, he seized huge production capacities, first in the chemical industry, then in the food industry and agriculture. He later bought a significant part of the Czech media. Thanks to skilful professional marketing and the inability of competing political parties, he and his political project YES got into the Czech Parliament and government at the first attempt in 2013. He won the next election well in advance and became Prime Minister. His companies received large-scale European subsidies.  Political competition has never accepted defeat. She forced the Prime Minister to legally put his firms into a trust. A standard billionaire promotes his own advantage through corruption of politicians and their parties. The Prime Minister founded a company that set up an entertainment business with European subsidies. He seems to have unethically circumvented the rules. But let an independent court consider that. The media persecution of Prime Minister Babiš and street rallies against a government backed by the prime minister's opposition certainly cost a lot of money. But the prime minister's party's preferences have not been down, rather the opposite. He would win the new elections with the upper hand.  The real cause of the current situation is the European Union system, which allows corruption through subsidies to private enterprises. Instead of competition, competition for subsidies, which are an instrument ensuring dependence on and thus maintaining the EU system, is taking place. Solving possible criminal cases on a political platform is also a typically totalitarian practice. That's what's being done here now.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Commissioner, let us be blunt, there is corruption in European funds. As chairman of the Committee on Regional Development, I mean that an unrelenting fight must be waged against corruption on the Structural Funds because it is about the credibility of our policy and it is also about confidence in the European institutions. And in this struggle, you will find us and you will find me by your side, as you will find me and you will find us at your side so that consequences are given to cases of conflicts of interest and suspicions of fraud, if not corruption, in the Czech Republic. We have a European Public Prosecutor's Office to improve this fight. The head of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, Mrs Kuvesi, has just been appointed, and what do we learn? That its means are not up to the task that must be waged, that is why we must work towards the budgetary independence of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. The latter will only be fully independent and can aim for its objectives if it has the means to be able to carry out this essential fight against corruption on the CAP and on the structural funds to protect our European budget.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, this discussion, Mrs Charanzova, is not an internal Czech discussion, and I believe that this will explain my speech alongside that of Mrs Von Cramon-Taubadel.  I am not concerned with the details of the way in which the judiciary within the Czech Republic proceeds. We do not dispute any investigations or judicial procedures, but I have two questions, and I would ask the Commission and the Council for their support. The first point is that European funding must not promote oligarchic structures, which means that we must promote and clarify both the issue of 'conflict of interest', Article 61, and – let me call it this – 'anti-oligarch legislation' within our European institutions. And the second thing we need to clarify is: how much European funding can a single person receive within a year and within an MFF? Otherwise, we become implausible when one person gets 100, 200, 300, 400 million and other people perhaps just 5 000. Then the imbalance is too great.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The resumption of the indictment of the Czech Prime Minister for embezzlement of EU funds is important. Our taxpayers' money should not be used for cheating and fiddling. If you do that, you should know that negative consequences are around the corner.  But the problem is big. That is why it is important that we also talk about the major problem of corruption that exists in many parts of europe. Unfortunately, what the Czech Prime Minister has done is just one example. Corruption, fraud and misappropriation of money occur in many parts of the EU. We also know that it hinders development and human rights. It is therefore of the utmost importance that the European Commission takes its duties as a reviewer very seriously.  I want to see a Europe free from corruption and cheating. Europe should be based on justice and community. Our common resources should be used for these purposes and not end up in the pockets of greedy and corrupt people. Zero tolerance must be the goal here. That is the only way we maintain confidence and keep europe together.

name: Ondřej KNOTEK
text: – Mr President, I am happy to set the record straight. Prime Minister Babiš initiated the creation of the ANO anti-corruption movement in 2011. People vote for him because he works hard and he's incorruptible. The subsidy under prosecution took place in 2008, but the impetus for criminal proceedings came only in 2016. Of the original 11 defendants, only two remain. In September 2019, the prosecution of the Prime Minister was even stopped. But the Attorney General needed to add some information and dropped the prosecution.  The conflict of interest procedure shall be between the Commission and the Member State. It has been made clear that the politicisation of this procedure is very unprofessive to the whole thing. The Prime Minister followed the law, transferred the companies to a trust. However, there is a contradiction in the interpretation of the concept of 'conflict of interest'. Let the experts deal with it, not the opposition politicians. In conclusion, the European Parliament's soil has been poorly used to devolv the domestic political situation, and those who do so are damaging the EU in the eyes of Czech citizens.

name: Mikuláš PEKSA
text: – Mr President, it is quite difficult to follow up with something new after the debates on Poland and Hungary. Unfortunately, I think that Andrej Babiš should be the last wake-up call to remind us that it is really time to step up, because the situation, the setting up of our mechanisms for controlling financial flows within the European Union, is simply not good. The way andrej Babiš bypassed the European conflict of interest regulation is, in principle, very primitive. He simply transferred his companies to a trust, which he controls through his relatives and can essentially cancel at any time. This is basically a very trivial trick and primitive action by a salon impostor. But let's take a look at the other part. Andrej Babiš is the owner of one of the largest economic groups within the Czech Republic and receives a very significant part of European subsidies. He uses this money to spread his influence within the Czech Republic and to maintain his position. Here, the European Union directly finances his political campaign for the Chamber of Deputies of the Czech Republic, the European Parliament and other institutions through Agrofert. This is a problem, because the state then acts as a lawyer for Andrej Babiš and unfortunately not only protects him, but also protects other friendly businessmen or politicians, or as you want to call them, who operate in a similar way in other countries. In the European Council, when we talk about any more serious measures, we need unanimity, and unfortunately, if the oligarchs are covering for each other, we will never be able to achieve that.

name: Hynek BLAŠKO
text: – Mr President, the citizens of the Czech Republic are tired of the constant debate of Prime Minister Babiš. I would like to point out that the more often his cases are dealt with, the more electoral preferences he has. Please allow the Czech ordinary courts to rule. There is no one in the European Parliament who can point to Babiš and say, 'You are guilty'. This is an internal matter for the Czech Republic and its courts, including the electorate. Are there really no more important issues in this Parliament?  This Parliament promotes gender balance. That is why I have no choice but to ask for the establishment of a commission to deal with the work of the President of the European Commission von den Leyen, who was also shadowed by the suspicion that everything she did at the Ministry of Defence of the Federal Republic of Germany was not clean and also that she had a conflict of interest. The Commission should either remove or confirm this shadow of suspicion and, on the basis of the results of the investigation, the Chairwoman should accept political responsibility.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, it was said earlier by one Member here, I think it was Ms Charanzová, that there are prejudices at play here. There are no prejudices from me, I can guarantee you. All I want, if money has gone astray, is that the money is returned. It has nothing to do with prejudice at all. People scrimp and scrape money together to pay their taxes, and it ends up coming here. We’ve got to make sure that that money goes back to the right people. I believe the proposed cuts in the MFF to agriculture and rural development were made possible because European citizens don’t believe the money is going to the right people. This just adds to that. We cannot monitor every last cent of CAP money once it ends up in the nation state. However, we can create the architecture under the current review process to make sure that it is as difficult as possible for the money to go astray – whether that be legitimately or illegitimately – because currently there’s money going astray, and it’s actually legal to do it. We’ve got to nail that too – big subsidies to people who should not get it.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, the EU budget is money paid in by the people of the European Union. This is why it is our duty, as Members of the European Parliament, to defend it, to spend it with care, and to make sure that it is well spent. Any conflict of interests or misuse of EU funds is unacceptable – even more so if it is done by a prime minister. This is an attack upon the people’s money. It’s unacceptable.  What do we have to do? The first thing is that we have to recover the money and make sure that all amounts under investigation are returned to the EU budget. This is why we have the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and this is why we have created the European Public Prosecutor: to be strong, to be independent, and to be active in exactly such cases. It is important that the companies of Mr Babiš – and I underline this – return those amounts, and not the citizens of the Czech Republic as a whole. If there was any criminal offence, we must make sure that it is duly investigated. Beyond the judicial consequences, there is of course also the political responsibility which belongs to the party of Mr Babiš and to his group in the European Parliament, the Renew Group.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have this impression after hearing the President-in-Office of the Council say that the Council recognises that this is not a matter for the Council, and take this problem somewhere there. The Commissioner has presented a great procedure, which has been going on for many years, concerns several items of many funds and finally says that these procedures will still take up to 24 months. So the first reflection – too long, and from the basic institutions of the three, it turns out that the European Parliament is only admonishing. I would like to be clear, this is not about politics, it is simply about money fairly, as Mrs Hohlmeier said, they are used or misused, that is, they are misused and are to be returned, and that is not what the Czech courts should consider, but the European institutions. On the other hand, we have heard from David that Prime Minister Babish is an extremely gifted, perhaps the most business-gifted prime minister in the European Union.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am very grateful, also to the Commission, for having given such a cautious opinion on these allegations and these issues that arise here in the Babic case, where various investigations are taking place. We should wait for this investigation before making any pre-judgments. If we do not do that, we will automatically be accused of having a debate on envy here, and that is not what we want. Nor do we want to be annoyed that Mr Babic is perhaps raising a number of contradictory points, that he disagrees with the EU on border security, migration, cutting red tape or maintaining the Czech crown. We really should be neutral on this whole issue and wait for the investigation. At most, we should ask ourselves whether the rules we have given ourselves still fit, or whether we should perhaps even abolish these subsidies altogether.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Mr President, Council, Commission, I really ask you to listen very carefully to what I will say. This is extremely harmful to the European Union. This is extremely damaging to the public image of the Union.  Theoretically speaking, the Babiš case is not even the only one of such huge proportions. We only know what happened inside one country, and we know that he is an oligarch. But it’s really not about about Babiš, is what I wanted to say. I want to say this: if the financial regulation Article 61 is not a sufficient base, then we have to change it, and we have to change it fast. We need true powers for the European Union to bring an end to this, and EPO deserves all the needed resources to do that.

name: Angelika WINZIG
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Fraud and corruption must not find a place in our EU. We owe this above all to our taxpayers. I would like to say just one thing: Mr David has now left the Chamber, but if he is already doing general business bashing, this is a conflict of interest between politics and entrepreneurship. As an entrepreneur and politician, it is quite clear to me that I do not use public funding during my term of office or participate in any public tenders. For a politician, criminal law simply cannot be the moral authority. Our Chancellor, Kurz, would also not approve of us in his group driving this double track. Yes, now it is time to clarify quickly, demand transparency and, if repayments are to be made, to get them done quickly. In any case, the citizens of the Czech Republic will decide on the political consequences in the future.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Honourable President-in-Office, the transparent absorption of European funds is our common cause. This is not a matter for an individual country, especially when individual cases are also published in newspapers such as the New York Times, which was the case for Mr Babiš. Agricultural and rural development funds are not funds for enriching oligarchs, but are funds earmarked for family farms. And the money improperly spent or obtained must be easily returned. I also support the proposal made by the previous Commissioner Hogan to limit the maximum in the future financial perspective and that this amount is so small that it will come in handy for the development of family farms, not that this money will benefit either a wide range of oligarchs or the royal family. That way, we will not get the trust of European voters. As long as the money goes into that hands. Therefore, the money must be spent transparently and the money received incorrectly returned.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I think it is logical that the European Parliament is debating the Case of Andrej Babiš if he is one of the largest buyers of European subsidies in the Czech Republic. It is European money, european taxpayers' money, and it is therefore logical that the representatives of European countries, European Members, want to have a debate on this. After all, it is not normal for one of the richest Czechs to draw money for poor regions and for small and medium-sized enterprises. Commissioner, I ask and call on you to see that the matter is properly investigated. Secondly, I ask you to publish audit reports as soon as possible. Citizens in the Czech Republic want to know exactly what is in these audit reports. And they have every right to be. They have a right to know what their Prime Minister is doing, how he is breaking the law and whether he has a major conflict of interest. The Czech judiciary will decide whether he is criminally responsible, not us. And please do your best to ensure that this case never arises. So that the oligarchs will never make European money again.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, believe me, as a Czech Member, I am not really interested in the fact that the conflict of interest of the Czech Prime Minister is being discussed repeatedly here. I'm sorry. On the other hand, I fully understand my colleagues in the European Parliament that they are demanding control over European funds. The European Commission's audit repeatedly found a conflict of interest between the Czech Prime Minister and the unauthorised use of EU funds by his companies. The Commissioner stated that the money for the Stork's Nest had been returned to the European budget, so there was no damage to either the EU or the Czech Republic. Yes, Commissioner, but I remember very well when the First Words of the Czech Prime Minister on this case were this: 'I know nothing about this project, I have nothing to do with it'. And only after the investigation, under great pressure, did the Prime Minister remember. The European Parliament is not a court, we are not judging, we just want a really thorough investigation, because the European budget must be controlled and only drawn by authorised persons.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me conclude first of all by stressing very clearly that the Commission has zero tolerance for fraud or misuse of EU funds. I know this House fully supports the Commission in its fight against corruption in the structural funds. We need to ensure that public money is properly spent.  Let me recall that the Commission presented a proposal in May 2018 on the protection of the Union’s budget in cases of generalised defiance as regards the rule of law in the Member States. The proposal provides for a mechanism to reduce or suspend EU funding in cases of defiance of the rule of law. For instance, the following situations may lead to misuse of the EU funds or would prevent the application of the control mechanism in case of misuse of funds: threats to the independence of the judiciary system, arbitrary or unlawful decisions by public authorities, limited availability and effectiveness of legal remedies, failure to implement judgments, or limitations on effective investigation, prosecution or sanctions for breaches of law. The Commission’s top priority is to protect the EU budget. The Commission has zero tolerance for fraud or misuse of EU funds.  With respect to the allegations of conflicts of interests in the Czech Republic, the EU budget is fully protected. No payments from the EU budget under the European structural and investment funds are being made to projects that could potentially be concerned by the alleged conflict of interests. In relation to the Rural Development Fund, the Commission is not reimbursing the Czech authorities for the amounts related to projects that could be potentially affected by alleged conflict of interests. With respect to the reopening of the prosecution, the ongoing national judicial investigation is the exclusive competence of the Czech authorities. As the Czech authorities withdrew the product from EU financing, there was no impact on the EU budget. The Commission is committed to keeping the Parliament informed.

name: Nikolina Brnjac
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me reiterate the importance the Council attaches to the protection of the Union’s financial interests and to the need to make sure that money is spent in an appropriate and lawful way. The investigation into individual cases in allegation is the task of the national prosecutor and judges, and of the European Anti Fraud Office – and, soon, also of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. I have taken careful note of your concerns, as well as the indicators provided by the Commissioner.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The motions for resolutions to be tabled pursuant to Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure will be announced at a later date. The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the February 2020 part-session. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Writing. – The voice of Czech citizens against Prime Minister Babiš, who is accused of large financial abuses of EU funds, is the loudest call for democracy in the history of an independent Czech Republic. We have to listen to him. Babiš's argument that he will not leave because he is stubborn is immature, and the statement that the European Commission is not an appropriate authority is an underprice.  If the European Commission has sufficient authority to allocate money, it is also good enough to check its spending together with the Court of Auditors and to draw attention to abuses. I call on you, regardless of political colour, to support citizens demanding the immediate resignation of Prime Minister Babiš and to support the European Commission, which demands the reimbursement of subsidies.  This is the only real way to take responsibility and the only option if we want to maintain the transparency and democracy that the Czech Republic deserves.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the Conference of the Parties (COP 15) of the Convention on Biological Diversity (Kunming 2020) (2019/2824(RSP)).

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, in November, this Parliament declared the climate an environment emergency. The devastating bush fires in Australia, the recent fires in the Amazon and Siberia, the droughts in Europe last summer, as well as the dramatic decline in pollinators – this all sadly illustrates the need to act. The European Commission has taken it seriously, and one of its first decisions has been to launch the European Green Deal, the new agenda for sustainable growth in the European Union, tackling the most serious climate and environmental challenges of our times. This Commission wants the European Union to lead on both climate neutrality and the road to the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on Biological Diversit (CBD) in Kunming in October 2020, where the world is to agree on the post—2020 global biodiversity framework.  I welcome the fact that the European Parliament fully supports this ambition. For the European Union, it means leading by example and therefore developing our own European commitments. The European Union Biodiversity Strategy 2030, which we will adopt by March 2020, will include proposals for such EU commitments and will set out our ambition for Kunming, including on global targets. Preparations for this strategy are currently going on at full speed within the Commission, and the resolution which you will adopt tomorrow will be an important input and inspiration for our own reflections and upcoming decisions. We failed twice to achieve our past ten-year biodiversity targets; we cannot allow ourselves to fail again.  Science is perfectly clear that we need a holistic approach for transformative change to address the climate and environment emergency. This should be the spirit for our preparations for CBD COP15, as well as for our work under the European Green Deal. As regards the post-2020 global biodiversity framework, we fully support the European Parliament’s demand for a stronger implementation mechanism and strengthen tools for accountability. We need a systemic and regular cycle for reviewing implementation of the committed actions and progress in reducing the pressures on biodiversity. We should agree on one or a small number of clear overarching long-term goals, similar to the 1.5-degree objective for climate change, in order to maintain political support through the period. We should also kick-start the cycle immediately. Parties should respond to the global framework by 2021, allowing a stocktaking of actions and commitments at COP16 in 2022, at least for the most important issues.  Finally, the monitoring and indicator framework should include headline indicators that are common across parties and hence allow an assessment of the national contributions to achieving the global targets. A stronger implementation and review mechanism will boost work under many environmental agreements. Let me highlight, in this context, the synergies with our important work on international ocean governance, and in particular with our ongoing negotiations on a new international treaty under the UN Convention of the Law of the Sea to protect marine biodiversity in the high seas.  It is essential to ensure the means of implementation. The European Union and its Member States collectively lived up to the international commitment to double international biodiversity financing to developing countries. We need financial flows from all sources to benefit nature and biodiversity more, including by mobilising domestic resources. Let me stress three further important aspects in this context. First, the world still spends much more on subsidies that are harmful to biodiversity than it spends on pro-biodiversity action. We need much more progress on phasing out the subsidies and reshaping them to ensure that they are compatible and supportive to biodiversity conservation. Secondly, restoration of ecosystems is typically more expensive than conservation. The quicker we protect the remaining valuable nature and we address the drivers of biodiversity loss, the less we will need to restore, if possible, and the cheaper it will be.  Finally, we need to massively scale-up investments in climate—resilient, nature-based solutions which multiply benefits for biodiversity, climate—change mitigation and adaptation, food security, and finally, of course, health. For the European Union, leading by example means that we should make strong commitments to better protect and climate-proof the biodiversity—rich areas, to restore degraded ecosystems in nature across rural and urban landscapes, to sustainably use and manage our agricultural, forest and ocean resources, and to integrate biodiversity across policies and sectors, including in our outermost regions and territories.  We need to make sure that we deliver on our commitments, this time by creating the adequate enabling environment, from full implementation and enforcement of the EU’s nature legislation to potentially developing new legislation for restoring nature, mainstreaming biodiversity and providing adequate financing. The next multiannual financial framework will be crucial in this regard. We need to guarantee that adequate resources are provided for the protection, restoration and sustainable use of ecosystems through the core EU funding instruments, such as the common agricultural policy, cohesion and regional funds, Horizon Europe, the external action financial instrument and LIFE. We need to ensure that such funding leverages private funding through investEU.  We need to ensure a just transition where the necessary transformational change do not leave anyone behind. This means we have to support, for example, our farmers, forest managers and fishermen and women along this transition. We also need to avoid exporting the damage of biodiversity outside the European Union by consuming unsustainably produced and traded products. This is why the future EU biodiversity strategy will need to address sustainable consumption and production, a reduction of the EU’s ecological footprint and the integration of biodiversity into our trade policy.  We also need to engage much better with our international partners and various stakeholders. For example, we need to work with businesses and financial actors with the tools to account for their biodiversity dependency and impacts, so that they can take the right measures to support and contribute to biodiversity.  The window of opportunity to achieve our global biodiversity vision to live in harmony with nature is narrowing fast, and the next years will be crucial. Knowing the time it takes to get to implementation, this Commission is very aware of its responsibility during its five-year mandate. You can count on our full commitment to work hard and achieve our common objective.

name: Agnès EVREN
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, the UN proposed on Monday to protect 30% of the planet by 2030. For COP 15, 17 objectives are thus advanced to enhance the value of life, reduce our impact on nature or link climate and biodiversity, which are two sides of the same coin: that of the survival of our planet. I agree with all of these objectives. Unlike those of Aichi, who have remained wishful thinking alas, this draft finally presents precise and numerical objectives with means of follow-up. This is also what we are defending in our resolution, but let us go even further: we want these objectives to be legally binding so that they do not go unheeded. Let us make COP 15 the equivalent of the Paris climate agreement and, from now on, let us take concrete action on European territory. I call on the European Commission in the strategy it will present in March to take such binding targets itself and to intensify efforts across its policies. Let us increase our protected areas, develop more support for research and innovation, massively support our farmers, fishermen and forestry in the transition to more sustainable practices. Responsibility also lies with the Member States, but also with each territorial community. Let us not wait until October, now is the time to act.

name: César LUENA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr. President, thank you. Thank you, Commissioner, for your presentation. First of all, I would like to make a reminder as a thank you, when talking about the fight against climate change, but also about the global protection of biodiversity, scientists and activists. I believe that this Parliament has to thank them, because thanks to them there is a level of awareness and also of current political commitment to science and environmentalists. Look, I'm going to quickly tell you some data. Since 1900, the average abundance of native species in most major terrestrial habitats has declined," you hear, by at least 20%. More than 40% of amphibian species, nearly 33% of reef corals and more than a third of all marine mammals are threatened; 10% of insects as well. This is the sixth mass extinction of species.  What do the citizens of the European Union think? Well, according to the latest polls, 96% say that nature needs to be protected and that responsibility is everyone's responsibility. Therefore, protecting life on our planet and responding to the demands of citizens have been the priorities with which the Social Democrats have approached this resolution.  And I'm going to tell you seven points very quickly. The ecological transition, ladies and gentlemen, has to be fair. We must prevent new inequalities from being created. Second, environmental taxation. I won't get tired of saying it in this House. We need enough resources. A new green tax model. The one who pollutes the most has to pay more. Deforestation — and this is very important — the European Union has to legislate to achieve deforestation-free supply chains. We have to fight the illegal logging of forests. The agreement, as the rapporteur of the People's Party has also said, to be adopted in China has to be binding, because otherwise we will have achieved nothing. The increase in protected areas to 30% by 2030 to 50% by 2050 is very important. And finally, too, reduce the percentage of pesticides. Achieve a percentage— rather — for the reduction of pesticides. Ladies and gentlemen, we don't have another planet. This is the planet on which the species, human beings are and on which we live and, therefore, also from the point of view of our species, we have to help the planet in the protection of biodiversity. It is very important that tomorrow's resolution be powerful to go to China with a united and strong voice in biodiversity protection.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Europe, the European Union, is facing unprecedented environmental challenges and biodiversity loss is one of them. As already said, we are witnessing a truly emergency situation because 73% of terrestrial ecosystems in the European Union and 40% of maritime ecosystems are in a situation of degradation and risk. In fact, we may be entering a stage that we can call the sixth mass extinction – and the European Environment Agency says so – because the number of species that are extinct day by day is the largest that has ever existed throughout human history. Therefore, we have great challenges. We have to deal with them, and that is what Parliament wants to do with this resolution, to ask the Commission for greater ambition in the new biodiversity protection strategy and for that greater ambition in our European strategy to be the cover letter at the next COP 15 meeting in China. Legally binding targets to protect natural areas, 30% by 2030, half of the planet by 2050; legally binding targets to restore vastly degraded areas and degraded habitats at risk of extinction. To do this we must also have more budget. You can't have more ambition with less budget. 10% of the new financial framework has to be specifically associated with biodiversity protection and, of course, we need to work together with all the actors who have to do with the decisive elements for biodiversity protection. Farmers, fishermen are partners.  No objective of the Paris Agreement of the European Green Pact will succeed if we are not ambitious in this new biodiversity strategy.

name: Ville NIINISTÖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the world’s biodiversity is reeling and it’s manmade. We are not just destroying living conditions by increasing climate change, but also through the overconsumption of resources, overexploitation and the way we are producing our livelihoods – that is affecting the whole future of biodiversity and the flora and fauna of this planet. The world’s top scientists are warning that even a million species will disappear from the planet by 2030 if we don’t act and change our behaviour.  So it’s obvious that the COP meeting on biodiversity has to be a similar meeting as Paris was for climate. We need legally binding targets because none of the previous targets we’ve had globally have been met. So we need implementation, we need a legally binding process, so that all countries will increase their protected areas and will change the way their economies work. That’s why in the European Parliament and in the Green group we want to push for a 30% target for both marine and terrestrial protection that will also affect and apply to European Union countries. That’s what the Commission should work on so that we also, as the first big actor in the COP meeting, will say that we are prepared to do this within Europe – make it legally binding. We need to restore also areas that are damaged. This is a big part of protecting diversity and reversing the state of biodiversity. That also has to be included in the targets. Finally, I would like to mention a totally different big ethical challenge that has to do with human technology – that applies to gene drives. There are companies and organisations developing a technology that can wipe out fauna – a whole population of mosquitoes, for example – if it’s prematurely put into nature and we Greens want a moratorium on this technology so that it’s not used in a way which has harmful consequences that are totally unknown and could be totally unprecedented. (Applause)

name: Aurelia BEIGNEUX
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, COP 15, which will take place in October, will have to set targets for the next ten years for biodiversity. We must not hide our faces about climate change: human activity is obviously responsible. But rather than systematically moralizing citizens and acting only through taxation, is it not politics that should be blamed? We bitterly note that neither the change in the economic model, nor the questioning of free trade treaties, nor the need to restore internal and external borders to the European Union appear to be your priorities in protecting the environment. Yes, we are responsible for our lifestyles and consumption patterns, but our individual efforts are still very little if there is no major change in breaking with the dominant ideology. There is an urgent need: we are witnessing the disappearance of species that are directly affected by climatic and environmental phenomena. The situation of the Poles and Australia sadly reminds us of this. The health of our compatriots is threatened by air pollution, water pollution, land pollution, performance logics and the pressure of financial power. Why blame the citizen who needs his vehicle to work, when the shipping companies, which produce more CO2 than the automobile transport, have no obligation to reduce their emissions? With treaties passed here, poorly produced goods are imported on the other side of the world. Thanks to treaties voted here, we allow the extension of the use of GMOs or the use of pesticides that CETA offers us on a platter, such as atrazine. You say you defend biodiversity, but you tell me that ritual slaughter is not a problem, given the freedom of religion. However, there is no demand for any guarantees on the fate of the cattle exported. The ecology must be real and not just the display. Greenwashing and worldliness only clear the real culprits of the troubles of our time.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I think that the protection of the biodiversity is key and the time for this debate is timely organised because, just today, the World Economic Forum has published a report about the terrible biodiversity losses all over the world. The problem is that it’s not so much in Europe. It’s outside of Europe. The papers which are being prepared here in this building, beyond some important recommendations and measures such as to protect the habitats, to contain the borders, how to revitalise the forests, are, unfortunately, also filled with many regulatory socialist measures, which I think, at the end, would not be so helpful and could bring, on the contrary, a lot of harm. As an example, there are these iconic carnivores with a problem to cope with mankind: lions, tigers and wolf. So lions and tigers, because they are living in underdeveloped countries, they have the problems, while the wolf, in northern countries, including Europe, is now protected and extending its range, expanding its numbers. Take the steps which would bring good and not harm.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, biodiversity is not only an intmanity, but also an essential element in adapting to climate change. The stronger the biodiversity, the better our planet's adaptability to the inevitable warming ahead. We must recognise that we are in a state of emergency. Biodiversity is deteriorating at an alarming rate. It is therefore sad and incredible that the EU failed so badly in its biodiversity targets for 2020.  Repatriation is important, but first we must be able to stop it deteriorating. In order to put an end to the loss of diversity, we need to address the root causes. They can be found in both agriculture, forestry and land use changes. The common agricultural policy must be reformed to meet both the Paris Agreement and biodiversity objectives. The reform of agricultural subsidies, as now proposed, does not do this. We need to move on to organic farming techniques and away from monoculture farming.  Forestry is also a key element. 80% of species live in our forests and how we use our forests is absolutely essential for diversity. Much is said about deforestation and afforestation is offered, but afforestation is not the solution to the loss of diversity. The species can only become extinct once and at present a record number of species are threatened by extinction. The new 2030 strategy must include binding and measurable targets and increase the number of protected areas to at least 30% and restore at least 30% of weakened ecosystems by 2030.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this resolution clearly represents the dramatic scale of the ecological emergency we are experiencing. It is in the eyes of all of us that the decline of nature globally is unprecedented in human history, with the acceleration of the extinction rate of a myriad of species and the threat of extinction that now affects a further million species of animals and plants. Extreme weather phenomena caused by ongoing climate change make the impact on biodiversity loss even more damaging. It is peacefully recognised that the current trend has devastating consequences for the whole of mankind and is likely to undermine the achievement of 80 % of the Sustainable Development Goals, with huge increases in levels of poverty, food insecurity and damage to human health. Faced with all this, the least that the current European Commission can do for the next COP 15 in China and in the launch of the new EU biodiversity strategy for 2030 is to interpret the overcoming of the logic of voluntary commitments, reaching the most ambitious legally binding targets for the protection of biodiversity and ecosystem services.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The extinction of animal and plant species has increased at a rate we have not seen before, and we are facing a very serious ecological crisis. Approximately one million – an unimaginable number – of animal and plant species are at risk of extinction. This is the most serious thing we've seen since the dinosaurs died out.  The loss of biodiversity also has devastating consequences for us humans. I think about when the bees die out; what then happens to food production, with our ability to make a living on this planet? At the same time, we continue to see a high level of pesticide use, not least in agriculture, and we know that this is one of the causes of the crisis we are experiencing.  We really need to reduce the amount of chemicals in our environment and put an immediate stop to reverse the development we are seeing. We know that the intensive use is dangerous. We also know that endocrine disruptors are particularly dangerous for our ecosystems and for us humans, and they are present in our everyday lives, all the time. Not least our children, we have one here, experience this in their everyday lives. It affects our health tremendously. We must set ambitious reduction targets for pesticides.  I am very proud of the work that has been done, and our group's priorities are well anchored in this resolution for COP15. I am pleased that we are aiming to achieve binding biodiversity targets. We will fight for that.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Thank you, colleague, and a greeting also to your beautiful child, who has made us company for this intervention.

name: Pascal CANFIN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we are discussing your strategy on biodiversity in Europe for 2030 this evening. That is fine, but there is already a European strategy, for 2020, and it has totally failed. None of the conservation objectives in Europe that we have set for ourselves will be met. Therefore, if you come back to us in a few weeks, at the end of February, with a strategy, with big numbers, good intentions, but without any concrete binding legislative elements that will allow us to change the situation, it will be a nice strategy but an unnecessary strategy. And what is expected in practice is 30% of the entire European territory that is protected to leave nature alone against the impacts of human activity. What we want is a binding reduction target for pesticide use and risks in Europe. What we want is for you to finally come back with a method of assessing the impact of these pesticides on bees. It has been several months since the European Parliament asked you the question, we are still waiting for your new proposal. And it is also to protect nature outside Europe. We, the European continent, are the most impactful in the world, by our consumption, on tropical forests. Come back with a concrete proposal to combat imported deforestation. That's all we want. If we do not have that, Commissioner, it will be a strategy for nothing.

name: Marie TOUSSAINT
text: Mr President, 75% of the earth's environment and 66% of the marine environment are at risk. One million out of eight species is on the verge of extinction. By destroying biodiversity, we are self-destructing. The future of humanity is threatened by those states that are ransacking the forests present on their territory or by these multinationals for whom oil can flow as long as profit flows with it. For too long, only money has been played out at borders. It is now the ecological imperative that must go beyond national logic if we are to defend our common future. Instead of continuing to plunder nature as if we could exploit it without limit, we must finally consider it as a planetary common that has the right to regenerate itself. This is not just a philosophical change: we must give nature a legal status to truly protect the living. The coming year will be crucial for the future of the planet: the UN has called for the preservation of 30% of the world's surface. If we want COP 15 not to be a failure as COP 25 was, Europe must take the necessary measures, re-establish Europe and recognise ecocides and the rights of nature.

name: Sylvia LIMMER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Who among us does not want this: clean air, clean rivers, an intact environment and the protection of native flora and fauna. I am immediately with you to participate in the appropriate framework conditions in a reasonable way. Of course, there should be heated discussions right here. For me, man is part of our ecosystem, while many green-left demands are already pondering whether the idea was not godfather, without humanity everything would be much better anyway. I am more concerned about the fundamental: environmental protection was yesterday, today the climate is saved hypocritically – with fatal consequences for the environment, which the climate-end-time youngsters care little about. Greta's troops acknowledge with astonishing ecological equanimity that the climate religion is the victim of landscape protection and, above all, many forest areas for wind turbines. Likewise, many areas are permanently sealed, which does not prevent them from demanding, with false fervor, better certification of products without deforestation. Can I laugh? On the one hand, there is lament of the overexploitation of the seas, the deterioration of coastal regions is lamented, and on the other hand, the Green Deal swears by the great importance of the seas for the construction of offshore wind turbines. And those who who once failed to prevent a ban on cadmium and lead in solar panels or sulphur hexafluoride, are now gruming about the use of pesticides and are also the same ones who do not at least shrug when the degradation of rare earths – in batteries, for example – is caused by highly radioactive thorium and other toxic waste products in China, and instead moan about the alleged stress of biodiversity. I would like to remind you that evolution and the transformation of the biosphere have always been the rule, not the exception. If we now trust these political cronies, who claim to be the holders of pure doctrine, to cross the road, then we make the buck a gardener. In any case, I do not. (The speaker declined a question about Sarah Wiemer's "blue card" procedure)

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the latest report of the Intergovernmental Platform on Biodiversity is alarming: more than one million animal and plant species, or one in eight species, are now threatened with extinction. This is the sixth mass extinction that is underway. Yet our leaders are not up to the task. The targets agreed in 2010 will not be achieved. Therefore, the decisions of COP 15 will be decisive. To be credible, the European Union must take strong measures and lead the entire international community. I'll give you two. First of all on pesticides: according to scientists, intensive agriculture is one of the major causes of biodiversity loss. Broad-spectrum pesticides, such as glyphosate, are particularly singled out. Our Parliament must now decide on their ban with a precise timetable for deploying the alternatives. Secondly, on the genetically modified organisms used to preserve pesticide crops: in 2001 we banned the techniques that existed at the time, but the major industrialists are trying to circumvent our regulations by introducing new GMOs, which nevertheless pose the same danger to our environment. It is time for our Parliament to stand in their way by banning them.

name: June Alison MUMMERY
text: – Mr President, while the upcoming UN biodiversity conference aims to build a common future for all life on Earth, when it comes to Britain’s seas, the EU’s attitude is little more than take, take, take. Just look at the vast amounts of biodiversity killed in British waters by Dutch electric pole fishing – a method banned by the Chinese for being too efficient. Or the super trawlers working in the Channel – gigantic factory ships which scoop of whole shoals of fish together with anything else in the area, such as the under strain sea bass and highly intelligent dolphins. These death trawlers are blamed for nearly wiping out whole fisheries in East Africa and destroying the incomes of some of the poorest people. These are only two small examples of the EU putting profit before biodiversity.  Until the EU takes action to stop practices which threaten the environment of its backyard, it has no right to lecture anyone else. The fact is, actions speak louder the words and the people are watching.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Biodiversity and climate protection must go hand in hand. When we set ambitious targets for climate protection in Paris, it is now time to draw up a clear roadmap for more biodiversity. For this, we need a strong signal from the EU in Kunming. This includes working for sustainable agriculture and forestry around the world, which makes a major contribution to biodiversity, habitats and ecosystems and has the potential to mitigate the effects of climate change. On the other hand, I do not think it makes sense to set objectives for the sake of the objectives and to pursue symbolic politics. Better regulation must be paramount in all measures, whether national, Europe-wide or internationally. For example, an extension of the protected area to 30% must be subject to a proper impact assessment. That is why I am calling for the common sense of the House to advocate sensible measures based on comprehensive impact assessments.

name: Sándor RÓNAI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Every day we have seen the tragic events of the loss of our planet in connection with the fire in Australia. They say that in addition to human tragedies and casualties, about a billion animals died in the fire. And drastically declining habitats could result in the extinction of new species. Moreover, the catastrophe is affecting the whole world. The smoke from the bushfire has spread all over the Earth. In New Zealand, the snow covering the mountains has been darkened, and the atmosphere can be affected throughout the planet.  This must be a warning to us Europeans. Wherever the climate catastrophe causes destruction anywhere in the world, it can affect everyone, us Europeans. There may also be a danger to our lives and to the survival of European species. Only in Australia ... (the President has withdrawn the floor from the Congressman) is threatened with extinction. It is our responsibility to prevent and preserve the biodiversity of our planet. The fact that we are diverse is a value that we must take care of at all costs.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Mr President, I usually talk about forests in the European Parliament, but today I will talk about cities, because 68% of the world's population will live in urban areas by 2050. We know that climate change increases the frequency of heat waves. We know that we will have much greater variations in rainfall.  In the case of a city that is also experiencing a high level of pollution - such as our Bucharest - the solutions could be: creating urban forests, creating a green belt, encouraging vertical gardens and green roofs. The idea of an intelligent city must also encompass the sustainability part, because we must have natural ecosystems corrected through the corridors so that the seeds spread easily. So we need European investment in green roofs, in parks, in private gardens, in green facades, which could create additional spaces for citizens.  Mr President, dear colleagues, cities should be integrated into nature, not the other way around. Nature is part of our life, it's not just a holiday destination.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are in the midst of the sixth major extinction of species, this time caused by humans. We are threatening a million species, and I think it is now high time to do something, and the UN targets are really good. However, we must also set ourselves targets in Europe, for example in the common agricultural policy. Agriculture in Europe, with its intensive farming, also contributes to the extinction of species. We must set very clear objectives for reducing pesticides, but also for reducing increased nitrogen inputs. We also have a responsibility to import 20 million hectares of soya, thereby promoting industrial agriculture in Europe. Here, too, we need to fundamentally change something.  We should not be subject to the verdict now either, 30% protected areas are good and 70% can be dirt areas. No, we must also extensify agriculture and forestry as a whole. And let me make one more point: we have tabled a motion that we need a moratorium on gene drives. This killer gene technique, we really do not need it.

name: Ivan DAVID
text: – Mr President, first of all, it must be said that the European Union as a whole is not a contracting party to the UN Convention on Biological Diversity. There are 193 UN countries. The European Commission's initiative is just another ambitious project to raise huge sums of money for vaguely defined projects. If natural diversity and the worsening of climate change are to be moderated, Europe should not engage in projects such as the EU Treaty with Mercosur, which will lead to further irreversible destruction of cattle forests and crop cultivation for export. Wildlife refuges are being destroyed by the greed of multinational corporations and overpopulation with resource depletion. In December, an industrial exploitation of fish from the Gambia River was approved by a majority of Members for a small fee, which will certainly not help indigenous peoples and wildlife. This is what care for natural diversity looks like in practice.

name: Petros KOKKALIS
text: – Mr President, Mr Commissioner, today this House overwhelmingly voted in favour of the Commission’s communication on the European Green Deal. In this proposal, the Commission promises to analyse the findings of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report on oceans and propose measures in the maritime area. A week ago, a report published in the Journal of Advances in Atmospheric Sciences confirmed that in the past 30 years the oceans are heating 450% faster than they were in the previous 20 years. The oceans, of course, retain 90% of the excessive anthropogenic heat in the atmosphere. The amount of excess heat absorbed by the oceans in these past 25 years equals 3.6 billion Hiroshima bombs.  As far as we know, the oceans are home to somewhere between half a million and 10 million marine species – in fact, the greatest habitat of biodiversity on our planet. In our resolution today we urge the Commission to give the Green Deal a blue dimension. I ask you, Commissioner, to finally put together a true European Blue Deal. It’s high time we took care of the high seas.

name: Michal WIEZIK
text: – Mr President, the protection of biodiversity means the protection of living conditions. This is the greatest challenge we face, we are existentially dependent on biodiversity conservation. We are clearly not doing enough to preserve biodiversity. Our action is the reason for the biodiversity crisis. The sixth mass extinction is caused by us – by taking, changing and destroying too much. Strict protection of natural ecosystems and wildlife populations is a necessary condition for rescue. We need to set aside large enough areas where we do not cut, fish, fish or build infrastructure. We must set aside areas where nature has space, and we must allocate them in the order of more than before. I am pleased that the resolution on the protection of biodiversity envisages this in the case of old forests and forests, but frankly, we are kind of happy to propose rules for the world, but we forget our homework. We also have magnificent forests in Europe, but we are lousy protectors. The extinction of species and the collapse of biodiversity cannot be undone. We need to tackle this problem with the utmost seriousness. It's about life.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to share a few things with you here. In 40 years, half of the coral reefs have disappeared. In 30 years, half of the forests have been felled. One million, yes, one million species will disappear in the next ten years. The reasons we know them: habitat degradation often orchestrated by humans, overexploitation of resources, climate change or pollution. We are all responsible for our bad daily habits, but we are also responsible for this disaster here, colleagues in the European Parliament, with some of our decisions, such as that of trade agreements with the end of the world, guided more by immediate profit than by the preservation of the environment and our ecosystem. If we human beings continue to behave as if we were the only species on Earth, we will end up being the last species before a well-deserved extinction. It is high time to understand that we are part of a whole and that if we do not preserve biodiversity, we will not survive. It's as simple as that.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Honourable President-in-Office. The conservation of life on earth depends on ecosystems, which depend on the conservation of biodiversity among living organisms.  For years, we have faced the threat of extinction of millions of animal species, with excessive use of agricultural land, pesticides, pollution. And the result? The earth is becoming biologically and genetically increasingly impoverished. We often forget that it is biodiversity that is the cornerstone of our economy, the means of survival, health, food safety and, ultimately, quality of life.   The latest impact assessments of the EU's biodiversity strategy so far are not very promising. The rate of extinction of endangered species continues to rise. It is time to change this, and this resolution is a good foundation on which the Commission can formulate a new, successful strategy. Let us show the world that protecting and maintaining nature while building a safe, inclusive and sustainable society is possible.

name: Tilly METZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Not only are we in a climate emergency, we are also in a biodiversity emergency. Have you noticed that it is getting quieter and quieter in the countryside? The birds fall silent, and the insects disappear. So the sixth major species extinction has long since begun, and we are simply continuing as before, business as usual at the expense of the next generation. It took millions of years for nature to develop biodiversity and complex ecosystems. It seems that it will only take humanity a few decades to destroy it. And yet we know exactly what we need to do: clear targets for pesticide reduction, no more imports of genetically manipulated plants, no more huge monocultures. We need to expand nature reserves, protect the forest, our waters and all ecosystems in general. Without the protection and restoration of biodiversity, there is no future for people either.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, the Irish National Parks and Wildlife Service report submitted to the UN Convention on Biological Diversity last year, also blames the pollinator decline on the obsession with intensive agriculture, the loss of hedgerows, and monocultures, including commercial forests made up of fast-growing coniferous species of low biodiversity value. This part of the report, in fact, accurately describes Irish government policy and its complete disregard for biodiversity. Hedgerow cutting was extended in the 2018 Heritage Act. The Irish government, and indeed the EU, still rewards intensive farming to the detriment of high-value nature farms and the Irish government’s obsession with, and over-dependence on, sitka spruce violates the basic principles of biodiversity. We need legally binding biodiversity targets at global an EU level and sufficient funding for these under the next EU long-term budget. We also need better enforcement of EU nature protection laws. We’ve got to care, Commissioner, or things will stay the same and get worse.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, biodiversity is the concept that subsumes the essential values of human life. At the same time, it provides benefits not only for us, but also for future generations. The human factor, however, causes a considerable decrease in it, with serious effects in the medium and long term.  Climate change or global warming in general is the destructive element for it. The European Green Agreement aims to be an instrument and mechanism by which Member States are determined, inter alia, to compete in the preservation of biodiversity. However, Member States need to understand that there is a need to come up with adequate and sufficient funding to achieve these objectives.  Agriculture must be seen as a partner in this battle to maintain biodiversity. Farmers must also be financially supported in order for their farming practices to be in line with environmental objectives. They can't do more with less money. Last but not least, research and innovation in the conservation and restoration of biodiversity must be adequately supported.

name: Caroline VOADEN
text: – Mr President, it doesn’t matter where we sit in this House or where we put our cross on the ballot paper. It doesn’t matter about the colour of our skin or the language that we speak. The biodiversity we have inherited is a precious resource that we all share and that we simply have to protect for our children and our grandchildren. The hideous fires in Australia, in which half a billion animals are thought to have perished, should serve as a wake up call to all of us. We must take serious action now to set concrete binding targets to protect nature, reduce carbon emissions and address the climate emergency. The EU’s biodiversity targets set for 2020 will not be met. Let’s try and do better before COP 15 with the 2030 targets. As I prepare to leave this House for the last time tomorrow, I implore you Commissioner and all my fellow MEPs, to be radical, be passionate, be strong, stand up to the money men and the vested interests, the oil barons and the chemical giants. We only have one planet. I won’t be here to fight for it but you will, make sure you do. (Applause)

name: Grace O'SULLIVAN
text: – Mr President, the COP meeting in China is biodiversity’s Paris Agreement moment. People have finally realised the urgency of the climate crisis, but have come to also understand that climate, and the biodiversity crisis are intertwined. As an ecological educator, I have always liked explaining by example.
