If we don’t protect biodiversity, the time will come when children won’t know what it is to pick a wild flower, and we’ll only know butterflies and ladybirds in picture books.  This is the EU’s moment to prove its commitment to stopping the huge destruction of habitats and the decline in species globally. This process cannot be completed without addressing the issue of agriculture and fishing.  Today we voted on a resolution on the European Green Deal. Probably the EU’s most ambitious environmental policy ever, but we know not enough is being done in regards to reforming the way we farm and fish in Europe. We must get serious. We must get COP on, and we must have action.

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Mr President, the protection and conservation of biodiversity is essential not only for the production of food, fuel and medicines, but also for a healthy life and sustainable local family business. We need to bring together biodiversity and climate protection as part of a long—term, nature—friendly economic development. The European Commission has to guarantee the biodiversity objectives, effectively monitoring key projects funded by the European Union. In my home country, Bulgaria, the Natura 2000 safeguard mechanisms are practically not implemented due to inadequate governmental policies in the field of tourism, transport, energy, agriculture and forest protection. The recent failure with Struma highway, Natura 2000 mismanagement and the case of Pirin National Park are only some of many problems. We need strong examples to show that there is political will to achieve the EU goals and to provide strict control and monitoring of EU policies.

name: Pierre KARLESKIND
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since at the moment we are looking a lot towards Australia, let us take a closer look because there is something else burning. Let's look a little closer under the surface of the water, let's look at this great coral reef that burns before our eyes. Rising temperatures, human activities, chemical and biological pollution, plastic of all kinds, all these elements have devastating effects on this great barrier. More broadly, according to the IPBES (Intergovernmental Science and Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services), two-thirds of the marine environment has been significantly altered by human action. But underwater, it goes relatively unnoticed, so let's take a closer look. Let us raise ambitious goals to rebuild marine biodiversity, bear the ambition of 30% marine protected areas, bear as much ambition for 100% of our ocean, this ocean that has been acting like a sponge for decades, but which is beginning to run out. Two points of the resolution are particularly urgent: that the European Union, the world's first maritime zone, make the ocean one of its priorities, and also that all parties to the convention recognise the ocean, as my colleague Catherine Chabaud would say, as a common good of humanity. Our future depends on it.

name: Jutta PAULUS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I have brought something with me here: this is the report 'The environment in Europe – state and outlook'. Of course, this is also available online and, of course, in all EU languages. It collects data from the last five years collected by the European Environment Agency on the environment in Europe. I say it straight away: it does not look good. Our natural resources are not in good condition. What is particularly worrying is that the species of the world is declining. I haven't seen partridge for ages, you rarely hear a lark. The key message in this report is that we must finally stop looking at biodiversity and species protection separately from other policy areas and supporting them with a few million, while at the same time putting many billions into nature-destroying economies. I am therefore pleased that this Parliament will adopt a strong resolution on biodiversity tomorrow, where there are many important points in it. I hope that these principles will also be reflected when we talk about the common agricultural policy or when we talk about the budget. Because we need these resources to improve the state of the environment in Europe.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: – Dear Chair of the Sitting! Dear colleagues, My grandson is very intrigued by ornithology, knows to tell or about each of several hundred flies. That's why my heart hurts that he might not see a black stork, a Philippine eagle, or anyone else. Around 150 species of plants, birds, animals and insects disappear every day worldwide, mainly as a result of human activity. I believe that intensive reduction in the use of agriculture, pesticides and herbicides should be an important step in the work. We must support organic farming and clean food without GMOs. Then, first, animal and plant health will be improved, biodiversity is promoted.  Secondly, such grown products are both healthier and tasty.  Thirdly, it is economically viable because the demand for clean food in the world is increasing.  I certainly expect ambitious support for biodiversity and adequate funding from the European Union budget.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Mr President, over the past ten years, our understanding and knowledge of the interdependence between fauna, flora and humans has progressed, but the destruction continues at a scale and speed never seen before. It has been mentioned that one million species are threatened with extinction according to 2019 figures from the IPBES, which is a group of international scientists. We really entered a tipping point period. The climate emergency calls for addressing this loss of biodiversity and these man-made factors, which endanger the future of humanity. And when I talk about becoming a human being, I think that the loss of biodiversity is impacting indigenous peoples. No one is talking about these indigenous peoples, and yet they are going into the preservation of biodiversity and they are playing a crucial role. At the same time, this loss of biodiversity has consequences for developing countries, food sovereignty and population health. Europe must therefore take a clear and strong position in Kunming, China at the end of 2020, and we have a duty to preserve this life, to replant forests, to clean up the oceans and to promote healthy agriculture without GMOs and pesticides.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to pin the loss of biodiversity to three figures and one insect. The figures are 84, 76 and 15. 84% of European crops depend on natural pollination by insects, the number of these flying insects has decreased by 76% within 30 years, and up to EUR 15 billion of the EU's annual agricultural yield is directly attributable to pollinators. This is dramatic, and in many ways. And one of these insects is the bee. Protecting them is therefore not only useful for reasons of animal welfare, biodiversity or ecological balance, but also economically. The bee dies for four reasons: firstly, varroa mite, secondly, global warming, thirdly monocultures and fourth pesticides and, above all, neonicotinoids. We are getting a grip on the Varroa mite, and I believe that we have done our homework well this morning with the new Green Deal on climate protection. My proposals on monoculture and pesticides: firstly, support family farms more. These bring diversity to the fields, save the bee and the profession of the farmer. Secondly, ban neonicotinoids, reduce pesticides and research alternatives. For if the bee dies, man dies. I do not know how you feel about this sentence, Commissioner, but I would like to prevent this.

name: Sarah WIENER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. We have heard a lot about biodiversity. In this minute, I would like to draw attention to a particular biodiversity issue, the largest ecosystem, the dirt under our feet, the soil. The soil is the last paradise under our feet and has so many microbial functions: water purification, storage functions, it feeds the whole world, so I think it's really time to talk again about soil guidelines, soil protection and humus protection. Because without soil everything will be nothing. A side fact is that we see what is broken on the ground, how it erodes, how it is blown away, how bacterial life decreases. Exactly the same thing happens in our gut. So the disease of the soil is also related to our own disease in our gut, which is the largest ecosystem among humans. My minute is up. I would just like to say: please protect the soil and intestines of all people.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, Commissioner Sinkevičius, it is obvious from the facts and data that we urgently need a new binding biodiversity strategy. The fires in the Arctic Circle, the Amazon and Australia have brought back to the fore in the most dramatic way the need to adopt binding targets for the conservation and restoration of biodiversity. With this weapon we must appear at COP15 in China, with this weapon we must put all the powers of the planet before their responsibilities and call for a binding agreement, similar to that of Paris. But first we as the European Union have to assume our responsibilities, with adequate funding from the new budget, with the protection of biodiversity, with the support of clean food and their producers, but also with the involvement of businesses. Good practices for the protection of biodiversity by businesses, such as Business for Nature, which also applies in Greece, can be our guide.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Many species of animals, plants and other organisms are wiped out by the massive use of chemicals, but also because we are taking more and more of their habitat away from them. However, another cause of species extinction is often ignored. This is the radio radiation, the intensity of which is constantly increasing. Many years of research have shown that radiation, for example, can interfere with orientation in bees and other animals, so that they fly away from home but can no longer find their way home. Mice sometimes become irreversibly infertile as early as the fifth generation. We have made similar observations in other animal species. If we continue to expand mobile communications as planned, many species of animals and plants will disappear irretrievably from this earth.

name: Nuno MELO
text: – Mr President, the European Union must make the oceans one of the priorities of its biodiversity strategy. Moreover, in my country, most of our territory is precisely sea. Biodiversity and healthy ecosystems, including oceans, which absorb more than 25% of CO2 emissions and are the main supplier of oxygen, are key to achieving the goals of the Paris Agreement and strengthening the European Union's resilience and adaptation capabilities to climate change, which will reduce ocean oxygen by up to 4% by 2100. And the effects of this decrease in oxygen will be dramatic for the habitats and coastal economies that depend on the oceans. We have seen one million species at risk of extinction, the degradation of coastal areas or the increase in plastic islands, which in the North Pacific are already seventeen times the size of Portugal. I'm finished, Mr President. We need a zero plastic policy in the oceans, to save the oceans, to prove that we want to win the battle of biodiversity.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We must do more for the protection of species worldwide and, of course, in the European Union. That is why tomorrow, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, we will be voting in favour of this resolution, and I would like to thank all those who have helped, especially, of course, for the PPE-DE in Agn's Evren. However, I would like to warn that when we talk about biodiversity, we always favour simple solutions – more protected areas, 30% everywhere, stricter infringement procedures. Let us also think about new ideas – better networking and– as Mr Jahr proposed in the agricultural reform – incentives for restoration, for example, re-irrigation of bogs. We must support this more and, unfortunately, I have to say so, we sometimes have to weigh up this. Sometimes European species protection law already brings conflict situations today, for example with human health, if you try to get traffic out of cities, then sometimes we have problems. That is why we are weighing up and, above all, not insulting farmers unilaterally, as is done in Amendment No 1. That really does not get us to the finish line. We must work together, not confrontation.

name: Ljudmila NOVAK
text: – Honourable President-in-Office. The Indians say the land is our mother, so we have to treat it very carefully. If we don't treat her carefully, it's very revenge. And we learn it day by day. The fact is that many animal and plant species have disappeared, so we must take action. At the same time, these measures must be life-long. So that people should not be angry about these excessive administrative measures. Every animal and plant species on this planet has its meaning, has a purpose. Although we sometimes get angry at insects, they are very important colleagues in pollination. The European Commission has an extremely large and important task – how to protect animal and plant species, while also meeting the needs of humans. It's not all farmers' fault. Our consumerism is also a great deal of blame for the pollution.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Mr President, our life on this planet is in jeopardy. The threat lies not only in climate change, but also in declining biodiversity. This threat is evidenced not only by the recent burning forests in the Amazon or by fires in Australia or, more recently, siberia, but also by the huge decline of bees and other insects that our generation normally encountered when visiting nature and were part of our lives. But we only have one planet, and we need to act now, but sensibly, and we must stop felling forests, we must stop using dangerous pesticides, nicotinoids, and expand protected areas. It is therefore right that we are debating here and adopting this resolution tomorrow. We must call on the Member States to do more, while at the same time allocing sufficient money to this and making these commitments legally binding. We must therefore also allocate money to this from the budget, but also from other horizontal programmes of the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, the objective of halting biodiversity loss by 2020 has failed. The rate of extinction of species has not slowed down, and on the contrary is accentuated, and the number of animal and plant species at risk of extinction is colossal. The repercussions on ecosystems and human communities will be serious. In this context, it is not enough to retread failed strategies, nor to proclaim ambitious goals but devoid of realistic means and enough for their achievement. What is expected at the level of the next Multiannual Financial Framework, Commissioner, is far from encouraging at this level as well. The solution is also not through forms of private appropriation and the commodification of nature and its resources, which only accentuate the problem. Habitat destruction and fragmentation, climate change, the introduction of invasive alien species into the environment are among the causes of biodiversity loss, inseparable causes of the prevailing economic model and the policies that underpin it. To consistently tackle these causes ultimately requires jeopardising this model and these policies.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank Members for their contributions and support for an ambitious biodiversity policy within the European Union and globally. I can only agree with Mr Luena, when he said we have only one planet and no ‘Planet B’. We have a huge responsibility to implement the transformative change that is required to put nature on the path to recovery by 2030. For the benefit of all people, yes, we need to be ambitious. We will need to explain very clearly to citizens and stakeholders why we need to change our patterns of consumption and production, highlight the benefits for well—being, health and for the economy, and ensure a just transition. Let me reassure you that I have taken good note and listened carefully to your call for legally—binding targets, to your comments on pesticides, sustainable agriculture, deforestation and gene—drive organisms. We are still discussing the biodiversity strategy internally, but action-oriented targets should be about integrating biodiversity across policies and sectors, including agriculture, forestry and fisheries, and about protecting and restoring nature. Of course, this should be evidence—based and well assessed. I am particularly grateful to Mr Kokkalis, Ms O’Sullivan, Mr Melo and Mr Karleskind for raising the important role of oceans – not only for biodiversity but also for mitigating climate change. As the Commissioner for Environment, Oceans and Fisheries, I am particularly sensitive to this topic, and I can reassure you that I will make sure that our Green Deal will also be a blue deal because, as you know, green without blue is only yellow. I’m looking forward to collaborating with the Parliament on implementing the European Green Deal on shaping an ambitious European Union 2030 Biodiversity Strategy and on preparing for a successful Biodiversity COP15 in October in Kunming. I am looking forward to the resolution that you adopt tomorrow. It will guide us when we finalise and adopt our biodiversity strategy over the coming weeks.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: In accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure, six motions for resolutions have been tabled. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 16 January 2020.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Peter Jahr's report on behalf of the Committee on Petitions on the work of the European Ombudsman in 2018 (2019/2134(INI)) (A9-0032/2019). I would also like to remind you at this point that you can ask for the possibility of spontaneous intervention and the use of the 'blue card', both in the usual way and through the electronic system. Instructions for use are available at the entrance of the Chamber.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the This week, we discussed very intensively the need for the European institutions to move closer to the citizen. We want to establish a European Convention so that citizens can have a say in how the European Union should develop and how to proceed – the key word: democratisation, the key word: transparency. However, ladies and gentlemen, please do not forget that with the European Ombudsman we have an institution that is very close to the citizen, and closer to the citizen, one could almost say, is not possible. You can get in touch with the Ombudsman directly, you can write to him, you can even say that you can touch him if you want. It is also important to bear in mind and to say that the Ombudsman is there for the citizens and not for the Council, not for the Commission and not for the European Parliament. In other words, as ombudsmen, we sometimes have to look at the institutions, the Commission and the Council, and yet we must cooperate intensively. I congratulate the Ombudsman, Emily O'Reilly, on their work and their constructive efforts to achieve this balancing act, if you like, to cooperate with us and to respect the interests of the citizens. It is a question of improving the quality of the management of the European Union and the access and quality of its services for citizens. In particular, I would like to commend Mrs O'Reilly's work on transparency in the Council, in which you – I would say this explicitly – have been strongly supported by Parliament. On the other hand, this has caused less joy in the Council. But transparency and public access to Council documents is essential, and it can really be said that the Council could cut off at least two slices of the European Parliament – no more and no less. We demand transparency from the Council, that is what we are doing, and that is what the Council should do. It is important that European Union legislative procedures are made more accountable to the public, and it is also important that we can bring this closer to the citizens. We call on the Council, as one of the two bodies of European legislation, not to act as a diplomatic forum, but to adapt its working methods to the standards of parliamentary democracy, as required by the Treaties. It was a pleasure for me to work on the report. We have had good cooperation between or with the rapporteurs. We have produced a good report, we have ensured that it has been depoliticised – I always call it this – so that it has been able to achieve a broad majority. That was really the case when the report was adopted in the Committee on Petitions by 28 votes in favour, one against and one abstention. This is also a good sign for the work of the Committee on Petitions, if you like, and also a good sign of cooperation between the Committee on Petitions and the Ombudsman. I hope that this can continue this year.

name: Emily O'Reilly
text: European Ombudsman. – Mr President, good evening everybody and thank you to Mr Jahr and to the shadow rapporteurs for your work on this report. It is always a great pleasure to present the annual reports of my office to Parliament. However, this year is particularly significant, as I am presenting our work to a new Parliament, with many new Members and which four weeks ago voted confidence in me and in that work by electing me for a second mandate. I am very grateful for that trust and I intend fully to live up to it. I also very much welcome the presence of Commissioner Šefčovič at this debate, which comes at the very beginning of this Commission’s mandate and I wish it well in the vital work it does for everyone in Europe and also for many beyond our borders, Honourable Members, as Ombudsman I am the bridge between citizens and the EU administration when problems arise and complaints are made. The complaints come from individuals, civil society organisations, businesses, journalists and often from Members of this Parliament. We apply not only EU law in our analysis, but also the principles of good administration, seeking a just outcome for citizens who are often overwhelmed by the at times technocratic nature and distance of the EU administration. We are not advocates, but we try to create a balanced playing field between the often powerless complainant and the very powerful institutions. The year 2018 saw a strong increase in complaints that fall within my mandate, and this continued in 2019. This is not because the EU administration lowered its standards, but because many more people became aware of the work of my office and what it has achieved and can achieve.  I am grateful to the EU institutions, agencies and bodies for their cooperation in this work. The vast majority of cases are dealt with through a strong collaborative engagement with the administration and it is important to acknowledge that. Yes, I highlight problems, because that is my job, but I also witness all of the good work of EU officials and have indeed publicly and tangibly acknowledged it through an awards scheme introduced to showcase and praise their work and to share good practice throughout the administration. As in previous years, accountability and transparency related inquiries made up the highest proportion of my office’s work. In 2018, I also used one of the Ombudsman’s infrequently used powers: that of submitting a Special Report to the European Parliament. This was only the second time I had done so since my first election as Ombudsman. In 2013, I told Parliament that this power should be used very rarely and only in particularly serious cases where an institution does not act upon Ombudsman recommendations. That Special Report concerned an inquiry into the accountability of the Council of the EU, notably through the lack of transparency of the legislative processes used for discussing and amending draft EU legislation. The public has a right to know how their governments contribute to shaping that EU legislation. Without that right being exercised, the ‘blame Brussels’ culture will continue with national Ministers obscuring their own role in the making of laws that affect their citizens. I was very grateful to receive the overwhelming support of the Plenary for my proposals. While these recommendations have met some resistance from larger Member States, I welcome the growing coalition of governments in Council that have publicly expressed support for such changes. At the moment, it is 10 Member States and I hope that the current Presidency and the following German Presidency will take up this issue of importance to European democracy and indeed legitimacy. As the European Ombudsman, I also coordinate the European Network of Ombudsmen – which consists of 96 offices in 36 European countries, with the European Parliament’s Committee on Petitions also being a member. The 2018 annual conference took place in April in the European Parliament in Brussels, with Michel Barnier as keynote speaker, and I am very grateful for the highly professional support of Parliament in helping us make the event such a success.  At the start of the Ombudsman’s new five-year mandate, it is important to ask and to examine what role it should play within the architecture of the EU in 2020 and beyond. If the Von der Leyen Commission is going to be the ‘geopolitical’ Commission, and become more involved in migration issues, foreign policy, defence cooperation and in tackling the global climate crisis – alongside several EU agencies – then who will provide oversight of this work? This Parliament will provide the democratic oversight, of course, and the Ombudsman must also provide oversight of an EU administration which arguably is more directly hands on and on the ground than ever before. Whether it is Frontex coordinating forced return flights for migrants, or EASO interviewing asylum seekers in the Greek islands, or the European Defence Agency trying to envisage the technology required for a 21st century battlefield, the EU is changing and so the Ombudsman must also adapt in order to keep pace with that change. However, the reality is that the Office consists of fewer than seventy (70) posts. We are receiving record numbers of complaints and dealing with more and more complex cases. The lack of resources of my Office has already been recognised by Parliament in the annual budgetary process and in the ongoing revision of the Ombudsman statute. However, I do ask that this issue is discussed further and in a more comprehensive way, and especially with the Commission and Council, and I hope we can find an agreed way forward. It is in the interest of all of us, that the Ombudsman’s office is fully equipped and resourced for the 21st century. We must be able to fulfil our role under the EU treaties, in line with the expectations of European citizens, and in this new ‘geopolitical’ world.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, Madam Ombudsman, I am very pleased to be here tonight and to have the opportunity to discuss with you the annual report of the activities of the European Ombudsman in 2018 and the report of the Committee on Petitions (PETI). Let me start by congratulating the rapporteur, Mr Peter Jahr, the coordinators of the PETI committee and its members who have been involved in this valuable work. As every year, these reports provide all EU institutions, agencies, bodies and offices with the views of Parliament on the issues that it considers as being noteworthy and important. As far as the Commission is concerned, I would like to assure you that the Commission is very much committed to ensuring good administration in our relations with the citizens, associations and businesses with whom we interact. This is a fundamental part of our work, and we attach great importance to the quality of these relations.  The Commission is indeed dedicated to the values of service, independence, responsibility, accountability, efficiency and transparency, and it strives to put the citizens’ right to good administration into practice and to avoid instances of maladministration. The cooperation with the European Ombudsman is key in this respect, especially as around two-thirds of European Ombudsman inquiries, namely 58.2% or 285 inquiries in 2018, concerned the European Commission. We are indeed the institution with the most direct administrative dealings with the citizens. Every year, the Commission agrees with around three-quarters of the European Ombudsman’s proposals, be they proposals for a solution, suggestions for improvement or recommendations. Thus, in most cases where the Ombudsman issues recommendations, proposals for a solution or suggestions for improvement, the Commission and the Ombudsman agree in the end. This explains why, at the end of the day, only around 6% of the inquiries end with finding of maladministration. In other words, the Ombudsman, after diligent inquiries, in an overwhelming majority of cases, closes complaints with no conclusions of maladministration on the side of the Commission, either because there was indeed no instance of maladministration or because a satisfying outcome could be achieved.  The Commission’s high standards of good administration have been highlighted by the European Ombudsman, notably on the occasion of the European Ombudsman award for good administration. In 2019, the Commission won the overall prize, which recognises initiatives having a visible and direct positive impact on the lives of people in Europe and beyond for its work on the reduction of plastic pollution and awareness—raising about single—use plastics. It also won several awards in different subcategories. The Commission is also aware that it has to continue to pave the way, assess, improve even more and, where necessary, correct its administrative practices. This is why the Commission will pursue the very constructive relationship it has built with the Ombudsman over the years, first and foremost in the interest of the European citizens and other interested parties. I look forward to the debate tonight with the Honourable Members, and I thank you already for your attention.

name: Cristian TERHEŞ
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Mr President, Commissioner, Mrs O'Reilly, as shadow rapporteur of this report, I can tell you that it is easy to work on a person's activity report when that person is very active and very professional in what he or she is doing. As shadow rapporteur from The S&D of Mrs O'Reilly's work in 2018, I was impressed by her professionalism, courage and dedication to defending the interests of the citizens of the European Union in relation to various institutions, which was also proven by the fact that she was re-elected to this position. Transparency, accountability of European officials, access to information and documents were several areas where Mrs O'Reilly was very active and where she came up with appropriate solutions. In this respect, Mrs O'Reilly has come up with concrete proposals to ensure the highest possible degree of transparency across all european institutions. Transparency is a fundamental element of the rule of law and I call on the new European Commission to take into account Mrs O'Reilly's proposals in this regard. Mr. Martin Selmayr.  According to Romanian law, as a parenthesis, such an act would have been classified as an act of corruption, and the guilty would have been prosecuted, at least for abuse of office and conflict of interest. It lacks credibility, and I am glad that we have a Commissioner present today at this debate, that various officials at european Commission level will lecture or lecture the Member States about the rule of law and the fight against corruption, when they themselves defy the rules, as the Juncker Commission has done. I encourage Mrs O'Reilly to be as courageous and committed in everything she does, to defend the interests of the citizens of the European Union, and on our part, both as members of the PETI Committee and as MEPs, we assure her of our full support. Good job and good luck, Ms O'Reilly.

name: Yana TOOM
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I don’t want to repeat what has been said before. I want to, but I don’t have time so I will not.  We all know that Emily O’Reilly has done an excellent job and I congratulate her on her re—election. However, this election has shown that there are some procedural problems. It will be our task in the Committee on Petitions to change or clarify the election procedure for the next term. It should be in line with the principles that the Ombudsman stands for: clear, transparent and fair. There should be rules on campaigning for, as we all know, this campaign, unfortunately, was kind of dirty sometimes, and we of course need a very clear timeframe so as not to put those candidates who are acting according to the rules into a vulnerable position in comparison with others. After the adoption of this report tomorrow, we also need a vision for the future. I agree with what was said by my colleagues from the PPE and S&D Groups, but I would like to highlight another thing. There are still things which have to be done regarding good administration in EU institutions, and the procedure behind Commission responses is one of them. When we send citizens’ complaints about Member States and possible infringements to the Commission, the Commission asks the national authorities about this. They ask the possible infringer whether they are breaking EU law, and the answer is of course always, ‘no’. What is interesting is that the Commission is normally satisfied with this answer and we receive answers from the Commission saying that there is no problem and no infringement. This means that we are not standing on the side of the citizen who is complaining and who is in an unequal battle with European bureaucracy. This needs to be changed. The same applies to the ‘EU Pilot’ where we can submit individual complaints about possible infringements. The process is not transparent. The documents of closed files are not openly available and getting them is a big problem. I would like to see a more proactive and more transparent approach, and of course I look forward to cooperating with the Ombudsman further and hopefully to solving this problem.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, I believe that the European Union is ill-placed to give lessons in morality or respect for human rights. Indeed, its institutions violate the most basic rules of ethics. This is particularly the case for the Brussels Commission and the European Central Bank, as evidenced by the European Ombudsman's 2018 report. Page 9, the Ombudsman denounces the way in which the European Commission appointed its Secretary General, The German Martin Selmayr in February 2018. On this occasion, it denounced "four instances of maladministration, including the creation of a fictitious state of emergency to fill the post". I take it that I was right to denounce the illegality of his appointment, both in this Chamber and in the Committee on Legal Affairs. Alas, it took 16 months to hear me and get rid of Selmayr. Following the scandal, the Ombudsman called for a detailed procedure for the appointment of the Secretary-General. Alas, it points out in its report that 'the Commission has refused to put such a procedure in place'. The lack of transparency therefore persists. On page 13, the Ombudsman also pins the European Central Bank and more specifically its President Mario Draghi, whom she accuses of having joined a private organisation, the "Group of 30", which includes the directors of the major private banks. Despite these admonitions, Draghi remained a member of the Group of 30. The Ombudsman infers very alarmingly that this is likely to cast doubt on the independence of the European Central Bank from financial lobbies. The Ombudsman thus confirms the reality of what I keep denouncing: the European Union lacks transparency and ethics.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear Ombudsman, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to congratulate you on your re-election as European Ombudsman, because this is the best possible recognition of your work so far. Also this report exhibition your activity in 2018 as the best ratings. The ECR Group, of course, fully supports this text. The beginning of the term of office, however, is a much better opportunity to talk about the future than about the past. I would very much like to ask you to pay particular attention to the lack of transparency in the decision-making process in the trilogue negotiations, the so-called trilogues. Unfortunately, this procedure becomes a caricature of what it should be. The most glaring example of this is the work on the mobility package in which I had the opportunity to participate. The impression of a democratic deficit in the European Union is to blame for the lack of transparency in the creation of European law. I am convinced that the European Ombudsman should look at the practice of creating it with particular attention.

name: Alexis GEORGOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the last elections have once again demonstrated the public's distrust of the European Union. It is therefore imperative that we decode the message sent to us by the peoples of Europe and recognise the need to try harder; Only in this way will citizens be able to be persuaded and in favour of European integration. It is not enough, then, to open the door for many to follow, but we must also shed a lot of light. In conclusion, citizens should become knowledgeable and sociable about the whole process. Transparency is not that citizens can be fully informed of what is happening but that they are informed in an easy-to-understand and understandable way, so that they can participate effectively at every stage of legislation. In this fight, we have our mediator Emily O'Reilly who, for another year, serves this position with absolute commitment. Ladies and gentlemen of the Commission and of the Council, do not ignore it.

name: Mario FURORE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by congratulating Mrs O'Reilly on her re-election and on her successful work to safeguard good administration. I would also like to thank Mr Jahr for the work he has done on this report, the content of which I support on the whole, with the exception of the paragraph on the ECB which, in my opinion, stands in stark opposition to the protection of the principles of openness and transparency inherent in decision-making processes at EU level. Among the positive aspects of the text, however, I note the recognition of the right of public access to documents of EU bodies as an inalienable right to be guaranteed to all citizens. A right today, however, strongly compromised by the regulatory framework, and I refer to Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001, the provisions of which, dating back almost twenty years, no longer reflect the current legal situation or the institutional practice used in this field today. I am therefore fully in line with the request for its revision. Equally positive are the passages in which the need to adopt much stricter standards and the highest ethical standards to prevent... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Furore, you still have time.

name: Mario FURORE
text: – ... I am therefore fully in line with the request for its revision. Equally positive are the passages in which the need to adopt much stricter rules and the highest ethical standards is highlighted in order to prevent conflicts of interest and revolving doors in all EU institutions, thus ensuring respect for the duty of integrity. It is the task of the Von der Leyen Commission to ensure that cases of maladministration, anti-ethical behaviour and regulatory violations, such as those found in the past in the Selmayr and Barroso cases, are no longer repeated, making a decisive u-turn in the name of good administration, full transparency and moral integrity.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We have certain speaking times here in this House. It doesn't help if you write things down and then read things down at double speed. Mr Emian, you are new to Parliament, and Mrs Evi has been with us for quite some time. She used to sit there, and she knows full well that there were colleagues I have already admonished. Perhaps you will consult them, which is appropriate if you have speaking time in the future.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, the EU Ombudsman plays a vital role in our European democracy, improving administration and ensuring that the ethics of our institutions are upheld, and I was delighted to see Emily O’Reilly re-elected in December. Emily, you’ve been an exemplary case of somebody who has advocated for transparency and good governance and, at a time when many of us – or many of our countries – are questioning the EU, and on the eve of our departure, your work on opening the black box of decision—making is needed more than ever.  This is my last speech in the European Parliament, representing my beautiful and diverse home region, the North East of England. It’s been an honour; it’s been a privilege. I hope at some point somebody else will sit in this seat representing my home. But, in the meantime, we’re going and I’d like to thank my current staff, Paul Ugo, Carla, Matt, Max and Malcolm, for their dedication and hard work during the most testing of times, and my previous staff as well. So from us, the British delegation in the Committee on Petitions, all we have to say is good luck and good night.  (Loud applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: It's usually not my job, but you were very moved straight. You said you were elected to the north-east of England. My hometown of Gerlingen has a twin town in the northeast, Seaham. I would ask you to share the best greetings to Seaham.

name: Marie-Pierre VEDRENNE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Ombudsman, thank you to the rapporteur for his work. Citizens' confidence in the European Union includes greater transparency. Progress has been made in our institutions, for example in the commercial field. The European Commission must continue to publish the negotiating documents and the Council to make the mandates public. Improvements are possible, as we have all pointed out, and they are necessary. The Council, specifically, must ensure more transparency in its operation. We must also put all our energy into en-agreement to be adopted as soon as possible for the establishment of the mandatory and legally binding common transparency register for representations of interest. Bringing citizens closer to the European institutions means effectively combating Euroscepticism. In this sense, we must all continue our work and strengthen the strategy launched by the Ombudsman to increase her visibility. You can count on my support.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to begin by congratulating Mrs O'Reilly on her re-election. His work has certainly been greatly appreciated by this Parliament. As is appreciated – and it has been correctly reported, in a very good way – the work carried out during 2018 in the report we are debating this evening, a report that once again calls, as we did in last year's report, for a transparency register to finally be introduced in a mandatory and legally binding manner, so that it is able to overcome the serious shortcomings in force on lobbying. We need much stricter rules for lobbying and preventing conflicts of interest, but also significant changes to make all decision-making processes truly transparent and accountable. If the Von der Leyen Commission really wants to change course on the wake of the disrespects made by the previous Juncker Commission, take these demands on its own and act accordingly. On the other hand, I disagree – and this is the only negative note in this report – with the paragraph in the same paragraph focusing on the ECB: contrary to what is stated in the text, I believe that the ban on MEMBERS of the ECB from participating in closed-door forums should be clear, especially if they are organised by or if the participants include banks supervised by the ECB itself.

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: – Sur President, l-ewwelnett nixtieq nifraħ flower Emily O'Reilly illi ġiet ikkonfermata bħala l-Ombudsman Ewropew. Dan huwa vot ta' fidu大ja fil-ħidma pożittiva illi wettqet sabiex l-Uffi大大ju tal-Ombudsman jibqa' wieħed a大大essibbli għaħa-ħdadidini Ewropej.  Sodisfatt illi f'dan ir rapport annwali l-Ombudsman Ewropew tkellmet dwar suġġett importanti ħafna għalija: dak tat-trattament tal-persuni b'diżabilità taħt l-iskema konġunta tas-Sigurtà f'każ ta' Mard.  Naqbel ukoll perfettament mar-rakkomandazzjoni flower-Gumsjoni sabiex jiġi rivedut ukoll il-provvediment ta' din l-iskema sabiex b'hekk ikun konformi wkoll mal-Konvenzjoni tal-Ġnus Magħda għall-persuni b'diżabilità.  Naqbel ukoll mar-rakkomandazzjoni dwar iż-żieda fl-a大大ikeessibilità għall-persuni neqsin mid-dawl fi pro大eduri ta' selezzjoni ta' kandidti f'uffi大大ji Ewropej. Hemm bżonn illi mill-aktar fis jiġu implimentati teknoloġiji ta' assistenza għall-kandidati li jpoġġu għal testijiet li jsiru bil-kompjuter.  Qabel nagħlaq, nixtieq nirringrazzja lil Jude illi kienet il-koordinatri大i tagħna fi ħdan il-kumitat, fi ħdan il-Grupp tas-Sos-So大jalisti, u d-Demokratii tal-impenn u d-dedikazzjoni li dejjem uriet. Ħa nimmissjawha ħafna.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament, in its annual report, once again congratulates Emily O'Reilly and the entire Office of the European Ombudsman on their excellent work. European citizens have found in the Ombudsman a valuable ally, which for years has been fighting to ensure the quality of the Union's administration, the transparency of its decisions, accessibility and the quality of services to the population. I would therefore like to wish Emily O'Reilly every success in her new term of office, a strong message of encouragement to pursue her important initiatives with determination – on all the improvement of the Council's decision-making mechanisms – and to always firmly oppose any episode of maladministration, as she did in the case of Selmayr's appointment as Secretary-General of the Commission. I can proudly say that I have worked with the Ombudsman over the years to stop the shameful practice of unpaid traineeships within the INSTITUTIONS of the European Union. We must now make a further effort: to fight to ban unpaid internships and traineeships in all the Member States of the Union.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I would like to conclude by saying that I support this report and I am happy for one particular article, which may look to colleagues as not being relevant, that it is formal, but the practice from the Czech Republic shows that it is very important. And that is Article 47, where the conditions for the performance of the ombudsman's duties are laid down. Impartiality, expertise, independence from political functions, but also moral prowess. Some may consider this a mere formality, but we have now witnessed a great public debate in the Czech Republic, when the President of the Republic proposed a new candidate for ombudsman, a prominent professor of criminal law, who, however, it turned out that in the 1970s she cooperated with communist prosecutors who sent some political prisoners in the Czech Republic to their deaths, such as Dr. Milada Horáková. And unfortunately, the big social debate relativized this candidate's moral wrongdoing. In the end, therefore, she resigned, and I am glad that in Europe we have a clear line that the Ombudsman must not only be professionally professed, but also morally professed. It's extremely important.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, I use this speaking time to add my voice to the appreciation of the very meaning of the institution of ombudsman, or ombudsperson, as some say, and particularly to congratulate you for your recent re-election by the plenary of this European Parliament. You have five years to go. It’s an appreciation of your work enhancing greater transparency and access to documents, although the regulation has yet to be updated. The work has been blocked by the Council, despite the efforts by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), which I chair.  There is also much work to do in order to make sure that conflicts of interest are no longer there, that revolving doors are out of the scene, that your inquiry on certain practices of certain industries, in particular, pharmaceutical industries, are compliant with the UN Convention on persons with disabilities, and, finally, that the code of good administration is upgraded into a real European regulation.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their statements and comments. I think that Mr Terheş has just started what was, as I have seen it, universal high praise for the great work done by Ms O’Reilly, which we in the Commission fully share.  To Ms Toom, I just would like to tell and to reassure her that if it comes to infringements and EU pilot procedures, I’m very much looking forward to our discussion in the Committee on Petitions (PETI), for which I just got an invitation, where we can go into more depth and discuss how we can improve our cooperation in this field as well. I also would like to inform the honourable Members of this House that on Tuesday, the Commission appointed a new Secretary-General fully following the procedure and, I believe, selecting a highly competent and exemplary professional and good European, Ms Juhansone, who I’m sure will be an excellent Secretary-General.  I would also like to add that the Commission clearly and constantly strives to ensure a very high level of good administration and we are going to work with you in that regard to make sure that the rights which are enshrined in Article 41 of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights will be fully respected and enjoyed by our citizens. Therefore, citizens, companies and associations with whom we have interaction can fully expect that they will get an open, accessible and properly managed administration from our side in the European Commission. I would like to also stress the fact that our daily exchanges with the Ombudsman help us to do it better every day, and that we jointly want to provide citizens with very high administrative standards, which are based on the principles of non-discrimination, courtesy, impartiality and consistency – a few of the points you also highlighted in your interventions.  Your resolution and the report of the Committee on Petitions on the annual report on the activities of the European Ombudsman stress areas where our institutions do well and where they can improve and I would just really like to promise you that in the coming weeks, the Commission will examine your resolution and will reply, as in the past, to all the issues which you raised and which concern the Commission.  I would also like to use this opportunity to thank Ms Kirton-Darling and Mr Corbett, who I see there as well, and all the UK colleagues and friends for their dedication, for their hard work. I just want to thank you and I want to tell you that we will miss you.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mrs Griffin, you would like to raise a point of order.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: – Maroš thank you for everything that you did in terms of the Green New Deal and energy poverty, and I would just like to say that we would like a definition of energy poverty from you and your colleagues in this mandate.  But seriously, thank you so much for everything that you did for vulnerable citizens.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Madam President, that was far beyond the Rules of Procedure, but after such a bit of a farewell mood, I did not interrupt you.

name: Emily O'Reilly
text: European Ombudsman. – Mr President, it’s very inspiring to listen to the support and the ideas that come from Parliament at this time. I look forward very much to further discussions with you over the coming months and years. Could I begin with Ms Kirton-Darling: it’s not often that an Irish person expresses sadness at seeing British people leave, but in this case I do want to say how sad we are, and also want to thank you for your wonderful cooperation and support with my office, and with the Ombudsman institution generally over the last number of years. I have to say, I was particularly impressed over the last few months, in particular in the last year, when things must have been so stressful for all of you. The diligence and the integrity with which you continue to do your work and take an interest in things here, and even in this small office, when there were so many bigger things clamouring for your attention. I wish you all of the very best and we will miss you, and thank you. Could I say, just taking up some of the points that were made. Thank you Mr Terheş for your comments, for your work and for your praise for my work and the work of the colleagues.  Ms Toom, thank you for taking note of issues that arose in relation to the election procedure, the Rules of Procedure. It won’t be my problem in five years’ time, but there is an important conversation to be had in relation to the election of the European Ombudsman. In relation to the case involving the former secretary, the appointment of the former Secretary-General of the Commission: yes, the outgoing Commission, the last Commission, did reject the recommendation. But as Vice-President Šefčovič has just noted, this time it was different, and the appointment of the new Secretary-General has been pretty much in line with the recommendations that we made in our investigation. Mr Złotowski: the trilogues – yes, we have investigated that in the past, it’s unfinished business, and we shall be going back to see what is happening there.  Mr Georgoulis: yes, citizens’ participation is absolutely vital, and particularly for the legitimacy of the EU, and that underpins so much of the work that we do. I agree with Mr Furore, the right of access 1049/2001 is an old regulation, but even short of revising it, there is still an awful lot we can do to have more recommendations accepted, more documents made accessible to the people whom we serve. Council transparency – yes, our big piece, work in progress, but I can see progress and I note in particular that from an issue that was somewhat marginal and somewhat within the Brussels and Strasbourg bubble, it is now becoming more mainstream. Ms Evi, thank you for all your great support. Transparency again: the ECB, all of these agencies and institutions – we need to open them up to greater public scrutiny into greater accountability. The comments in relation to disability, to assisted technology; we certainly take them on board, and we take those particular issues a particularly seriously. I was very pleased to see just last week, the EEAS advertising for paid traineeships, and that arises out of the joint work of my Office and with many people from the Parliament, led by Mr Benifei. So, many ideas there. Thank you again for your support and for once again re-electing me and trusting me with this very important Office.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the The cooperation between Ms O'Reilly and the Committee on Petitions in recent years has been good. One might ask: is everything okay in the European Union? No. But one can also ask: have we managed to improve things together? Then I would say yes. In other words, we should continue where we left off. There is still a lot of work to be done, let's tackle it. I say to you: the Committee on Petitions will give you explicit support in the matters that lie ahead – it has been mentioned – whether it is about greater transparency, the right to vote and other things. We will shape things together. I would like to stress once again that I also very much regret that our colleague Kirton-Darling has to leave the committee, Parliament. As coordinator of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I have seen some coordinators from the S&D Group. I would like to see a few more of your sort, and I am really sorry that you have to leave Parliament because of what I consider to be the wrong decision in your home country. But stay with us. Remember, there are also a few sensible Members in the European Parliament, and contact does not have to be cut off. I hope that the report will be voted on in a good way tomorrow. The report really deserves to get a huge majority, also so that we have better political support in order to continue working.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 16 January 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – Although we are discussing today the European Ombudsman's activity report for 2018, it is worth pointing out a few things so that this important role for citizens in the future will bring them the most benefits. Emily O'Reilly should be congratulated on her excellent work and constructive efforts to improve the quality of EU administration and the accessibility and quality of its services to citizens. For these reasons, the European Ombudsman's efforts to facilitate citizens' participation in eu policy-making should be supported. Each new Ombudsman should also continue to monitor the use of the Eci instrument, including monitoring the implementation of the revised ECI Regulation. It is also worth urging the European Ombudsman to continue to cooperate with national ombudsmen through the European Networks of Ombudsmen. Stresses, furthermore, the need to develop ways of cooperation between the various national ombudsmen that will help citizens to fight effectively for their rights. It is precisely such action that should become a priority in the European Parliament's recommendations to the Ombudsman.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the reform of the general principles of the comitology procedure (2019/2974(RSP)). Again and again, I would like to remind you that you can ask for the possibility of spontaneous intervention and the use of the 'blue card', both in the usual way and with the help of the electronic system. Instructions for use are available at the entrance to the Chamber.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first I would like to thank you for the opportunity to discuss the comitology framework with you.  The Treaty of Lisbon introduced the differentiation between delegated and implementing acts and, on this basis, the co—legislator adopted the Comitology Regulation. It lays down the mechanisms for control by Member States over the Commission’s exercise of implementing powers. The regulation also provides for the right of Parliament and the Council to be fully informed of the draft implementing acts submitted by the Commission to the committees of Member States. It also provides for a scrutiny right to address situations in which the Commission may have exceeded its implementing powers.  I think that it’s fair to say that the regulation is fulfilling its purpose. Why? Because, in 2018, the committees provided opinions on 1 633 draft implementing acts. There was no negative opinion and there were 32 so—called ‘no opinion’ cases in 2018. This ‘no opinion’ means that there is no qualified majority in favour or against draft implementing acts in the committee because of either the contrasting positions of the Member States or abstentions. In specific cases, the Appeal Committee must be consulted in such no—opinion scenarios. In 2018, this was the case for 12 draft implementing acts in the areas of health and consumer policy. In all of these 12 cases, the Appeal Committee also delivered a no, or lack of, opinion. It is precisely this very limited number of cases that have led to discussions, mainly because they have so far occurred in the politically sensitive areas of the authorisation of genetically modified food and feed and, to a lesser extent, in relation to the approval of active substances for plant protection products. When the Appeal Committee also delivers no opinion, the Commission may adopt the implementing act proposed. Indeed, the logic of the Comitology Regulation is only blocked from adopting an act if there is opinion in the Committee against it. This has been a guiding principle in comitology from the very beginning and ensures efficient implementation. As regards the 12 implementing acts in the areas of health and consumer policy, the respective substantive legal framework, not the Comitology Regulation, actually obliges the Commission to take the decision based on the procedural requirements and solid evidence gathered. In these cases of a lack of qualified majority in the Committee, the Commission has therefore been legally bound to take, at times, very unpopular decisions. The Juncker Commission therefore decided to propose, as a priority, to change these rules and put forward targeted amendments on the functioning of the Appeal Committee, with the objective of allowing for greater accountability on the part of the Member States in the decision—making process. The proposed amendments were the following: first, to calculate the qualified majority out of Member States which are present or represented and which do not abstain – and that means not all of the Member States; second, to provide for the possibility for a second referral to the Appeal Committee at ministerial level to address the problematic issues a second time; and, third, to make individual Member States’ representatives’ votes at Appeal Committee level public – this is what we discussed a few minutes ago – and to provide for the possibility to refer the matter to the Council for a non-binding opinion and overall political guidance.  Where do we stand with this proposal? Overall, there was practically no progress over the last close to three years. On the Council side, there has been no support whatsoever for this proposal. On the Parliament side, the lead Committee on Legal Affairs has not yet presented a draft report and only some opinion—giving committees supported the proposal. I therefore welcome today’s debate because it gives us the opportunity to collectively take stock of the situation. We have, however, to be realistic and frank. Unless there is a bold move that would help unblock this file, it is unlikely that progress will be made any time soon. The new Commission will factor this and your views today into ultimately deciding on how to proceed in the framework of the assessment of all pending proposals, ahead of the adoption of the Commission 2020 work programme. In any case, the Commission intends to continue to use all existing means to encourage Member States to take on their responsibility in the comitology process and to come to the solutions with Member States that find the widest possible support in the committee. Let me also refer to some concrete steps we are taking to improve the transparency of comitology, which I believe are also very important for this House. I will soon launch a new, modernised comitology register. The new public register will not only provide access to all draft implementing acts, but will also allow more user—friendly access to information on committees and their meetings. I will also work jointly with you and the Council to make sure that the non—binding delineation criteria between delegating and implementing acts that we agreed on last year will actually facilitate negotiations and bring benefits.  The Commission is fully committed to respecting the criteria when preparing legislative proposals and during legislative negotiations. In parallel, we must also jointly advance negotiations on the outstanding alignment of acts that still make reference to the regulatory procedure with scrutiny. We were very successful here in agreeing on the first package last year, but work needs to continue on the remaining parts of the package. I’m looking forward to hearing your views on this file because I believe it would help us in finalising the work on the Commission work programme for this year.

name: József SZÁJER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Vice—President of the Commission for his words. I would like to say that at the end of the last mandate, surprisingly, we had some progress, especially in the area of realignment in the comitology area. However, we did not get this specific dossier through. The Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) is just in the process of starting to consider this. However, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO), the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE), the Committee on International Trade (INTA), the Committee on Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) have provided opinions on the proposed regulation. These opinions underline the importance of keeping the comitology framework as it stands, since it’s working properly, but they also agree that the transparency aspect should be further enhanced. The JURI Committee is basically focusing on this request from the other committees, especially in the area of political transparency and accountability. In a number of high-profile cases, however, according to the present procedure, in the absence of a clear position from the Member State, the political responsibility for taking a final decision falls upon the Commission, which without clear political backing from the Member State, is an undesirable situation.  This is what the reform presented in 2007 was intended to remedy in full agreement with the general aim of the proposal. We have to face the fact, however, that taking into account the kind of resistance that most Member States show against it in the Council, the future of this reform is at least highly unpredictable and non-favourable. I particularly regret that the part of the proposal provoking this controversy among Member States also affects the rest of the suggestions, which are otherwise valuable and forward—looking in themselves. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Richard CORBETT
text: blue-card question. – Mr Szájer, do you not agree that if Member States, and indeed the Parliament, have conferred the power on the Commission to take a decision when the Member States cannot agree – remember to implement legislation that we have adopted but Council is unable to agree one way or another – that it is not unreasonable that the Commission should take its responsibilities and take a decision. And after all, the Commission is an executive that is responsible to this Parliament. It’s accountable to us. So it should take the decision and not actually try to divest itself of political responsibility through this proposal.

name: József SZÁJER
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Corbett, I’m not against that solution. I could very well back that. We understand at the moment that it has not moved in Council for several years. This is the situation. We can push it forward, we can be enthusiastic supporters of this idea, but I would like to go with the line that Vice-President Šefčovič has proposed: to be creative and find some way, especially in the area where we can enhance transparency and accountability. On this point, basically all the committees who gave their opinions agree.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has This debate must focus on two essential concepts: accountability of the Member States and transparency for the population. As the Commissioner has already mentioned, it is also possible for Member States not to express their opinion and pass the decision on to the Commission, even in politically very sensitive areas that have a direct impact on citizens' health and safety, such as authorisations, genetic engineering or the authorisation of active substances with pesticides. That is not satisfactory. This is really not satisfactory, because the lack of transparency means that a different voting behaviour in the respective Member States can be communicated to the outside world than it actually was, according to the motto: wash my fur, but please do not wet me. For these reasons, I am very positive about the Commission's proposals to improve the procedure: the change in the method of calculation, the mandatory referral to the Appeals Committee and also the publication of electoral behaviour in the Appeals Committee. I reject the proposal by some colleagues, which we have just heard in this House, that the Commission should withdraw the proposal and make a new proposal that the Council likes better. Because it must be clear to us that any new proposal will be a watered-down version of the current proposal. In conclusion, what is very important to me to make clear, Commissioner, is that the European Parliament wants to continue working on this dossier. It is the Council which, unfortunately, is blocking in this case and seems unable to take a decision on this essential issue. That is why I am calling on the Council this evening to finally adopt a position and, best of all, to agree to the Commission's proposal.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. "Mr President, Mr 'Ef-ovi', we are among ourselves, so maybe we can talk frankly, so we will do it. You are well aware that the Reason the Commission has given this text is because it is caught between the council's hammer and the anvil of the big companies who say: if you do not take a decision, we will sue the Commission and the European Union. You are therefore obliged to decide where the Council is frighteningly cowardly. We are still talking - and you have said this and we all know this - about the health of 500 million European consumers. We are talking about chemicals, GMOs, and I say this in Parliament, of which I am a member, we are now obliged to take objections. As you said, there are not many of them yet, but there are more and more of them, because we are in an increasingly complex society. We are asked, in fact, to decide urgently in binary: yes or no. It is no longer acceptable, it is no longer possible. I came to hear you first and foremost as to whether the Commission will continue to make this issue a priority, because it is one for democracy and for the citizens. We are not going to go into the details today as to how we can do it, but I think that giving a bonus to those who do not vote may be to increase cowardice, but it is another debate. In any case, I am pleased to hear you say that this is an issue that remains on the Commission's agenda for the coming year. I hope that Parliament can help you move forward. Let me close by paying tribute to the work of my colleague Richard Corbett, with whom we had drawn up an opinion in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs in the last term, to all the work that Richard has been able to do in this Parliament, and to say, in turn, how sorry I am to see Members like him leave us because of the lies of those who are there.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Dear President, Commissioner, colleagues. This morning, we debated a conference in this House on the future of Europe and agreed that europe of the future must be more democratic, more able to hear the voice of its citizens. The comitology procedure is perhaps the most critical of the European legislative order, which is the main criticism of democracy and the lack of transparency. Unfortunately, however, its gaps and the abuse of this mechanism by the Member States are particularly evident in decision-making, particularly on sensitive issues that have a direct impact on the quality of our food, the environment, human and animal health and welfare. As the responsible rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development of the Green Group, I would like to call on the new Commission to continue with the objective set by your predecessors, to reform the committee procedure as soon as possible, to ensure transparency in decision-making, and to limit the ability of Member States to avoid responsibility by abstaining from decision-making.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I, like my colleagues, support the reform of comitology. I believe that, in the case of the Commission's power to adopt implementing acts, it is very unfortunate if a significant part of these acts has been left without the opinion of individual Member States. It has already been described here that a number of important things are decided in these implementing acts – modified foods, pesticides, etc. On the other hand, we are in a state of creeping debate that has lasted for several years. We have debated this issue several times in the last parliamentary term, and it would probably be worth it for the Commission now to take this issue, which is more technically and not so important, because its importance is not assessed, and now try to push this proposal through the Council with new vigor or to obtain a clear opinion on whether certain modified material is acceptable to the Council. We agree that the current situation is not satisfactory, but we feel that there is simply no will to complete the process in any way. I mean, please, it's up to you, do your best.

name: Martin HOJSÍK
text: – Mr President, I think comitology is one of the amazing things about the European Union that no one understands, and we all talk about... (Interjection from the floor: ‘I do!’) – he does, but the public doesn’t! – (Laughter) and we talk about an EU close to the people, and that’s where we are missing out a lot. We also talk about transparency and accountability and this is something that this procedure is utterly lacking. Pesticides have been one of the hallmarks of the problems related to comitology. People don’t know how the governments voted, and what it ends up with is the general blame – Brussels decided, it’s a Brussels diktat – but at the end of the day, it’s the civil servants of the very Member States, of the very governments, who are there, taking the decisions, without public scrutiny.  I think this is something where we really need to change. I’m very happy to see that the Commission proposal is still on the table, but what we need now is really to start to get some movement in this House, but also with a renewed initiative from the Commission, so I hope that it’s going to end up on the work plan, but above all, from the Council, and maybe citizens need to step up their pressure.

name: Karen MELCHIOR
text: Mr President! I follow up on what my colleague Martin Hojsík said, namely that the European Union is the Union of Europeans and that we are here today because Europeans chose us to stand here. But I also know that there are many Europeans who feel that the European Union is a long way off. They don't understand what's going on and feel it's bureaucracy and technocracy. How many of us really understand comitology? There are few people in Europe, and even few people in this room. And if we cannot understand and explain comitology ourselves, how can we expect our voters - our Europeans - to understand and accept the way decisions are made? If we cannot explain our legislative processes, then we are failing in the fundamental democratic principles on which our Union is founded. It is an obligation that we can explain our democracy and our legislation to our electorate. That is why I support the renew Europe Group's desire to reform the principles of comitology and am pleased to hear that Commissioner Šefčovič also supports this.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, the points made by Ms Melchior and others were absolutely right. The comitology system is opaque and nobody in the wider public understands it. But of course we do have another system for delegating powers to the Commission, which is delegated acts, where it is clear and simple. We delegate powers to the Commission, but we can block their decision if we don’t like it, and we can even retrieve the powers that we have delegated if we wish to do so. This can be done unilaterally as Parliament, even though it was a joint decision with the Council to delegate the powers. Is that not an argument to make much greater use of delegated powers rather than implementing acts? Mr Szájer and I were the co-rapporteurs on the delimitation between implementing acts and delegated acts, but, frankly, we should make much more use of delegated acts. They are transparent and democratic.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would also like to thank honourable Members for the family atmosphere in this discussion on a highly legalistic and challenging topic. I agree with Mr Hojsík and also with Karen Melchior that it’s not easy to explain to our citizens how the implementing acts are being implemented and adopted. I would really like to reassure all of you that I took very good note of all your thoughts and suggestions, and I also want to make it clear that President von der Leyen and I are fully committed to deploy also this process and our special partnership to advance on the reforms in all aspects, including on promoting more transparency and accountability in this particular area.  I took very good note of Mr Szájer, Mr Ropė and also Mr Durand, with clear advice and points made in that direction. I would like to thank Mr Corbett also for explaining the difficult situation in which we are because when we are implementing and adopting, we are actually fulfilling the will of this House which was expressed as a co-legislator when adopting the legislative act. Therefore, our space for legislative manoeuvre is very often very limited and therefore what we would do is we will again try to advance this file and work with the Council and with you to really make sure that the procedures have more transparency and clarity in the future. I very much appreciate the fact that most of your suggestions and interventions went in the same direction as the Commission proposal, and I will do my best to actually get a better understanding of the position of the Council. I will work with the Croatian and, if necessary, the German Presidency to make sure that we get some traction on this file.  What would also help us would be a clear position from the European Parliament. I appreciate that several committees have already adopted their positions, but what we need is your clear position, a clear European Parliament stand on this issue. This gives my discussions with the Council more authority because we know that it is not only the Commission but also the European Parliament seeing things in the same way which can help us to advance the discussion further. So thank you very much for the support, for the ideas on this very important issue, and we will definitely work with you very closely on this.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I do not want to exaggerate the family atmosphere, Commissioner, but you said that the 'implementing acts' are what Parliament wants. I would like to admit that sometimes I am not entirely clear whether they are carrying out an 'implementing act' or an 'interpreting act' with this action. Perhaps we should talk about this occasionally. The debate is closed.
